document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: "Don't know enough about it!": awareness and attitudes toward organ donation and transplantation among the black Caribbean and black African population in Lambeth, Southwark, and Lewisham, United Kingdom.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
Demand for transplant organs in the UK far outweighs supply, this situation is particularly severe in the black African and black Caribbean populations with patients from these groups having a disproportionately greater presentation on kidney transplant waiting lists. This study assesses the current awareness and attitudes towards organ donation and transplantation in the black Caribbean and black African populations in Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham: London, UK.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: ‘Unheard voices’: listening to refugees and asylum seekers in the planning and delivery of mental health service provision in London
document.publisher: Commission for Patient and Public Involvement in Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PEOPLE WITH MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,MENTAL HEALTH,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,CLIENT GROUPS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ETHNIC GROUPS,DISADVANTAGED GROUPS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,PSYCHOLOGICAL DETERMINANTS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,APRIL 2010]]>
document.body:
Asylum seekers and refugees are more likely to experience poorer mental health than native populations.  This research audit and good practice guide on the mental health needs and provision of mental health services for refugees and asylum seekers is intended for use by health providers, service users, local authorities and other key statutory and voluntary agencies working with refugees and asylum seekers in London.

The guidance includes:

  • List of tables
  • Introduction
  • Research
  • Good practice guide
  • Mental health provision for asylum seekers detained in immigration detention centre's
  • Appendices
  • Bibliography
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: ‘We are not blaming anyone, but if we don't know about amenities, we cannot seek them out’: black and minority older people's views on the quality of local health and personal social services in England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Part of the National Service Framework for Older People (NSFOP) was improving access to culturally-appropriate services and doing more to meet the needs of black and minority ethnic (BME) older people. A mid-term independent review of NSFOP was led by the Healtcare Commission; this paper reports on the consultation process with older people that underpins that review.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 10 steps to your Single Equality Scheme
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
This guidance has been developed to assist NHS organisations that have a duty, as public authorities, to comply with the Race, Disability and Gender Public Sector Duties; and in anticipation of new duties in relation to age, religion and belief and sexual orientation. Whilst NHS organisations may develop different approaches to a Single Equality Scheme these easy to follow steps guide one through the necessary stages required to develop a generic approach to the common activities associated with the various duties.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A briefing on ethnic inequalities in access to treatments
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
CHD remains the commonest cause of premature death in London and is a major cause of health inequalities.

The CHD National Service Framework set a target rate of 1,500 revascularisations (specialist treatment for CHD) per million  population across England. The London rate was 1,245 pmp in 2002/03, above the national average, but short of the national target.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A common MYBPC3 (cardiac myosin binding protein C) variant associated with cardiomyopathies in south Asia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
Heart failure is a leading cause of mortality in south Asians though its genetic etiology still remains largely unknown.

A major monogenic cause of heart failure is cardiomyopathies due to sarcomeric mutations; this investigation describes a deletion of 25bp in MYBPC3 that is associated with heritable cardiomyopathies and an increased risk of heart failure particularly in Indian populations.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A comparative study of stress and unmet needs in carers of south Asian and white adults with learning disabilities
document.publisher: Ethnicity and Inequalities in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES]]>
document.body:
This study compares stress levels and the unmet service needs of informal carers of south Asian or white ethnicity who care for adults with learning disabilities.

The demographic details, strees levels and unmet service needs were compared and analysed using chi-square tests and regression analyses for 742 informal carers.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A controlled trial of the effectiveness of a diabetes education programme in a multi-ethnic community in Glasgow
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This study aimed to develop a culturally appropriate educational intervention program for south Asians with type 2 diabetes.

A multi-site prospective randomised controlled study was conducted in three general practices and all day care centres with a high proportion of patients from different ethnic minority groups in Glasgow. The intervention contained 18 educational sessions in 6 separate programs.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A description of some aspects of the triangular meeting between immigrant patients, their interpreters and GPs in primary health care in Stockholm, Sweden.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
This study is the first to combine the perspectives of immigrant patients, interpreters and general practitioners (GP's) during a consultation, the study's main aim was to describe some aspects of this consultation but also to measure patient satisfaction and whether interpreters or GP's experienced ethnic conflict during the consultation.

182 participants (52 patients, 65 GP's & 65 interpreters) took part in a questionnaire based study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A good practice guide for involving travellers in housing: guidelines for housing services on effective engagement and consultation with Irish travellers and gypsies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,CLIENT GROUPS,SERVICE DELIVERY,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ENVIRONMENT,ENVIRONMENTAL,ETHNICITY,ETHNIC GROUPS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,GYPSIES AND TRAVELLERS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,GROUPS,POPULATIONS,APRIL 2010,HOUSING]]>
document.body:
This good practice guide aims to be a resource for housing services to develop their knowledge of gypsy and Irish traveller accommodation issues and to guide them in ways of engaging more effectively with these communities in line with their statutory duties.  Developing ways of involving gypsies and travellers in processes of tackling the social exclusions they face is central to this guide.

The guide includes:

  • Chapter 1 - A brief introduction to gypsy and traveller communities in the UK
  • Chapter 2 - A examination of current policies on equality and accommodation and how they impact on travellers
  • Chapter 3 - Discusses the accommodation context for travellers
  • Chapter 4 - A case study showing the accommodation history of and Irish traveller in London
  • Chapter 5 - Identifies different service delivery methods that support travellers
  • Chapter 6 - Identifies barriers to collaboration between housing services and travellers.
  • Chapter 7 - Discusses the importance of ethnic monitoring
  • Chapter 8 - Discusses the impact of inter-agency forums on developing effective partnerships between statutory and voluntary services and the traveller community
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A meta analysis comparing the efficacy of omeprazole with H2 receptor antagonists for acute treatment of duodenal ulcer in Asian patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,OTHER,GASTROENTEROLOGY]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This review has been assessed by the UK Cochrane Centre as meeting all of the following criteria. Firstly it is a systematic review (rather than a practice guideline, economic analysis or decision analysis). Secondly it must be relevant to health care. Thirdly it must have explicit criteria for including studies in the review. Fourthly, at least one of the included studies must be an RCT and finally there must be a summary of included studies. The NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination has not evaluated the quality of this review any further.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of psycho-behavioral obesity interventions among US multiethnic and minority adults
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,BIOLOGICAL COMPOSITION,OBESITY,GENETICS,ADULTS,ETHNIC GROUPS,ETHNICITY,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,2009 APRIL,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,AGE GROUPS,GENOMICS,OBESOGENIC,2009]]>
document.body:
This review examines current psycho-behavioural interventions in reducing weight or preventing weight gains among US ethnic minority and multiethnic adults.

Data was examined from 24 controlled intervention studies which represented 23 different programs and involved 13,326 adults. The studies were identified using databases including: MEDLINE, Academic Search Premier, ERIC and PsycARTICLES.

CEEHD Note: This is a US study and some findings may not transfer to UK practice.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A practical guide to ethnic monitoring in the NHS and social care
document.publisher: DH/Health and Social Care Information Centre/NHS Employers
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING]]>
document.description: Best Practice Guidance
document.body:
This 61 page guide promotes the standard collection and use of ethnic group and related data on patients, service users and staff of the NHS and social services.

It shows good practice examples throughout the NHS and social care which will help them meet their responsibilities under the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000.

The guide includes:

  • Foreword
  • Executive summary
  • Introduction
  • The Department of Health's commitment to race equality
  • Why ethnic monitoring is important
  • Critical drivers to encourage ethnic monitoring
  • Ethnic group collections in the NHS and adult social care
  • National standards for ethnic group and related matters
  • How to identify, collect and report ethnicity data
  • Annexes
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A randomised controlled trial of an educational intervention for depression among Asian women in primary care in the United Kingdom
document.publisher: The International journal of social psychiatry
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
The objective of the study was to determine the effect of patient education on patient perspectives and outcome of depression in a sample of Asian women in primary care. DESIGN: A randomised, clinical trial of "patient education" versus "usual care".

CONCLUSIONS: Patients with common mental disorders, especially those with milder forms of the condition, who received the educational material had a higher recovery rate than patients who do not receive such education. The mechanism for this improvement was unclear, not being reflected in patient's apparent understanding of depression nor explained by change in general practitioner's response. The results of this study need to be replicated. (Ref. Cochrane)

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DIABETES,OTHER]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study identified lessons from and gaps in research on diet-disease links among former migrants in the United Kingdom including Caribbean-, South Asian, East African-, Irish- and Scottish-born adults.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A secondary analysis of primary care survey data to explore differences in response by ethnicity
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This report uses data collected from the Healthcare Commission's primary care patients survey to examine whether there are any significant differences in the experiences of patients from different ethnic groups. 

The report includes:

  • Introduction
  • Survey of primary care trust patients
  • Dataset
  • Methodology for our secondary analyis
  • Headline results from survey as published

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A sickle crisis?: a report of the National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (2008)
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,BLOOD DISORDERS,ETHNICITY LINKED DISORDERS,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,SECONDARY / HOSPITAL CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH LONG TERM & CHRONIC CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This 86 page report reviews the circumstances around deaths in patients with haemoglobinopathies - sickle cell disease and beta thalassaemia – in the 21st century in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and the Offshore Islands. The National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD) was interested in ascertaining remediable factors in the prophylaxis and  management of the clinical syndromes caused by:

• Sickle cell anaemia (HbSS)
• Sickle haemoglobin C (HbSC)
• Sickle haemoglobin D (HbSD)
• Sickle ß-thalassaemia (HbS ß-Thal)
• ß-thalassaemia major
• ß-thalassaemia intermedia.

It includes sections covering ongoing care, pain management, final clinical management, organisation of care, and death certification and autopsies.

To find a link to the original full text, the 'Executive Summary', a slide show presentation, 'Report Findings' and a self assessment checklist for trusts, see the NCEPOD web page.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of personality disorder, race and ethnicity: prevalence, aetiology and treatment
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
Psychoses and ethnicity is a relatively well researched field, however the importance of culture, race and ethnicity on personality disorders (PD) has been up to now overlooked.  This study systematically reviews the published literature on ethnic variations of prevalence, aetiology and treatment of PD.

A systematic review of PD and race, culture and ethnicity which included a narrative synthesis of observational data and meta-analyses of prevalence data with heterogeneity was conducted.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the literature on black and minority ethnic communities in sport and physical recreation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This systematic review examines participation in sport and physical recreation by black and minority ethnic (BME) communities in the UK.

Databases including Academic Search Premier, Sport Discus, Leisure Tourism Database, Sociological Abstracts, Physical Education Index and IngentaConnect were searched for relevant publications from 1998 to 2009.  Information held by sport councils and data from the 2001 census was also searched.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the methods and themes of health-related research on the Iranian diaspora: massive needs and opportunities
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study systematically reviewed methods used in population-based health research on Iranians to learn lessons to apply to future planned epidemiological research.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: A systematic review of treatments for post-traumatic stress disorder among refugees and asylum-seekers
document.publisher: The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
A consensus is emerging for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in the general population, however although refugees and asylum seekers have a rate of PTSD ten times that of the general population, no such consensus exists for this group.  A systematic review of randomized controlled trials of the treatment of PTSD among refugees and asylum seekers was conducted.

Ten randomized controlled trials met the criteria for the review.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Access of BME staff to senior positions in the NHS
document.publisher: NHS Institute for Innovation and Improvement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
This report examines any organisational barriers that may exist to black and ethnic minority (BME) staff rising to positions of authority in the NHS.

The report investigates how well the NHS is doing in recruiting BME staff into senior positions, examines organisational drivers supporting senior workforce diversity, and organisational and individual barriers to senior workforce diversity as well as providing analysis, conclusions and recommendations.

 

]]>

document.title: Access to diabetes services: the experiences of Bangladeshi people in Bradford, UK.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Rhodes, P., Nocon, A., & J. Wright. 2003. Access to diabetes services: the experiences of Bangladeshi people in Bradford, UK. Ethnicity & Health. vol. 8, pt. 3, pp. 171-88.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Access to genetic services by minority ethnic populations: a pilot study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,ETHNICITY LINKED DISORDERS,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,VOLUNTARY AND COMMUNITY SECTOR,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This is a pilot study report published by the Genetics Interest Group in 1999. This research report explored the provisions and access to genetic services by ethnic minority communities who have a poor uptake of such services; a fact that is well documented. The report's aim was to develop proposals for further work based on its findings.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Access to interpreting services in England: secondary analysis of national data
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS]]>
document.body:
This study aimed at estimating the number of people requiring language support amongst minority ethnic communities in England for health care.

A secondary analysis of the 1999 and 2004 health survey's was carried out.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Access to services with interpreters: user views
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS]]>
document.body:
The citizenship survey in 2001 indicated that 36% of people from minority ethnic groups spoke languages other than English at home with just under 14% of them needing somebody to interpret some or all of the questions for them in the survey.

This report investigates the experiences of people who need interpreters to access and use health, welfare and other services. 

The report includes:

  • Introduction to the issues
  • Researching lives in context
  • Ideals and process in using interpreters
  • 'Community', family and friends
  • Trust: personal and abstract qualities in interpreting
  • Conclusions and recommendations
  • References
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Accounts of carers' satisfaction with health care at the end of life: a comparison of first generation black Caribbeans and white patients with advanced disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body:
The final year of life of first generation black Caribbeans and white patients with advanced disease in an inner London health authority are compared, focusing on their satisfaction with service provision in both primary care and acute settings using face-to face interviews with carers of deceased patients. Includes examples of best practice in palliative care and culturally sensitive provision.

]]>

document.title: Achievements and challenges in ethnicity and health in NHS Scotland
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY]]>
document.body:
A report on the progress of the NHS in Scotland in delivering a culturally competent service that meets the diverse needs of people of different cultural backgrounds.

The report includes:

  • Foreword
  • A changing Scotland
  • Progress in NHS Scotland
  • A review of six years' work
  • Challenges for the future
  • Appendices
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Active surveillance for tuberculosis in Wales: 1996-2003

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Addressing ethnic diversity in health outcome measurement: a systematic and critical review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
'Patient reported outcome' measures are encountering increasing demand with the majority of health outcome measures being developed in English speaking countries such as the UK and the USA.  This systematic review explores whether the most commonly used health outcome measures that were developed in the UK or the USA could be routinely used and have comparable meaning for UK black and minority ethnic groups.

ASSIA, British Nursing Index, Cochrane Library, CINAHL, EMBASE, HMIC, Medline, PsycINFO, SCI and SSCI were used to identify relevant resources published between 1995 and 2003.  Local databases in India and Pakistan such as Indmed and PakMediNet were also searched for relevant papers.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Addressing ethnic inequalities in maternity service experiences and outcomes: responding to women's needs and preferences
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,BIRTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
The key messages from this better health briefing (Number 11) include:

  • Significant ethnic inequalities in maternity outcomes in the UK continue to persist
  • Determinants are multifactorial for ethnic health inequalities, though there is evidence that current service provision contributes to adverse outcomes for minority women
  • There are a number of barriers that undermine timely access to high quality care for many black and minority ethnic women
  • A greater level of engagement with service users in their local population needs to be adopted by commissioners, managers and practitioners to address inequalities.  
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: African and Caribbean men and mental health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
The key messages from this better health briefing (Number 5) include:

  • There is a complex relationship between race, racism and mental health with more research needed to understand the links
  • Black males find themselves in situations that olace them at greater risk of mental health problems
  • Black men are unaware of sources of help and are less able to identify mental health problems
  • African and Caribbean men are over-represented in mental health services
  • There is a delay in seeking help by African and Caribbean men has they have negative perceptions of mental health services
  • Mental health services are in a position to respond positively to the mental health needs of African and Caribbean men
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: African Caribbean hypertensive patients' perceptions and utilization of primary health care services
document.publisher: Primary Health Care Research and Development
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
Hypertension remains a major health issue amongst immigrant and UK born African Caribbean people, this study investigates African Caribbean hypertensive patients access, utilization and perceptions of primary health care.

36 participants were included in the study which involved two focus groups, 21 semi-structured interviews and five vignette-based interviews.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ageing & ethnicity: a demographic profile of BME older people in England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,VOLUNTARY AND COMMUNITY SECTOR,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This briefing is aimed at voluntary and statutory agencies working with and providing services for older people from BME communities.

The briefing includes:

  • Introduction
  • Britain's diverse communities
  • Ethnic breakdown of the population in England
  • Population of BME groups in England
  • Projected future trends in the BME population
  • The changing profile of England's BME population

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ageing, ethnicity and psychiatric services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
In 2001 the Royal College of Psychiatrists produced a report concluding that black and minority ethnic older people had received little attention from psychiatric services. One of the recommendations of the report currently under review is the introduction of a database of good practice and increased research.

This article looks at some of the issues that remain from the report as well as new ones that have since been identified.

]]>

document.title: Airway resistance measured by the interrupter technique: normative data for 2–10 year olds of three ethnicities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ McKenzie, S., A., et al. 2002. Airway resistance measured by the interrupter technique: normative data for 2-10 year olds of three ethnicities. Archives of Disease in Childhood. vol. 87, pp. 248-251.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Alcohol issues and the south Asian and African Caribbean communities: improving education, research and service development
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,PEOPLE WITH LONG TERM & CHRONIC CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This report investigates current knowledge about alcohol use and misuse in the south Asian and African-Caribbean communities and, in particular:

  • explores specific needs in relation to education and service provision
  • reviews current service planning and provision
  • reviews current research initiatives and their relevance to south Asian and African-Caribbean communities
  • considers the appropriateness of current research frameworks
  • provides an overview of the capacity for research within these communities

A shorter version of this report which forms part of the Alcohol Education and Research Council's (AERC) 'Insight' series (number 29) is available here.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Alcohol-related and hepatocellular cancer deaths by country of birth in England and Wales: analysis of mortality and census data
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
A comparison of mortality rates by country of birth for alcohol-related conditions, liver disease and hepatocellular cancer (HCC) to explore potential inequalities and inform clinical and preventative care.

An analysis of mortality for people aged 20 years and over using the 2001 census data and death data from 1999 and 2001-2003 was conducted.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: An exploration of explanatory models of illness amongst Pushtuun families living in the UK who are high attenders in general practice
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
This study explored the health beliefs and explanatory models of health illness in a Pakistani sub-population, who were high attenders at a UK general practice.  

The study found that these families were living in poor adverse social conditions and all the high attenders, plus five other family members, were found to have high scores above the screening threshold for clinical depression.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: An integrated intervention program to control diabetes in overweight Chinese women and men with type 2 diabetes
document.publisher: Asia Pacific Journal of Clinical Nutrition
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET]]>
document.body:
An evaluation of a structured and integrated intervention program on diabetes management for individuals with type 2 diabetes.

A 24 week randomised control trial was conducted using men and women with type 2 diabetes and a BMI of 23kg/m2. Participants were split into two groups; 1) a reference group (n = 50) recieved diabetes instruction while 2) the intervention group (n = 100) recieved a more intensive intervention.

CEEHD Note: While this study has not been conducted on a UK population it does show that an intensive, multi intervention can affect HbA1c. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: An overview of the research evidence on ethnicity and communication in healthcare
document.publisher: Centre for Evidence in Ethnicity, Health & Diversity (CEEHD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
Key messages for service planners, commissioners and providers are available in the full 'Executive Summary'.   Overall key messages are below.

 
 

Overall Key Recommendations:

  • Effective communication is central to safeguarding the quality of health care, especially in respect of the needs of members of cultural and linguistic or migrant minorities. Use of 'informal interpreters' in health care settings is dangerous and must be actively  discouraged
     
  • In the longer term, consideration needs to be given to moving from an approach based on the model of interpretation, translation, advocacy or language support service (ITALS), towards delivery of 'Culturally and Linguistically Appropriate Services' (CLASS).

  • Ethnic monitoring requires the identification of individuals as belonging to groups defined in terms of their culture and origin - this should include language (and religion) and should be enforced.

  • Health should develop language support policy and practice with other Government departments, perhaps through an inter-departmental working group: good practice already exists in legal services
     
  • Organisations should have in place policies, structures, practices, procedures, and dedicated resources to support linguistic competence (e.g. those defined by the US National Center for Cultural Competence)

 

]]>

document.title: Application of Framingham risk estimates to ethnic minorities in United Kingdom and implications for primary prevention of heart disease in general practice: cross sectional population based study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
This investigation aimed to compare the 10 year risk of CHD, stroke and CVD estimated from the Framingham equations.

1386 men and women (475 white, 447 south Asian and 464 of African origin) aged 40-59 years with no history of CVD and a subgroup of 1069 people without known diabetes, left ventrucular hypertrophy, peripheral vascular disease, renal impairment or target organ damage were included in the study.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,HUMAN RESOURCES]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Assessing equity in systematic reviews: realising the recommendations of the Commission on Social Determinants of Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
Following recommendations from the Commission of Social Determinants for Health, this article provides guidance on assessing equity for users and authors of systematic reviews of interventions with the aim of improving their relevance for both clinical practice and public policy making.

Challenges for equity occur in seven components of systematic reviews:

  • Developing a logic model
  • Defining disadvantage
  • Deciding on appropriate study design(s)
  • Identifying outcomes of interest
  • Process evaluation and understanding context
  • Analysing and presenting data
  • Judging applicability of results
]]>

document.title: Asthma in black African, black Caribbean and south Asian adolescents in the MRC DASH study: a cross sectional analysis.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
Ethnic differences in the prevalence of asthma in children is currently under researched, this study aims to determine the prevalence of asthma and atopic asthma in children from the main ethnic groups in the UK and to discover whether any differences are associated with differential distributions in social and psychosocial risk factors.

A cross-sectional analysis of 6,643 (80% ethnic minority) children aged 11-13 years was conducted.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Attitudes to colorectal cancer screening among ethnic minority groups in the UK
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,COLORECTAL (BOWEL) CANCER,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
There is a lower participation amongst ethnic minorities for cancer screening programmes than for the white population in the UK. This study investigates attitudes to screening for colorectal cancer amongst ethnic minority groups in the UK.

Open and closed-ended questions on attitudes to screening and knowledge of colorectal cancer were added to a monthly national survey of the main ethnic minority groups in the UK. 875 face to face interviews were conducted with ethnic minority adults including 125 with white-British adults.

Minority ethnic groups included in the study were: Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Caribbean, African and Chinese.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Attitudes to HPV vaccination among ethnic minority mothers in the UK: an exploratory qualitative study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN]]>
document.body:
Five major themes emerged from this study exploring attitudes to HPV vaccination among black and Asian mothers living in Britain, these were:

  • experience of vaccinination
  • awareness of HPV vaccination and reactions to the information
  • reasons for giving vaccination
  • concerns about vaccination
  • social influences

A qualitative study using face-to-face interviews was conducted with 10 black/black British and 10 Asian/Asian British mothers.  

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Better together: a guide for people in the health service on how you can help to build more cohesive communities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,SERVICE SECTORS,PUBLIC HEALTH,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,COMMUNITY AND DOMICILIARY SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This guide by the Institute of Community Cohesion and the Department of Health is intended to aid health workers and NHS trusts to contribute to community cohesion in the areas they operate and, conversely, how community cohesion can impact on health, wellbeing and health inequalities.

The guide offers practical advice on what types of policies and actions can help to improve relations between people from different backgrounds and indicates where tensions are likely to arise and the kind of actions that may increase competition between different communities.

The guide includes:

  • Executive summary
  • Key issues and recommendations
  • Introduction
  • Why community cohesion is an important issue for people working in health services
  • The nature of community cohesion
  • Ten challenging questions to help you contribute to community cohesion
  • Practical approaches to community cohesion
  • Building community cohesion into your management system
  • Appendices
]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE SECTORS,SERVICE DELIVERY,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,ENVIRONMENTAL,CAUSES OF HARM,ETHNIC GROUPS,ETHNICITY,SMOKING CESSATION,POLICY,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,SMOKING,TOBACCO USE,PSYCHOLOGICAL DETERMINANTS,LIFESTYLE,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,HEALTH BELIEFS,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,INFORMATION,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,GEOGRAPHY,NATIONAL,GROUPS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,SETTINGS,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This practical resource for health professionals includes background information and smoking statistics, and examples of projects and initiatives targetting black and minority ethnic groups. document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Black and minority ethnic groups in England: second health and lifestyle survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,STATISTICS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This report presents the findings of the second Health Education Authority (HEA) survey on the health and lifestyles of black and minority ethnic groups in Britain. While the first survey covered a range of key areas, including aspects of ethnic identity, and focused particularly on smoking, the second survey provides further reformation on the characteristics of black and minority ethnic people in Britain, featuring more detailed analyses of demography, language and religion. Issues relevant to circulatory disorders (including diabetes) are highlighted, both because these have been shown to be prime concerns of people of minority ethnicity, and also because they are major causes of morbidity and mortality among ethnic minorities.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Black and minority ethnic parents with mental health problems and their children
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
The key messages from this Social Care Institute for Excellence research briefing (Number 29) are:

  • Poverty, unemployment and homelessness are likely to be experienced by black and minority ethnic (BME) parents with mental health problems.
  • Lone parenting can increase the risks of mental health problems arising from isolation and lack of support.
  • BME communities are poorly served by mental health services.
  • Through lack of cultural sensitivity BME parents with mental health problems are often reluctant to use mental health services.
  • Mental health problems may become more severe through reluctance to access services.
  • Mental health problems in BME parents can contribute to the over representation of their children in the child care system.
]]>

document.body:

Sources for this systematic review with meta-analysis included MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, PsycINFO, ASSIA, SIGLE, HMIC, Web of Science, Cochrane database and the National Research Register.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Black women and breast health: a review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,BREAST CANCER,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN]]>
document.body:
Cancer screening inequalities exist in the UK for ethnic minority groups, with limited data for black British women on breast health awareness and an underrepresentation of black British women in breast cancer studies.  This literature review aims to explore the perceptions black British women have about breast health and cancer screening practices.

A literature search was conducted using BNI, CINAHL, PubMed, OSH-ROM, PsycInfo, Google Scholar and Scopus for relevant published material between 1994 and 2009.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Breast and bowel cancer screening uptake patterns over 15 years for UK south Asian ethnic minority populations, corrected for differences in socio-demographic characteristics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
Some studies have reported that uptake is low for cancer screening programs amongst south Asian populations in the UK.

Subjects for the study potentially included all residents of Coventry and Warwickshire, UK eligible for screening. Uptakes were compared for rounds 1 and 2 of a national bowel screening program and rounds 1, 2 and 5 of the NHS breast screening program. In total there was 240,140 for the bowel and 211,512 for the breast screening programs respectively.

Screening uptake was compared for two broad meta-categories (south Asian and non-Asian) and five Asian sub-groups: Hindu-Gujarati, Hindu-Other, Muslim, Sikh and south Asian other.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Cancer incidence and survival by major ethnic group, England, 2002 - 2006
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,STATISTICS,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
The primary aim of this report is the identification of cancers for which black and minority ethnic groups are at greater risk than white ethnic groups.

The report covers patients diagnosed with cancer in England between 2002-2006. Incidence results are provided for 16 specific sites of solid cancer together with a grouping of "brain and other central nrevous system" cancers. There are also results for Hodgkin disease, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, myeloma and all leukaemias.  

The report includes:

  • Introduction
  • Cancer incidence by major ethnic group
  • Cancer incidence and relative survival by major ethnic group
  • Glossary
]]>

document.body:
A summary of data on cancer incidence, mortality, risk factors and screening for five of the largest Asian American groups in California.

Analysis was restricted to the four most common cancers (prostate, breast, lung and colon/rectum) and for the three sites known to be most common in Asian Americans (stomach, liver and cervix).

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Cancer survival in five continents: a worldwide population-based study (CONCORD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
With cancer survival rates varying widely between nations, the CONCORD study provides survival estimates for 1.9 million people diagnosed with cancer aged between 15 and 99 years.

Patients diagnosed between 1990 and 1994 (followed until 1999) with breast, colon, rectum or prostate cancer were included in the study.  2, 800 life tables were constructed, with survival estimates adjusted for differences in the age structure of patients diagnosed with cancer.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Cardiovascular disease, diabetes and established risk factors among populations of sub-Saharan African descent in Europe: a literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
The leading cause of death globally is cardiovascular disease (CVD), this review looks at the current understanding of the epidemiology of vascular disease, diabetes and related risk factors among populations of sub-Saharan African descent in comparison with European populations.

Data from individual studies as well as systematic reviews known to the authors were examined as well as publications found using electronic resources (MEDLINE, EMBASE & Google Scholar). All studies reviewed date from 1960 to February 2009.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Care and respect in death: good practice guidance for NHS mortuary staff
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body:
This guidance provides a resource for those running and working in NHS mortuaries which they can use to review their practice and protocols against best practice, ensuring local systems are set up to minimise the opportunities for error, and ensuring they reflect the underlying principles of care and respect in all areas of their work.

Mortuaries are a vital part of the service the NHS gives to patients who die in hospital, or are brought to hospital after death, and to their families and friends.  Mortuary staff have an important and challenging role, providing an efficient service while responding sensitively to the needs of the bereaved.  This is a difficult job, and there are many caring and dedicated staff working in NHS mortuaries.  On the rare occasions when something goes wrong, however, the impact on bereaved families can be devastating. 

This guidance was developed by a working group including representatives of the various groups working in or with NHS mortuaries; and refined with input from a wide range of individuals and organisations including bereavement organisations, faith groups, minority ethnic groups and hospital chaplains.

The document can be downloaded, or hard copies can be ordered from the DH publications orderline by quoting the title and the code 275584 and:

  • emailing dh@prolog.uk.com
  • telephoning 08701 555 455 or
  • faxing 01623 724 524
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Carers from black and minority ethnic communities: an evidence and policy update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,VOLUNTARY AND COMMUNITY SECTOR]]>
document.body:
111-1Carers from black and minority ethnic communities: an evidence and policy updateWritten for the 'ethnicity and health' Annual Evidence Update 2010

Claire Gregory

Consultant to the Race Equality Foundation

 

 

Carers from black and minority ethnic communities:
an evidence and policy update

(Return to Index Page)

Introduction
The number of carers in the UK is projected to rise significantly over the next twenty years as a result of increased life expectancy and more people surviving with impairments [ref 1]. Recent estimates for those at the heavy end of caring, indicate that two to three million people are already providing thirty-five or more hours of care per week while the percentage of adults caring for at least fifty hours has more than doubled since 2001 [ref 2].

Although these figures include black and minority ethnic (BME) communities, there is a lack of baseline data regarding the numbers, role and experiences of BME carers. The low take-up of mainstream services suggests that many lack support and only come to the attention of services when they reach crisis point [ref 3]. Despite greater recognition of carers, the specific needs and circumstances of BME communities continue to lack visibility in social policy and mainstream service provision [ref 4] .

 

Policy Developments

The National Carers Strategy
Carers at the Heart of 21st Century Families and Communities: a caring system on your side, a life of your own [ref 1] sets out to balance an over reliance on family carers with sufficient support. It outlines strategic outcomes for the next ten years but has not provided the necessary guidance or recommended the appropriate pilots to ensure that services are delivered in ways that are accessible and sensitive to the specific needs of BME carers [ref 3]. The lack of progress in this area has to be questioned in the light of ‘race’ equality legislation and the clear articulation of these issues since the early 1990s [refs 5, 6].

The coalition government’s intention to ‘refresh’ the Carers Strategy [ref 7] takes place in the context of public spending cuts and ‘trade-offs’ between priorities, which may have consequences for carers left to fill gaps and for groups less able to access services.

Equality Act 2010
While there has been widespread concern that the shift to a single equalities agenda will detract from the significance of ‘race’ equality issues [refs 8, 9, 10], the Equality Act introduces new rights for carers on the grounds of their caring role, including protection from discrimination in the workplace and in the provision of goods and services. It requires public bodies to address inequality on the grounds of socio-economic disadvantage and is significant in terms of recognising that discrimination can occur on various grounds simultaneously. This provides an opportunity to address support needs arising from two or more protected characteristics; for example lesbian, gay, bisexual or trans carers from BME communities [ref 11].

‘Big Society’
The change of policy focus from the Labour Government to the Coalition Government's vision of a 'Big Society' [ref 12] holds opportunities and risks for the BME voluntary sector. It could be argued that BME communities and organisations are accustomed to operating a version of this voluntary and community-based model because of their exclusion from or neglect by statutory agencies . The BME voluntary sector has a key role in supporting carers but it experiences marginalisation, inadequate funding and lack of strategic representation [ref 3]. It will be important to ensure that BME specific needs are not overlooked in the planning of the new structures and strategies [ref 13].

Service User and Carer Involvement
Studies indicate that both carers and black and minority ethnic communities are under-represented in mainstream involvement initiatives as well as in service user movements and user organisations [refs 14, 15]. The National Black Carers and Carers Workers Network (NBCCWN) is currently promoting carer involvement through a National BME Carers Panel and has assisted carers to work strategically at local, regional and national levels [ref 4]. This has the potential to reduce health and social care inequalities, improve services and inform professional practice [ref 16].

The Personalisation Agenda
The involvement of users and carers is seen by many as central to achieving the objectives of the personalisation agenda, which aims to increase independence, choice and control through the introduction of self-directed support and individual budgets [ref 17]. To date, the up-take of direct payments by both carers and people from BME communities has been low [ref 18]. Pilot projects suggest that individual budgets have the potential to deliver the core outcomes of the National Carers Strategy [ref 1], but highlight the tension between a user-focused personalisation agenda and the recognition of carers’ independent rights and support needs [ref 18]. While direct payments and individual budgets have the potential to resolve the problems caused by standardised provision, carers could be left with the responsibility for managing them. This has implications for BME carers, who may encounter significant difficulties unless appropriate support is available [ref 3]. In addition, the notion of independence may be interpreted differently by BME communities, who may prefer a community-based approach and a more traditional service.

 

Future Developments

The NBCCWN has called for policy makers and service commissioners to utilise its experience and grass-roots knowledge so that the needs and circumstances of BME carers are made visible in policy, practice and service provision. Since BME organisations have a central role in supporting carers from these communities, they should be adequately resourced and involved in the design and delivery of services With appropriate infrastructure support, the BME voluntary sector could have a strategic role in promoting participation and ensuring that the inequalities experienced by carers in health and social care are addressed and not reproduced in current policy developments [refs 3, 19]. At the same time, the current climate of spending cuts and changes in policy focus hold threats for this sector, which could perpetuate disadvantage. It is imperative that social policy and mainstream service provision promote equality and address the specific needs of carers appropriately.

Who is a carer
A carer is someone who provides ongoing unpaid care for a child, relative, friend, partner or neighbour who cannot manage on their own due to disability, serious illness, mental health difficulties, frailty or substance misuse. Children and young people under eighteen, whose lives are significantly affected by caring responsibilities, are usually referred to as ‘young carers’, (adapted from The Princess Royal Trust for Carers, 2010).

Black and minority ethnic (BME)
The term ‘black and minority ethnic’ is used here to refer to communities racialised and minoritised in relation to the local population on the basis of their ‘racial,’ ‘ethnic’ or national origin. This includes established groups (e.g. African, Asian, African-Caribbean), new migrant communities (e.g. people from Eastern European countries), refugee and asylum seeker communities, transient communities (e.g. the Traveller community), and groups often referred to as ‘invisible minorities’ (e.g. the Irish community).

References and Additional Resources

  1. Department of Health (DH). (2008). Carers at the Heart of 21st Century Families and Communities:  a caring system on your side, a life of your own. London: Department of Health.
    [view details]

  2. The National Health Service Information Centre for Health and Social Care (The NHS IC). (2010). Survey of Carers in Households in England 2009/10. Provisional results.
    [view details]

  3. National Black Carers and Carers Workers Network (NBCCWN). (2008). Beyond We Care Too. Putting Black Carers in the Picture. London: Afiya Trust
    [view details]

  4. Gregory, C. (2010). Improving health and social care support for carers from black and minority ethnic communities. Better Health Briefing 20. London: Race Equality Foundation.
    [view details]

  5. Atkin, K. and Rollings, J. (1992) ‘Informal Care in Asian and Afro/ Caribbean Communities: A Literature Review.’ British Journal of Social Work 22: 405-418
    [download pdf]  May require payment or subscription

  6. Katbamna S., Ahmad W., Bhakta P., Baker R., Parker G. (2004). ‘Do they look after their own? Informal support for South Asian carers.’ Health and Social Care in Community 12 (5): 398-406.
    [view details]

  7. Burstow, P. (2010). Refreshing the national Carers Strategy – call for evidence.  London: Department of Health
    [view details]

  8. National Council for Voluntary Organisations. (NCVO). (2010). Third Sector Foresight: Approaches to race equality.
    [view details]

  9. Race on the Agenda. (ROTA). (2008). The Single Equality Bill: What it means for the BAME Third Sector. Policy Briefing (Issue 22).
    [view details]

  10. The Afiya Trust. (2010a). Achieving Equality in Health and Social Care. A framework for action. London: The Afiya Trust.
    [download pdf]

  11. Government Equalities Office (GEO). (2010). Equality Act 2010. London Government Equalities Office. London: Government Equalities Office.
    [view details]

  12. Cabinet Office. (2010). The Coalition: our programme for government. London: Cabinet Office.
    [download pdf]

     
  13. The Afiya Trust. (2010b) Equity and Excellence: Liberating the NHS. Response to the White Paper. London: The Afiya Trust
    [download pdf]

  14. Carr, S. (2004). Has Service User Participation Made a Difference to Social Care Services? Position Paper No. 3. London: Social Care Institute for Excellence.
    [download pdf]

  15. Kalathil, J. (2009). Dancing to Our Own Tunes: reassessing black and minority ethnic mental health service user involvement. London: Seagull Print.
    [view details]

  16. Stuart, O. (2008). User Participation in Health Care Services. Better Health Briefing 7. London: Race Equality Foundation.
    [view details]

  17. Glynn, M., Beresford, P., Bewley, C., Branfield, F., Butt, J., Croft, S., Dattani Pitt, K., Fleming, J., Flynn, R., Parmore, C., Postle, K. and Turner, M. (2008). Person-centred support: what service users and practitioners say. York: Joseph Rowntree Foundation
    [view details]

  18. Glendinning, C., Arksey, H., Jones, K., Moran, N., Netten, A. and Rabiee, P. (2009). The Individual Budgets Pilot Projects: impacts and outcomes for carers, Working Paper No. 1902 DHP.
    [download pdf]

  19. The Black Manifesto. (2010). The Price of Race Inequality.
    [download pdf]

Additional Resources

  1. Care Quality Commission (CQC). (2010). The State of Health Care and Adult Social Care in England. Key themes and quality of services in 2009. London: The Stationery Office.
    [download pdf]

  2. Commission for Social Care Inspection (CSCI). (2009). The State of Social Care in England 2007–2008, London: Commission for Social Care Inspection.
    [download pdf]

  3. Department of Health (2009). Report of the Standing Commission on Carers 2007-2009. Carers at the heart of 21st century families and communities – work in progress. London: Department of Health.
    [download pdf]

  4. Fox, A. (2009). Putting People First without putting carers second.
    [download pdf]

  5. nef (the new economics foundation) (2010) Ten Big Questions about the Big Society and ten ways to make the best of it. London: nef
    [view details]

  6. The Children’s Society. (nd). Family Inclusion Project. Knowing your responsibilities
    [download pdf]

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Celebrating our cultures: guidelines for mental health promotion with black and minority communities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This guide is intended for use by public health and health promotion specialists, voluntary sector workers, primary care workers, mental health workers and local authority workers amongst others.

The guide aims to:

  • Provide information and evidence about mental health promotion with black and minority ethnic communities
  • Support local workers to plan and deliver effective interventions
  • Offer examples in a range of settings of mental health promotion with different communities
  • Identify ways to evaluate mental health promotion interventions for impact and effectiveness with black and minority ethnic communities

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: Guidance is also available for African-Caribbean and south Asian communities and for refugees and asylum seekers.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Celebrating our cultures: guidelines for mental health promotion with the south Asian community
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
The south Asian community is the largest minority ethnic community in the UK consisting as it does just over 4% of the UK population.  The south Asian community is also the most diverse of the ethnic minority communities in the UK encompassing hundreds of languages and dialects, many religions and beliefs and people from different classes and countries.  Mental health issues for the south Asian community include: stigma, cultural beliefs and practices, low levels of education, alcohol misuse, high suicide rates and self harm and lack of knowledge of services.

This guidance is intended for GPs, voluntary sector workers, primary care workers, and mental health workers amongst others to help them engage with and develop mental health promotion for south Asian communities.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Celebrating our cultures: mental health promotion with refugees and asylum seekers
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
Refugees and asylum seekers come from different geographic areas and have different cultural backgrounds and religious customs.  Mental health issues that affect refugees and asylum seekers include: racism, cultural beliefs and practices, unemployment, displacement and lack of belonging, loss of identity, high rates of anxiety and depression and delay in seeking help.

This guidance is intended for GPs, voluntary sector workers, primary care workers, and mental health workers amongst others to help them engage with and develop mental health promotion for refugees and asylum seekers.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Celebrating our cultures: mental health promotion with the African Caribbean community
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
People of African-Caribbean origin make up 1.8% of the UK population and mainly live in communities based within inner city areas.  Mental health issues for the African-Caribbean community include: racism, language barriers, poverty, loneliness and isolation, high reported rates of schizophrenia and compulsory admission under the mental health act.

This guidance is intended for GPs, voluntary sector workers, primary care workers, and mental health workers amongst others to help them engage with and develop mental health promotion for African-Caribbean communities.

]]>

document.body:
This report is amongst the first to attempt to systematically collect information and data and provide recommendations and conclusions on the topic of health and migration.

The report contains information on:

  • A conceptual framework for health and migration
  • Recent trends in migration

  • An analysis of health problems in selected European countries
  • Conclusions and recommendations
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Colorectal cancer and ethnic minorities in Britain
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING]]>
document.body:
111-1Colorectal cancer and ethnic minorities in Britain

An Urgent Need to Improve the Evidence Base


We welcome the Cancer Library’s focus on colorectal cancer in its National Knowledge Week.  This is an important topic for ethnic minorities in Britain. [link to Cancer Library Knowledge Week pages]

Ethnic differences in cancer burden: It is often assumed that immigrants to Western nations experience fewer health problems such as cancer; although for Asian American women cancer is now the leading cause of death.  Recent evidence from the USA shows major differences in cancer burden among Asian American ethnic groups, including colorectal cancer [ref 1].  In India, five to ten-fold differences in regional incidence rates of colon cancer are reported [ref 2].  In certain other populations, such as Ashkenazi Jews, increased incidence of colorectal cancer has a genetic component [ref 3].  Far less is known about British ethnic minority populations.

A lack of UK data:  A recent report commissioned by Cancer Research UK has highlighted the absence of good data on cancer incidence, management, mortality and survival in British ethnic minority groups [ref 4].

Bowel cancer screening: Early diagnosis will be improved by the new NHS bowel cancer screening programme, launched in 2006.  Research shows, however, that members of the UK South Asian community are half as likely to successfully complete the home bowel screening kit as the majority population [ref 5].  A qualitative study of screening by flexible sigmoidoscopy also indicates poor knowledge and cultural barriers for UK ethnic minority communities [ref 6].  More generally, awareness of CRC is low in Europe and cultural differences are evident in public willingness to discuss bowel symptoms [ref 7].

Language needs:  The NHS is committed to promoting access to its services and reducing inequalities in health as required by the Race Relations Amendment Act 2000.  Our NHS Library brings together in one location information on key patient resources in various languages.  These include materials on bowel cancer screening [refs 8 & 9].

Resources

 

1. McCracken M. Olsen M. Chen MS Jr. Jemal A. Thun M. Cokkinides V. Deapen D. Ward E. Cancer incidence, mortality, and associated risk factors among Asian Americans of Chinese, Filipino, Vietnamese, Korean, and Japanese ethnicities. CA: a Cancer Journal for Clinicians. 57(4):190-205, 2007 [view detail]

2. Mohandas KM. Desai DC. Epidemiology of digestive tract cancers in India. V. Large and small bowel. Indian Journal of Gastroenterology. 18(3):118-21, 1999 Jul-Sep. [view detail]

3. Locker GY. Lynch HT. Genetic factors and colorectal cancer in Ashkenazi Jews. Familial Cancer. 3(3-4):215-21, 2004 [view detail]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Colorectal cancer: presentation and outcome in British south Asians
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
Although colorectal cancer (CRC) has a lower incidence in patients of south Asian ethnicity when compared with the general population, there is little data regarding the demographics of these patients. This study based in Leicester aims to define any potential differences in presentation, pathogenesis and outcome between white and south Asian ethnic groups.

The Leicester CRC database was used to identify patients of south Asian origin. Patients who were not of south Asian or white ethnicity were discarded from the study. A total of 3435 patients were included in the study, 134 were of south Asian ethnicity.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Coming and going: some aspects of care for migrants with HIV in the UK
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,HIV/AIDS,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH,INFECTIONS,MICROORGANISM,HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS (HIV),VIRUSES]]>
document.body:
The impact of people travelling more frequently, particularly to and from areas of high HIV seroprevalence is reflected in patterns of HIV in the UK and Europe.

This study investigates the factors effecting the prevention and treatment of HIV in migrant populations living in the UK.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Commissioning and providing mental health advocacy for African and Caribbean men
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES,POPULATIONS SERVED,DISEASE/CONDITION GROUPS,MENTAL HEALTH PROBLEMS,ETHNIC MINORITY GROUPS]]>
document.description: Series: SCIE Resource guide 10
document.body:
This guide aims to provide pointers for commissioners and providers of advocacy services to ensure that African and Caribbean men have access to appropriate mental health advocacy.

The guide covers:

  • Key messages from the research evidence
  • Policy
  • Principles to guide positive practice
  • Translating these principles into practice
  • Options for the organisation of advocacy
  • Examples of advocacy services for African and Caribbean men
  • Implications for mental health service users from other black and minority ethnic communities
  • Information about available resources

This guide draws heavily on Mtetezi - Developing mental health advocacy with African and Caribbean men, (click on link to view in NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Commissioning Services for Minorities
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,ECONOMICS,DETERMINANTS,ECONOMICS,ETHNICITY,COMMISSIONING,POPULATIONS SERVED,TYPES OF COMMISSIONING,ETHNIC MINORITY GROUPS,SERVICE PROVISION,COST EFFECTIVENESS,PUBLIC HEALTH,RACE EQUALITY,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,DECISION MAKING,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,SPECIALIST COMMISSIONING,2008-OCTOBER,CULTURAL IDENTITY,RACE,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body:
111-1Commissioning Services for Minorities

  for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2008

 Professor Helen Hally

National Director
'Race for Health'

There are three tasks that need to be undertaken if the NHS is to begin to achieve world class commissioning for people from black and minority ethnic backgrounds. We need these three first steps because the statistics of inequality are stark and deeply worrying: men and women of Indian origin three times more likely than most people to have diabetes; the prevalence of stroke 70 per cent higher for African Caribbean men than the average; south Asian people 50 per cent more likely to die prematurely from coronary heart disease than the general population.

The three tasks are straightforward - though they require real commitment on the part of PCTs (Primary Care Trusts) and other NHS organisations. First, commissioners need to know and understand the needs of their people. Second, policy in this area must plan to achieve measurable outcomes to narrow differences. Third, NHS organisations must fully implement the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000 [ref 1].

 

First
Let’s take these one by one. First – knowing your people. If you do not know your population well, then the consequences are serious. Hundreds of local people may have undiagnosed diabetes, coronary heart disease, peri-natal complications or mental health problems.  If you reach them, you can:

  • avert blindness, amputation and end stage renal failure
  • prevent heart attacks and strokes
  • save the lives of babies – and mothers.

So, it is vital make sure that your local population is profiled properly for language needs, religious affiliation, ethnicity and any other special needs.

Some areas are already doing this and reaping the benefits [ref 2].  For example, in Liverpool, 97 practices are developing better understanding of patients. Pauline Mitchell of Liverpool PCT explains:  ‘We give them training, so staff understand why profiling is important. We provide a tool kit containing a data collection form, a template to enter the data on the clinical system, information on BME health, contacts for community groups plus advice leaflets in different languages. We’re cross-matching CHD, BMI, diabetes and smoking status of patients against the new profiling data. Soon, we will spot where patients are not getting vital healthcare.’

The government recently announced that there will be extra money available for GPs, not only to profile new patients, as at present, but their entire lists, as a 'Directed Enhanced Service' [ref 3]. While the sums involved are not large, they put this issue of comprehensive patient profiling firmly on the agenda of all attentive practices.

 

Next
The next task is achieving measurable outcomes.  If we are serious about securing real improvements for people from black and minority ethnic (BME) communities, then we have to know health outcomes for local populations. Then it is possible to spot where there are differences for BME groups. Where BME communities are doing poorly, it is vital to make robust plans with measurable outcomes to narrow those differences.

Again, there are templates for doing this. All Race for Health’s PCTs have all pledged to address key performance indicators at Board level. They have pledged to develop detailed plans for activity and measurable improvements in conditions such as diabetes, perinatal mortality, coronary heart disease, mental health. We hope that, by 2010, we can, for the first time, begin to show clear improvements in the health of BME people as a result of policies undertaken to tackle their health disadvantage. For more information, visit 'Race for Health' online [see link after references].

 

Finally
The third step is obeying the law. The Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000 has clear requirements. Organisations within the NHS should be making sure that both staff and patients enjoy their fair entitlement – be it to jobs or services - regardless of ethnicity. They should also be taking care to ensure that their workforce is suitably developed [ref 4].  It seems simple enough, but there is substantial evidence that the law is not being fully applied.  On the other hand, many PCTs are taking their responsibilities seriously.

Stephen James of Ealing PCT, explains:  ‘We check what the law is and how it applies to us. So we know our general and specific duties. Next, we list our policies, functions and services and how they relate to race equality. We make sure that people know how, for example, to do a race equality impact assessment and have the capacity to do it, engaging with patients, the public, voluntary organisations and the workforce. Finally, we tell people what we are doing, by publishing it on our website and, face to face, in various forums.’

This three point plan, set out above, is explained in a handy booklet published by Race for Health and entitled:  'Towards race equality in health: a guide to policy and good practice for commissioning services' [ref 5]. This plan should be within the capability of every NHS organisation that has its heart in the right place. It sits easily with the requirements of World Class Commissioning and the NHS Next Stage Review.  The time for simply talking about race inequality is over. We know what we should be doing.

References

  1. Department of Health, 2005.  Department of Health race equality scheme 2005-2008.  London:  Department of Health
    [view details]

  2. Public Health Sector, John Moores University, 2000.  Ethnicity profiling in primary care: the Princes Park Health Centre model.  Liverpool:  Public Health Sector, John Moores University
    [view details]

  3. NHS Employers, 2008. Clinical directed enhanced services (DES) guidance for GMS contract 2008/09: delivering investment in general practice. [Appendix 5: Specification for a directed enhanced service in England: ethnicity].  London:  NHS Employers 
    [download pdf]

  4. Race for Health, 2007.  Towards race equality in health: guide to policy and good practice for workforce development.  Manchester:  Race for Health
    [view details]

  5. Race for Health, nd [2008].  Towards race equality in health: a guide to policy and good practice for commissioning services.  Manchester:  Race for Health
    [view details]

 

Note: Professor Helen Hally is National Director of Race for Health, a Department of Health, NHS-based programme. It works with PCTs and Hospital Trusts to drive forward improvements in health for people from black and minority ethnic backgrounds.


 

]]>
