document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Communication in the development of culturally competent palliative care services in the UK: a case study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This article presents some results from an exploratory study, comissioned by Luton Health Action Zone, to explore the role of communication in delivering effective palliative care services to South Asians living in Luton. The main issues were found to be the need to inform South Asian populations of the availability of palliative care services and the need to improve communication between patients and service providers. This article describes the communication problems that service providers and nurses face. It also identifies possible policy improvements aimed at developing the 'cultural competency' of services.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Communication of carrier status information following universal newborn screening for sickle cell disorders and cystic fibrosis: qualitative study of experience and practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS,ETHNICITY LINKED DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Current practice methods and experiences of communicating carrier status information following newborn screening for cystic fibrosis (CF) and sickle cell (SC) disorders are described and explored to inform practice and further research.

All nine health regions in England were included in three linked qualitative studies. 67 family members of 51 infants identified as carriers of CF and SC and child health screening co-ordinators were included in semi-structured interviews and focus groups.

This Health Technology Assessment includes:

  • Abstract
  • Glossary and list of abbreviations
  • Executive Summary
  • Introduction
  • Aims, objectives and overview
  • Current or proposed models of communicating newborn carrier information
  • Views and experiences of health professionals communicating results
  • Views and experiences of parents receiving carrier results
  • Discussion
  • Acknowledgements
  • References
  • Appendices
]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body:
Semi-structured interviews were carried out in Sylheti, the Bengali dialect of this community, with bereaved primary carers of 18 patients (10 male, eight female) referred to an east London community palliative care team between 1986 and 1993. It concludes by describing ethno-specific needs in this particular community.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study explored comparative levels and time trends in blood pressure, total cholesterol, body mass index and current smoking among UK Caucasian and south-Asian individuals in order to assess whether the comparatively higher cardiovascular disease burden in south-Asians is due to differences in risk factor levels and trends.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Comparison of elderly suicide rates among migrants in England and Wales with their country of origin.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
Over the last three decades the black and minority ethnic (BME) elderly population has progressively increased; this study is the first in over ten years to compare suicide rates among elderly migrants with those in their country of origin.

Data from the Office of National Statistics and the World Health Organisation was used to compare suicide rates.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Comparison of life events, substance misuse, service use and mental illness among african-Caribbean, black African and white British men in east London: a qualitative study
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,OUTCOMES,DETERMINANTS,ETHNICITY,MENTAL & BEHAVIOURAL DISORDERS,PUBLIC HEALTH,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,SUBSTANCE MISUSE,URBAN AREAS,GEOGRAPHY,2008-JULY,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,POPULATIONS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,SETTINGS,RACE]]>
document.body:
This paper reports the findings of a study that explored the experiences of African-Caribbean, black African and white British men who report a dual diagnosis and are in contact with health and social care services in east London. 

Dual diagnosis refers to service users with both identified mental health difficulties, for example schizophrenia, borderline personality disorders, bi-polar disorders, and some addictions or problematic substance abuse issues, such as to heroin, crack, marijuana, khat, prescription drugs or alcohol.

]]>

document.title: Coronary heart disease: contrasting the health beliefs and behaviours of South Asian communities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CAUSES AND RISK FACTORS,CONDITIONS,PREVENTION,ALCOHOL DRINKING,CORONARY HEART DISEASE,DIET,GENERAL,GENERAL,DIET,OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,SMOKING,SMOKING CESSATION,CAUSES AND RISK FACTORS,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,PREVENTION,ETHNIC GROUPS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study was commissioned by the Health Education Authority to explore the health education needs of South Asian communities living in the UK. South Asians include those from India, East Africa, Pakistan and Bangladesh. The report looks at variation by level of education, socioeconomic group, alcohol, chewing of tobacco, physical activity, diet and dietary health education and personal risk of coronary heart disease (CHD).]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,RACE EQUALITY,PUBLIC HEALTH,OUTCOMES,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,POPULATIONS,SETTINGS,GROUPS,DISABILITIES,LEARNING DISABILITIES,MENTAL & BEHAVIOURAL DISORDERS,ETHNIC GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES,METHODS,ANALYSIS,MEASUREMENT,GEOGRAPHY,NATIONAL]]>
document.body:
This report aims to:

  • Obtain accurate figures for inpaitents in mental health and learning disability services in England and wales
  • Encourage the implementation of procedures for comprehensive recording and monitoring on the ethnic group of patients
  • Help health services move towards achieving the "Delivering Race Equality in Mental Health Care" scheme.

The report includes:

  • Executive summary 
  • Introduction
  • Information about learning disabilities
  • National organisations coordinating the census
  • Data, methods of analysis and interpretation
  • Results: mental health
  • Results: learning disabilities

  • References
  • Appendices

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Count me in 2008: results of the 2008 national census of inpatients in mental health and learning disability services in England and Wales
document.publisher: Commission for Healthcare Audit and Inspection
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES]]>
document.body:
This is the fourth national census of the ethnicity of all inpatients in NHS and independent mental health and learning disability hospitals and facilities in England and Wales. It was conducted on 31 March 2008, and follows a similar census carried out in 2006 and 2007, and a census of inpatients in mental health services only, which was carried out in 2005.

The report includes:

  • Summary
  • Introduction
  • National organisations coordinating the census
  • Data, methods of analysis and interpretation
  • Results: mental health
  • Results: learning disabilities
  • Conclusions
  • References
  • Appendices
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Count me in: results of a national census of inpatients in mental health hospitals and facilities in England and Wales
document.publisher: Commission for Healthcare Audit and Inspection
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY]]>
document.body:
Ethnic monitoring has been mandatory in publicly funded mental health services since 1995.  This is a report of a census conducted with on inpatients in mental health hospitals and facilities in England and Wales.  The census was intended primarily to achieve two things: to encourage sustainable, high quality ethnic assessment and monitoring; and to provide a baseline against which we can measure changes in mental health care in the future.

The report includes:

  • Foreword
  • About the census
  • Results of the census
  • The way forward
  • Supporting data
  • References
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: C-reactive protein and the insulin-like growth factor (IGF)-system in relation to risk of cardiovascular disease in different ethnic groups.
document.publisher: The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) 2006
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DIABETES]]>
document.body:
This study examines C-reactive protein (CRP) in ethnic groups with differing risk levels for cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes and their relationship with insulin sensitivity and the IGF system.

A random sample of 440 participants were included in the study. Ethnic goups involved in the study were: European (155), Pakistani (108) and African Caribbean (177).

]]>

31 articles published between 2000 and 2005 on ethnicity and cancer/palliative care were reviewed.

document.body: <![CDATA[ Key questions on tobacco use in Urdu, Cantonese, Punjabi and Sylheti from existing surveys were compiled. Members of the Pakistani, Chinese, Indian Sikh and Bangladeshi communities were consulted one-to-one and in groups to assess the appropriateness of the questions.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Cross-language generalization following treatment in bilingual speakers with aphasia: a review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This review focuses on the potential transfer or generalization of positive effects from a treated to an untreated language in bilingual or multilingual people with primary acquired aphasia.

Twelve studies previously published in English language peer-reviewed journals were included.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: This is a US study and some findings may not transfer to UK practice.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Cultural competence in mental health care: a review of model evaluations
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.description: Systematic review of models of cultural competency intervention in mental health care (all located in North America)
document.body: <![CDATA[ A systematic review of cultural competence models in mental health located 109 papers but only 9 included any evaluation: all were conducted in North America and few show conclusive evidence of change. None explored change of outcome for service users. The term 'cultural competence' remains contested.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Cultural diversity teaching in the medical undergraduate curriculum
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Since 1993 the General Medical Council has recommended that cultural diversity be included in UK medical school teaching. This study discusses a number of training models and evaluates the results of a study conducted into the views of medical education stakeholders on the organisation of cultural diversity teaching.

Semi-structured qualitative interviews were carried out with 61 stakeholders.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Cultural meanings of pain: a qualitative study of black Caribbean and white British patients with advanced cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
Little research has been conducted on the symptom of pain in cancer across different ethnic groups, this study explored and compared the meanings of pain amongst black Caribbean and white patients with advanced cancer.

Qualitative interviews were conducted with 26 black Caribbean and 19 white patients recruited from oncology outpatient clinics.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Cultural racism, language prejudice and discrimination in hospital contexts: an Australian study
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,SECONDARY / HOSPITAL CARE]]>
document.body:
Unacknowledged practices of cultural racism may contribute to racial and ethnic disparities in healthcare.  This study describes and discusses the practice of language prejudice by health service providers.

145 participants were drawn from 17 different organisations.  Participants included health service managers, ethnic liaison officers, interpreters, cultural trainers/educators and healthcare consumers.  Participants were drawn from 27 different ethnocultural and language backgrounds.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: This is an Australian study and some findings may not transfer to UK practice.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Culture and care in dementia: a study of the Asian community in North West Kent
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This report is the result of a project conducted over two years to explore the service related needs of Asian older people with dementia and their carers in Dartford and Gravesham.

The key aims of the project were:

  • Investigate the needs of older Asian people with dementia
  • Discover why dementia services are currently underused by Asians
  • Explore the service needs of Asians with dementia
  • Raise awareness and knowledge about dementia

The report includes:

  • Foreword
  • Executive summary
  • Introduction
  • Aims and methods
  • Stages of the project
  • Findings and discussion
  • Implications and conclusions
  • Appendices
  • References 
]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
Populations from the Indian subcontinent are known to have a higher prevalence of the metabolic syndrome (MetS), CVD and type 2 diabetes (T2D) than the general UK population. While identification of this increased risk is crucial to allow for effective treatment, there is controversy over the applicability of diagnostic criteria, and particularly measures of adiposity in ethnic minorities.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Delivering race equality focused implementation site project 2005 - 2008: evaluation report
document.publisher: Central and North West London NHS
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING]]>
document.body:
The Focused Implementation Site Project took place between 2005 and 2008 in the London boroughs of Brent, Harrow, Westminster and Kensington & Chelsea.

The key aims of the project listed in this evaluation report were:

  • A reduction in the disproportionate rate of admission of people from BME communities to psychiatric inpatient units
  • A reduction in the disproportionate rates of compulsory detention of BME users in inpatient units
  • A reduction in the proportion of prisoners from BME communities
  • A more active role for BME communities and BME service users in the
    training of professionals, in the development of mental health policy, and in the planning and provision of services
  • A workforce and organisation capable of delivering appropriate and
    responsive mental health services to BME communities
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Delivering race equality in mental health care: an action plan for reform inside and outside services and the Government’s response to the independent inquiry into the death of David Bennett
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PEOPLE WITH MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MENTAL HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING,SERVICE SECTORS,SECONDARY / HOSPITAL CARE,OUTCOMES,MENTAL & BEHAVIOURAL DISORDERS,ETHNIC GROUPS,ETHNICITY,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SERVICE PROVISION,PUBLIC HEALTH,RACE EQUALITY,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,HEALTHCARE & HEALTH SERVICES,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,2008-SEPTEMBER,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,RACE,CULTURAL IDENTITY]]>
document.body:
(92 page document - pdf 1291 kb)

This is an action plan for achieving equality and tackling discrimination in mental health services in England for all people of black and minority ethnic (BME) status, including those of Irish or Mediterranean origin and east European migrants.

Three key elements of service reform are:

  • more appropriate and responsive services - tailoring services more effectively for the needs of specific groups, such as older people, asylum seekers, and children
  • engaging communities in planning services, supported by 500 new community development workers
  • better information , through improved monitoring of ethnicity, including a new regular census of mental health patients.

The aims of the plan include: improving accessibility to services; improving patient satisfaction; reducing the rate of admission of people from BME communities to psychiatric inpatient units; and, reducing the disproportionate rates of compulsory detention of BME service users in inpatient units.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Delivering race equality in mental health care: report on the findings and outcomes of the community engagement programme 2005-2008
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
The National Institute for Mental Health England (NIMHE) community engagement project allowed 547 community researchers, 75 community organisations, 935 Black and minority ethnic current or ex-mental service users, 344 carers and 4,472 other community members to contribute to the development of mental health policy and to the planning and provision of services.

This report presents an analysis of the quantitative and qualitative data from 79 studies conducted by the community organisations participating in the project.  It provides a comprehensive overview of the issues that were explored by the studies in relation to Black and minority ethnic populations and mental wellbeing, mental health problems, mental health services and the vision of service characteristics for 2010 set out in Delivering race equality in mental health care (DRE).  The report also documents some of the project's outcomes for individuals, communities and mental health service development.

In order that the findings could be located in the context of current mental health policy, practice and service provision, commentaries were also elicited from mental health experts.

The report includes:

  • Foreword and introduction
  • Executive summary
  • Background, method and sample
  • Key themes and findings
  • Project outcomes
  • Recommendations from community organisations
  • References
  • Appendices
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Demographic data in asthma clinical trials: a systematic review with implications for generalizing trial findings and tackling health disparities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING]]>
document.body:
Factors related to asthma including morbidity, prevalence, adverse events, mortality and healthcare utilization vary widely among ethnic and other socio-demographic groups, recommendations have been made to report and analyse ethnic and demographic information in clinical trials as a means of tackling this variation.  This systematic review aims to determine the extent to which ethnic and other socio-demographic information is reported in publications from randomised controlled trials of asthma interventions.

Using 12 electronic bibliographic databases 87 relevant trials were identified, these were published between 1985 and 2006.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Department of Health race equality scheme 2005-2008
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,HUMAN RESOURCES,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
All public authorities are required to publish a Race Equality Scheme setting out their arrangements for meeting the duties placed upon them by the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000.

This document replaces the Department’s 2002-2005 scheme.

Key points include:

  • The need to emphasise race equality in designing and delivering NHS reforms and changing the focus to patient -centred services.
  • People from black and minority ethnic (BME) communities are among the most disadvantaged groups and among those least satisfied with the services they receive.
  • More appropriate services need to be developed for patients from BME groups, for example tailored screening and organ donation services.
  • Staff policies should promote diversity and race equality, for example, targeting recruitment and development opportunities at people from different ethnic groups. Recruitment and promotion processes should not inadvertently disadvantage people from BME communities.
  • The quality of information available on health and ethnicity need to be improved by developing and promoting improved ethnicity data collection and analysis.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Derivation, validation, and evaluation of a new QRISK model to estimate lifetime risk of cardiovascular disease: cohort study using QResearch database
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
This article describes the development, validation and evaluation of a new QRISK model to estimate the lifetime risk of developing cardiovascular risk (CD).

563 general practices in England and Wales contributed to the QResearch database between 1st January 1994 and 30th April 2010.  Patients free of CD aged between 30 and 84 years were included in the study, with 2 million 345, 759 being included in the derivation dataset and 1 million 267, 159 being included in the validation dataset.

Ethnic minorities were one of the groups to be identified as having high lifetime risk of developing CD.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Diabetes and Ethnicity
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIABETES,TYPE 1,TYPE 2,LIVING WITH DIABETES,PEOPLE FROM ETHNIC MINORITIES,RELIGION / SPECIAL OCCASIONS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,PEOPLE FROM ETHNIC MINORITIES]]>
document.description: SLEH National Knowledge Week commentary contributed by Professor Sudhesh Kumar drawing attention to the world-wide epidemic of diabetes and its consequences for populations of migrant origin.
document.body:
111-1Diabetes and Ethnicity

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2007

Professor Sudhesh Kumar
Professor of Medicine and
Associate Dean (External Affairs)
Medical School,
University of Warwick
 

 (Return to Knowledge Week index page) 

The world is in the grip of a Diabetes epidemic which may be more important in its implications for health care than many infectious diseases. The United Nations has declared November 14th to be ‘World Diabetes Day’ (Resolution 61/225 Dec 2006), which will be marked around the world by the lighting of key public buildings in blue.  It is estimated that between 250 and 300,000,000 people have the disease worldwide, and it has been observed that the disease is particularly rampant in the countries of South Asia, and among populations of migrants and those of migrant origin. 

Currently the International Diabetes Federation is warning that this may lead to a world-wide decrease in life-expectancy, especially among populations moving to richer countries. Surinamese people in the Netherlands show rates eight times that of autochthonous Dutch, and south Asians in Norway present at a rate nine times that of Norwegians.  Outcomes may be even more adverse:  Dutch Surinamese people have rates of end-stage renal failure 40 times that of the native population.  In Britain too, South Asian and Caribbean-descended populations are at much higher risk, present later, have worse disease control, and are at risk of more adverse outcomes.

Consistently, research and policy development call for better surveillance, earlier detection, improved education (for both communities and professions) and tailored prevention programmes including language-competent resources adapted for specific cultural groups, and the mobilisation of networks of community-based support. However both practitioners and policy makers complain that there is a lack of high quality evidence and community based workers including primary health care practitioners find it difficult to access quality-assured translated resources.

The NHS SLEH has brought together a selection of useful electronic resources to address these needs and is actively searching out new research and good quality information materials in minority languages or using innovative approaches to support patient self-efficacy. Research shows (see reference 1 below) how these can improve outcomes, and there is also guidance available on tricky issues such as the management of the disease during the holy month of fasting observed by many Muslims (Ramadan): (reference 2). As the national charity Diabetes UK (3) increases its outreach programmes to raise awareness of risk factors, advice and resources are also available for diabetes professionals to manage local events (4).

Over the coming year, we expect that these will be added to every month, and that new research will assist the management and prevention of diabetes among Black and Minority Ethnic groups across England – and that the SLEH will locate resources and research relevant to the growing number of new migrants and ethnic groups. We also hope that users will provide feedback on these and recommend new or well-evaluated resources of their own to share. 

References and Resources

  1. Effect of culturally appropriate health education on glycaemic control and knowledge of diabetes in British Pakistani women with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

  2. The effects of diet, sulfonylurea, and Repaglinide therapy on clinical and metabolic parameters in type 2 diabetic patients during Ramadan.

  3. Website: Diabetes UK

  4. Downloads to support diabetes awarness events can be found on the Diabetes UK website:  Diabetes Awareness Toolkit 

  5. See also the new booklet produced by the Department of Health with Islamic experts: "Ramadan Health Guide:  a guide to healthy fasting" - access through the SLEH site.

  6. The following link to a page in the Specialist Library for Ethnic Health provides an up-to-date list of resources relating to ethnicity and diabetes:  View Resources  

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET]]>
document.body:
Poor diet is often cited as a major contributing factor to high cardiovascular mortality in Eastern Europe, this study describes methods of dietary assessment and presents preliminary findings on food and nutrition intakes in large general population samples in Russia, Poland and the Czech Republic. 

Random samples of men and women aged 45-69 years took place in Novosbirsk (Russia), Krakow (Poland) and six Czech urban cities between 2002 and 2005.  A food frequency questionnaire was used to assess diet, complete dietary information was available for 26,870 persons.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: Dietary habits are subject to change over time.

]]>

30 migrants from Pakistan (women), 30 British-born Pakistani women and 25 British-born women of European origin were included in the study.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Differences in drug response between ethnic groups: the need for pharmaco-vigilance
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY]]>
document.body:
111-1Differences in drug response between ethnic groups: the need for pharmaco-vigilance

Written for the 'ethnicity and health' Annual Evidence Update 2009

 

 

Professor Larry Goodyer

 Tom Burnham

 BPharm, MPharm, PHD
Head of School of Pharmacy
De Montfort University

Pharm-line Database Manager
Pharmacy Department
Guy’s Hospital

Return to index page


It has long been acknowledged that differences in drug response exist between ethnic groups [refs 1-7]. This is known to be related to the way the drug is handled in the body (pharmacokinetics) and/or its physiological effects, for example through differences in receptor sensitivity. The result can be significant variations between such groups in the incidence of adverse effects or failure of therapy.

Currently, there is a lack of evidence-based NHS guidelines in this important area of clinical practice. A literature search conducted for the Ethnicity and Health Collection by London & South East Medicines Information based at Guy’s Hospital has identified relevant investigations or case reports for some 155 different drugs or classes of drug; highlighted as of immediate interest are immunosuppressants [ref 8], antipsychotics [refs 9, 10], and some cardiovascular medicines [refs 11-16].

Worryingly, relatively few of these differences are presently reflected in product licences or officially sanctioned product information. In 2007, only 16 drug labels in the UK commented on the response to drugs in Asians [ref 17]. Examples where risks were reported include:

  • Carbamazepine, where a safety review identified an increased risk for Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) in Chinese and some other Asian individuals who carry the HLA-B*1502 allele [ref 18],
     
  • Rosuvastatin, where a lower starting dose is specified in patients of Asian origin [ref 19].

For Black patients, although the US Food and Drug Administration has licensed a fixed-dose combination of isosorbide dinitrate and hydralazine (BiDil) for use in patients with heart failure, this lead has not been followed in the UK. Medication risks associated with this and other differences in drug response between ethnic groups still need to be addressed by the NHS.

It has also been pointed out, that broad ethnic groups – for example "Asian" – vary in definition and that their subgroups may differ greatly from each other in response to a particular drug [ref 17].  There is therefore a need for debate over whether reporting drug response in broad ethnic groups is necessarily helpful as a basis for clinical decisions.  It has been argued, for example [refs 6, 20], that the use of an ethnically-related model to calculate drug dosage will lead to some reduction in variability of response, but less than that which would be achieved by a truly individualised calculation based on a knowledge of the genetic factors for a particular patient that would influence drug response.

 

Challenges

 

Ethnic variations are undoubtedly related to genetic polymorphism and as the area of pharmacogenetics develops the genetic markers of those mechanisms responsible for the metabolism and mechanism of drug action will certainly become better understood [refs 21-23].  This will enable practitioners to predict from the genetic profile of any individual their response to a medication and individualise therapy accordingly. However this goal is likely to be some years away from being widely available as a practical tool in clinical practice.

In the interim, we consider that there is an urgent need for increased awareness among clinicians, patients and commissioners of the potential risks associated with differences in drug response between ethnic groups. Existing evidence should also be brought together systematically in reviews which assess the strength and quality of published research. The pharmaceutical industry and prescribing clinicians should also be encouraged to consider pharmaco-vigilance in communities of diversity. 

 

 

References

  1. A review and assessment of potential sources of ethnic differences in drug responsiveness
    T.D. Bjornsson et al., Journal of Clinical Pharmacology Sep 2003;43(9):943-967
    [view details]

     
  2. Racial and ethnic differences in response to medicines: towards individualized pharmaceutical treatment
    V.J. Burroughs et al.,  Journal of the National Medical Association Oct 2002;94(10-Suppl):1-26
    [view details]

  3. Ethnic or racial differences revisited: impact of dosage regimen and dosage form on pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics
    M.-L. Chen, Clinical Pharmacokinetics 2006;45(10):957-964
    [view details]

     
  4. The role of ethnicity in variability in response to drugs: focus on clinical pharmacology studies
    S.U. Yasuda et al., Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics Sep 2008;84(3):417–423
    [view details]

  5. Interethnic variability in human drug responses
    D.A. Evans et al., Drug Metabolism and Disposition Apr 2001; 29(4 Pt 2):606-610
    [view details]

  6. Is this the drug or dose for you?  Impact and consideration of ethnic factors in global drug development, regulatory review, and clinical practice
    S.-M. Huang and R. Temple, Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics Sep 2008;84(3):287-294
    [view details]

  7. Predictability of the effects of race or ethnicity on pharmacokinetics of drugs
    J.A. Johnson, International Journal of Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics Feb 2000;38(2):53-60
    [view details]

  8. Pharmacokinetics of immunosuppressants: a perspective on ethnic differences
    N.L. Dirks et al., International Journal of Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics Dec 2004;42(12):701-718
    [view details]

  9. Ethnicity and treatment response in schizophrenia: a comparison of 3 ethnic groups
    R.A. Emsley et al., Journal of Clinical Psychiatry Jan 2002;63(1):9-14
    [view details]

  10. Ethnicity and antipsychotic response
    E.J. Frackiewicz et al., Annals of Pharmacotherapy Nov 1997;31(11):1360-1369
    [view details]

  11. Ethnic differences in cardiovascular drug response: potential contribution of pharmacogenetics
    J.A. Johnson, Circulation 23 Sep 2008;118(13):1383-1393
    [view details]

  12. Overlap between whites and blacks in response to antihypertensive drugs
    A.R. Sehgal, Hypertension Mar 2004;43(3):566-572
    [view details]

  13. The influence of ethnicity on warfarin dosage requirement
    M-T.N. Dang et al., Annals of Pharmacotherapy Jun 2005;39(6):1008-1012
    [view details]

  14. Ethnic differences in the pharmacokinetics of oral nifedipine
    C.H. Ahsan et al., British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology Apr 1991;31(4):399-403
    [view details]

  15. The influence of dose and ethnic origins on the pharmacokinetics of nifedipine
    C.H. Ahsan et al., Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics Sep 1993;54(3):329-338
    [view details]

  16. Racial and ethnic differences in warfarin response
    S. El Rouby et al., Journal of Heart Valve Diseases Jan 2004;13(1):15-21
    [view details]

  17. Personalised medicine: who is an Asian?
    A. Li Wan Po, Lancet 2007; 369:1770-1771
    [view details]

  18. MHRA, 2008: Carbamazepine: genetic testing recommended in some Asian populations.  Drug Safety Update 1(9):5
    [view details]

  19. MHRA, 2006: Rosuvastatin (Crestor): introduction of 5mg starting dose.  Current Problems in Pharmacovigilance 31:4
    [view details]

  20. Individual genomes instead of race for personalized medicine
    P.C. Ng et al., Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics Sep 2008;84(3):306-309
    [view details]

  21. Differences in drug pharmacokinetics between East Asians and Caucasians and the role of genetic polymorphisms
    K. Kim et al., Journal of Clinical Pharmacology Oct 2004;44(10):1083-1105
    [view details]

  22. Interethnic differences in drug response: the contribution of genetic variability in beta adrenergic receptor and cytochrome P4502C9
    M. Muszkat, Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics Aug 2007;82(2):215-218
    [view details]

  23. Enhancing race-based prescribing precision with pharmacogenomics
    A.Nguyen et al., Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics Mar 2007;81(3):323-325
    [view details] 
]]>

document.body:
Some evidence exists to suggest that there are differences in access to healthcare in the UK for different ethnic groups; this study looks at differences in the process of diabetic care provided to white and south Asian patients.

A retrospective multi-practice audit was conducted, 839 diabetic patients were included in the audit with 671 recieving a formal annual diabetic review. 105 patients were classified as south Asian.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Different sex ratios of children born to Indian and Pakistani immigrants in Norway
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,BIRTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
In some Asian countries a low female to male ratio has been observed but the phenomenon has not received much attention regarding immigrants living in western societies.  This study investigates whether a low female to male ratio exists among Indian and Pakistani immigrants living in Norway.  Particular emphasis is placed on whether the determination of sex via ultrasound has affected this ratio.

A retrospective cohort study of live births was conducted with 1,597 mothers of Indian and 5,617 mothers of Pakistani origin.  Data was obtained from 'Statistics Norway' with sex ratio being determined from 21,325 children born during three time periods (1969-1986, 1987-1996 and 1997-2005).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Dimensions of diversity: population differences and health improvement opportunities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,RELIGION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
This report gives a concise overview of basic information about a range of population groups in Scotland.  For each group the report aims to describe basic demographic information, identify key health issues, suggest possible opportunities for health improvement and provide references for further information.

Overviews of population groups and aspects of these groups in the report include:

  • Asylum seekers and refugees
  • Ethnicity
  • Language
  • Migrants
  • Religion and belief
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Discovering the research priorities of people with diabetes in a multicultural community: a focus group study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
It is government policy to involve service users in research, however there is a lack of published research about involving patients from minority ethnic groups and people from deprived areas.  This study aims to discover the  research priorities of people with diabetes from a multicultural inner city community and compare these with expert-led research priorities.

A qualitative study was conducted in three inner city primary care practices in Nottingham, UK. 39 patients of varying ethnic background were included in focus groups, these were conducted in participants' preferred language and then analysed using the constant comparative method.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Discrimination and health in an English study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
This study examines the relationship between education, racial discrimination and health amongst different ethnic groups in England.

A stratified population survey was conducted with 673 participants aged 18-59 years living in Leeds, England. The ethnic groups involved in the study were: white (n=227), African-Caribbean (n=213) and Indian and Pakistani (n=233).  

]]>

document.title: Discussion of posthumous organ donation in Chinese families

document.body: <![CDATA[ This paper showed that campaigns for lessening death anxiety and promoting the social norm of organ donation must be conducted in Chinese societies, in order to encourage family discussion and improve the donation rate.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Diversity appraisal resource guide
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES]]>
document.body:
This resource guide has been designed to support RCN officers and representatives when they assess the progress that health care employers have made in promoting diversity and equality for nurses in the workplace. 

Some of the guidance covers nursing students on clinical placement, but most elements relate only to nurses and other health care staff with employment contracts. The focus of the guide is on how organisations promote equality and diversity in nurses’ employment, and how they put policies into practice.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Diversity matters - Disabled children & their families from BME
document.publisher: National Children's Bureau & Council for Disabled Children
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES]]>
document.description: Good practice Guideline
document.body:
The guide draws on practice, research and publications that address the  needs of minority ethnic disabled children and their families. It identifies lessons that can be learned from working with children, with disabled  children, with children from black and other minority ethnic communities, and with disabled adults.

The aims of this guide are to:

  • help to improve access to social care services for black and other minority ethnic disabled children

  • identify how services have successfully targeted black and other minority ethnic disabled children, young people and their families

  • provide tips and recommendations for service providers to help them ensure their services are accessible and relevant to all.

This guide includes:

  • examples of successful projects

  • tips on what to look for when setting up and delivering a service

  • possible challenges

  • common experiences that have led to success

  • practical suggestions

  • summaries of key legislation and policy with implications for practice 

  • a list of useful resources and references

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Do 'alternative' help-seeking strategies affect primary care service use? a survey of help-seeking for mental distress
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
There are currently few research studies that examine how people with a common mental disorder manage their mental distress, this study explores alternative help seeking strategies in a multi-ethnic community and also examines that relationship with primary care use.

268 participants were recruited from four GP practices and 14 community groups in East London. 117 of the participants had a common mental disorder according to a valid and structured interview schedule (CIS-R). The ethnic backgrounds of the participants included in the study were: Bangladeshi, black Caribbean and white British.

]]>

A systematic literature search limited to the English language was conducted for publications between 1996 and September 2005 using Pubmed and PsycINFO as well as a search of the Cochrane library.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Does the pulse pressure in people of European, African and South Asian descent differ?: a systematic review and meta-analysis of UK data
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.description: A systematic review and meta-analysis of UK data.
document.body:
A systematic review using Medline and Embase was carried out to investigate whether pulse pressures (PPs) in people of African and South Asian descent differ from those of White-European descent in the UK.

A meta-analysis was performed using Cochrane review manager software.

The review includes African, Bangladeshi, Indian, Pakistani, South Asian, and White men and women.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Does the white-coat effect in people of African and South Asian descent differ from that in White people of European origin? A systematic review and meta-analysis.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
This systematic review assesses whether the white-coat effect differs for people of African and south Asian descent when compared with people of European origin and whether this can explain demonstrated ethnic variations in blood pressure.

A systematic literature review was conducted using Medline (1966-2003), Embase (1980-2003) and citations from references.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Doxazosin versus bendrofluazide: a comparison of the metabolic effects in British South Asians with hypertension
document.publisher: The British journal of general practice : the journal of the Royal College of General Practitioners
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
People from British South Asian communities have an increased risk of mortality from coronary heart disease (CHD). Doxazosin, a selective alpha(1)-adrenergic blocker, in addition to lowering blood pressure, has been shown to have positive effects on glucose metabolism and lipid profiles in patients with hypertension.

Aim was to study doxazosin (1-8 mg) and bendrofluazide (2.5 mg) in patients of British South Asian origin with existing mild to moderate hypertension (doxazosin n = 78; bendrofluazide n = 82), to compare their effects on glucose and lipid metabolism in this group.

CONCLUSION: Doxazosin exhibits beneficial effects on glucose concentrations and lipid profile, in particular in lowering triglyceride concentrations in British South Asians. Whether these desirable characteristics translate to improved overall cardiovascular risk requires formal evaluation.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Drug intake during Ramadan
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES]]>
document.body:
Ramadan, a month of fasting, is a daily abstinence from any food, beverage, or oral drug from dawn to sunset Patients with chronic diseases often insist on fasting even though they are permitted not to by Islamic rules Patients with acute diseases would similarly be allowed to stop fasting and make up for it after Ramadan.

Several studies have shown that patients arbitrarily change the intake time and dosing of drugs without taking medical advice This behaviour could alter the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of drugs, especially those with a narrow therapeutic index, and consequently their efficacy and tolerance.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Drugs of porcine origin & clinical alternatives
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS]]>
document.body:
This care guidance is for use by clinicians when prescribing drugs and discussing treatment options with patients who have religious or cultural restrictions for porcine derived products within their diet.

The guidance includes:

  • Foreword: patient choice in medicine taking
  • The religious and cultural aspects of porcine derived products
  • Drug development and the move from animal source to synthetic agents
  • Reference list of drugs of porcine origin and their alternatives
  • Involving patients in decisions about porcine-derived medication
  • Signpost to patient choice information
  • Appendix one
  • References
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Dying to be home?: preferred location of death of first-generation black Caribbean and native-born white patients in the United Kingdom
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Although preference for location of death has been studied in the general population little is known about the black Caribbean population living in the United Kingdom. The findings of this study suggest that there is a need to improve training in discussing care and treatment choices, including location of death, and a deeper qualitative understanding of the cultural and other factors that may facilitate or prevent home deaths.]]>

document.body:

A cross-sectional survey of 4,796 children aged 9-10 years was conducted in three UK cities.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Early onset of breast cancer in a group of British Black women
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,CLINICAL GENETICS,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,SECONDARY / HOSPITAL CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.description: Black British Women get Breast cancer younger and may have worse outcomes
document.body:
A report based on retrospective review suggests that UK Black women are likely to present with cancers on average 21 years younger than White women – and suggests that there may be genetic or biological differences at work.  There is clearly a need for more research and urgent proactive case finding to combat these risks – even though no disparities in treatment were found, and socio-economic differences did not explain the inequality. 

 

Full reference: Bowen RL, Duffy SW, Ryan DA, Hart IR, Jones JL.  Early onset of breast cancer in a group of British black women.1: Br J Cancer. 2008 Jan 8 [Epub ahead of print]  doi:10.1038/sj.bjc.6604174 

 

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,VOLUNTARY AND COMMUNITY SECTOR,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
The key messages from this Better Health Briefing (Number 2) are:

 

  • Information about services should be available in a range of languages and formats

  • Employing staff from minority ethnic groups at all levels of an organisation will increase cultural competence within it

  • Families need to be involved in the communication process

  • Effective communication requires action at the institutional level as well as the individual level

document.title: Effective heart disease prevention: lessons from a qualitative study of user perspectives in Bangladeshi, Indian and Pakistani communities.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
There is a high mortality, incidence and prevalence of coronary heart disease (CHD) among Indian, Pakistani and Bangladeshi communities in the UK. This study considers how culturally focused CHD prevention interventions can be developed using service user perspectives.

A qualitative research study was carried out using focus group discussions, six were conducted at the beginning of the study and six were conducted towards the end.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Effective methods of engaging black and minority ethnic communities within health care settings
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Key messages from this better health briefing (number 18) include:

  • Unequal access and care in health settings is the result of poor engagement with black and minority ethnic (BME) communities
  • Language, communication and culture are some of the barriers to effective engagement with BME communities
  • Methods exist that can be utilised to enhance engagement with BME communities
  • When using engagement methods with BME communities practical considerations need to be addressed
  • London, Leeds and Bradford are providing examples of good practice
]]>

document.title: Emergence of ethnic differences in blood pressure in adolescence: the determinants of adolescent social well-being and health study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
Blood pressure is known to track from late childhood to adulthood and this may give some indication to the cause of ethnic differences in cardiovascular disease (CVD).  This study explores ethnic differences in changes to blood pressure between early and late adolescence in the UK.

White British (n=692), black Caribbean (n=670), black African (n=772), Indian (n=384), and Pakistani and Bangladeshi (n=402) schoolchildren aged 11-13 and 14-16 years in London, UK were tested for longitudinal measures of blood pressure, height, weight, leg length, smoking and socioeconomic circumstances.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: An earlier study with infants aged two years and under investigating the link between inflammatory markers and ethnic differences in CVD is available here.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: End of Life Care
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS]]>
document.description: Dr Margaret Goodman explores issues of palliative care and ethnicity, drawing on her experience researching for the Marie Curie charity.
document.body:
111-1End of Life Care

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2007

Margaret Goodman RN PhD

Senior Lecturer and Research Facilitator
University Hospitals Coventry & Warwickshire NHS Trust

It seems reasonable to expect that all patients with a life-threatening illness should have the opportunity to benefit from palliative care. In practice, however, whether access is actually achieved appears to be something of a lottery and this is even more apparent for patients from black and minority ethnic (BME) groups. This is despite evidence to suggest that BME patients use primary care services at a similar or higher level than white British counterparts even after adjustment for crude measures of need (references 1 and 2 below).

The reasons for disparity in use of palliative care services are not clear. However, the following have all been given as reasons for inequity of access: a lack of standardized referral and access criteria (reference 3); perceptions that palliative care services are primarily for patients with cancer (which may disadvantage BME groups because of their lower risk of cancer death and higher risk of dying from heart disease and strokes); a reluctance to refer or be referred for palliative care because of misunderstanding of what benefits palliative care offers; and a lack of awareness by healthcare professionals about the responses of BME groups to the concept of palliative care and a life-threatening illness diagnosis.

A systematic review of the issues around access to palliative care services, Ahmed et al (4)highlighted the paucity of research around these issues and suggested that the poor utilization of palliative care services by BME groups was primarily the result of problems with the timeliness of referrals (possibly linked with a perception by palliative care professionals about the giving of a ‘no-recovery’ diagnosis) and a lack of awareness of the availability and potential benefits of palliative care by BME communities. More recently, Koffman et al (5), from a limited survey, have suggested that disparities of knowledge of palliative care services arise from social and material deprivation rather than ethnicity, and that overall, lack of palliative care service awareness is associated with BME and deprived communities. Furthermore, healthcare professionals seem to have retained a perception that BME groups have supportive care systems, and this may lead them to delay referral to palliative care services and/or only offer access to home care services (6 and 7).

The baseline review being undertaken by all Primary Care Trusts in England, as part of the End of Life strategy, should provide a comprehensive picture of palliative care services and enable identification of whether there are actually services available for BME communities.  It will not, however, address all the issues associated with lack of awareness of the benefits of palliative care, under-provision for non-cancer patients and inconsistencies in the criteria used to determine who actually gains access to palliative care services. What is apparent is the limited evidence available to explain why BME groups underutilize palliative care services and even less research looking at strategies that can be used to change the situation.

References and Resources

  1. Linked to PubMed:
    Goddard M, Smith P, (2001) Equity of access to health care services: theory and evidence from the UK. Social Science Medicine 53; 1149-62

  2. Link to PubMed:
    Haynes R, (1991) Inequalities in health and health service use: evidence from the General Household Survey. Social Science Medicine 33; 361-8

  3. Not yet available.  See the British Library Thesis Service
    Goodman ML, (2007) Are the criteria governing access to palliative care services ethically acceptable? PhD Thesis, Keele University

  4. Access through Sage Journals online: 
    Ahmed N, Bestall JC, Ahmedzai SH, Payne SA, Clark D & Noble B, (2004) Systematic review of the problems and issues of accessing specialist palliative care by patients, carers and health and social care professionals. Palliative Medicine 18; 525-42

  5. Access through Sage Journals Online:
    Koffman J, Burke G, Dias A, Raval B, Byrne J, Gonzales J & Daniels C (2007) Demographic factors and awareness of palliative care and related services.  Palliative Medicine 21, 145-53

  6. Access through Sage Journals online:
    Fountain A, (1999) Ethnic minorities and palliative care in Derby. Palliative Medicine 13; 161-2

  7. See abstract at Sage Journals Online:
    Karim K, Bailey M, Tunna K, (2000) Nonwhite ethnicity and the provision of specialist palliative care services: factors affecting doctor’s referral patterns. Palliative Medicine 14; 471-78

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: End of Life Care 2010: an update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body:
111-1End of Life Care 2010: an updateWritten for the 'ethnicity and health' Annual Evidence Update 2010 

Margaret Goodman RN PhD

Senior Lecturer and Research Facilitator
University Hospitals Coventry & Warwickshire NHS Trust


End of Life Care 2010:
an update

(Return to Index Page)


It is disappointing to be unable to identify any significant changes in the evidence available to explain why black and minority ethnic (BME) groups under-utilize palliative care services, or any quality research suggesting interventions that can be used to alter the situation, in the three years since the SLEH 2007 National Knowledge Week and the Briefing produced by the Race Equality Foundation [ref 1].  It was noted then that “Evidence from small-scale and qualitative research suggests that there is a lack of understanding amongst palliative care providers of the specific and varying needs of minority ethnic service users.  Wider evidence suggests that specific resources and opportunities need to be established to enable the full participation of minority ethnic patients and carers in user involvement initiatives”.  At that time, although there have been a number of small-scale, project-funded initiatives to improve practice, regrettably few of these seem to have endured and none have been published in peer-reviewed papers.

The original UK National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence guidance [ref 2] worked on the premise that if needs are properly assessed (irrespective of an individual’s age, gender or ethnicity), then care appropriate to the cultural needs of the individual is likely to be provided.  This guidance recommended that healthcare and social care practitioners receive ‘cultural awareness’ training.  Previously, the House of Commons Health Committee on palliative care [ref 3] had similarly highlighted the need to ensure that all services are culturally sensitive and that training in cultural awareness should be an integral dimension for both generalist and specialist palliative care staff.  It must, nevertheless, be recognised that there remains a difference between knowledge and awareness of differing cultural needs and actual day-to-day practice.

However, it is encouraging to note that there is some evidence that more attention is now being given to the need to consider the palliative care different requirements of BME groups.  The launch of the Dying Matters Coalition and website in 2009 [ref 4] is one example.  The Coalition supports individuals in helping to identify what their specific needs are, including cultural aspects, to those who are in a caring role.  The aim is to promote talking about dying amongst patients, their caregivers and professionals involved with them.  Similarly, the Liverpool care pathway (LCP) [ref 5] highlights the need to ensure effective communication with the patient and caregivers and that any religious and spiritual needs are taken into account and accommodated during the final dying phase.  Although neither the LCP nor Dying Matters refer directly to the cultural needs of BME groups, presumably because of lack of an evidence base, in practice these needs are now highlighted in training and care delivery.  Similarly, the launch of guidance by the General Medical Council on the care of the dying [ref 6] emphasises the need for practitioners dealing with end-of-life questions to take account of equality and diversity duties:

Some groups of patients can experience inequalities in getting access to healthcare services and in the standard of care provided.  It is known that some older people, people with disabilities and people from ethnic minorities have received poor standards of care towards the end of life.  This can be because of physical, communication and other barriers, and mistaken beliefs or lack of knowledge among those providing services, about the patient's needs and interests.  Equalities, capacity and human rights laws reinforce your ethical duty to treat patients fairly (GMC 2010, para 8).

While this guidance is the product of extensive consultation and expert advice, it appears to contain very little in relation to new evidence about best practice.  In general, it is apparent that evidence on the actual needs of BME groups in the context of palliative care and insight into the factors governing poor uptake of services remains very limited.

 

References 

  1. Gunaratnam, Y. (2007).  Improving the quality of palliative care. Better Health Briefing 1. London: Race Equality Foundation.
    [view details]

  2. National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE). (2004). Guidance on cancer services: improving supportive and palliative care for adults with cancer. London: National Institute for Clinical Excellence.
    [download pdf]

  3. House of Commons Health Committee. (2004). Palliative care: fourth report of session 2003-2004. London: The Stationary Office.
    [download pdf]

  4. Dying Matters. (2009). [website] Available at: www.dyingmatters.org [Accessed October 2010]

  5. Marie Curie Palliative Care Institute Liverpool. (2010). Liverpool care pathway for the dying patient (LCP). Liverpool: Marie Curie Palliative Care Institute Liverpool.
    [view details]

  6. General Medical Council (GMC). (2010). Treatment and care towards the end of life: good practice in decision making. London: General Medical Council.
    [view details]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Endometriosis and cultural diversity: improving services for minority ethnic women
document.topics: <![CDATA[ WOMEN'S HEALTH,MENSTRUAL CYCLE DISORDERS,PAIN DISORDERS,PELVIC PAIN,ENDOMETRIOSIS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,ENDOMETRIOSIS,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,OTHER,INTERNATIONAL PERSPECTIVE]]>
document.body:
Endometriosis is a disabling chronic condition that is estimated to affect between 5 to 15% of women in the UK that has no definitive cure.  Previous research has focused on women from majority populations this study explores the ways in which ethnic minority women experience endometriosis and its treatment.

Women from African-Caribbean, Chinese, Greek/Greek Cypriot, Indian and Pakistani ethnic groups were included in the study.  Focus groups (n=42) and semi-structured interviews (n=29) were conducted with women aged 18-50 years.  Semi-structured interviews (n=8) were also conducted with health professionals who provide care for women with endometriosis.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: This study has been conducted as part of the ENDOCUL project a collaboration between Birmingham City University, De Montfort University and Middlesex University with funding from the NHS, with Birmingham Women's Hospital being the lead site.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Epidemiology of critically ill children in England and Wales: incidence, mortality, deprivation and ethnicity
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,SECONDARY / HOSPITAL CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
The admission rate and mortality of children receiving paediatric intensive care was investigated in relation to ethnicity and socioeconomic status in England and Wales.

All patients aged 16 years and under at 29 paediatric intensive care units between 2004 and 2007 in England and Wales were included in a national cohort of sequential hospital admissions.

The investigation found that admission rates were higher for south Asian children than for non-south Asian children; and concludes that, "risk adjusted mortality increases in south Asian children as deprivation decreases".

]]>

document.title: Epidemiology of esophageal cancer: orient to occident. Effects of chronology, geography and ethnicity.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) has been rapidly increasing in western countries over the past 50 years, this mini-review argues that ethnic groups from the eastern and southern areas of Eurasia such as Chinese, Koreans, Japanese and African might be more prone to developing esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC).]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Equal access, equal care?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.description: Can London Deliver the Race Equality Action Plan for Mental Health?
document.body: This is a London-specific analysis of data from the 2005 national 'Count Me In' mental health census.  Members of Black ethnic groups were twice as likely as white British to be in 'secure units' and more likely to be admitted via police or compulsory sections. South Asian and Chinese groups were under-represented in mental health care services.  Fewer referrals in London were made by primary care than nationally. Specific implications for London's Race Equality plans are discussed, and recommendations for improving future data collection made.]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
There is yet to be an accurate assessment of ethnic differences in physical activity in children in the UK. This study makes objective measurements of physical activity in 9-10 year old British children of south Asian, black African - Caribbean and white European origin.

A cross-sectional study involving 2071 urban primary school children was conducted.

]]>
