document.title: Ethnic and sex differences in circulating endotoxin levels: a novel marker of atherosclerotic and cardiovascular risk in a British multi-ethnic population
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
Ethnic differences in pro-inflammatory markers maybe related to ethnic differences in atherosclerotic and cardiovascular (CVD) and coronary (CHD) heart disease; this study investigates ethnic differences in circulating plasma endotoxin levels.

192 participants aged 40-59 years of age with no history of CHD, CVD, diabetes or stroke were randomly selected from the UK Wandsworth heart and stroke study. The study included the following ethnic groups: African (68), south Asian (63) and white (61).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic and socio-economic inequalities in coronary heart disease, diabetes and risk factors in Europeans and south Asians.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DIABETES]]>
document.body:
This study tested the hypothesis that worse socio-economic status is associated with a higher prevalence of CHD, glucose intolerance and related risk factors for south Asians and Europeans alike.

The study population consisted of 684 south Asians and 825 Europeans aged 25-74 in Newcastle UK. The south Asian study population was comprised of Indians (259), Pakistanis (305) and Bangladeshis (120).   

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic cancer data for improved commissioning of health services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,COMMISSIONING,DATASETS,DISEASE/CONDITION GROUPS,CANCERS AND TUMOURS,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,MANAGE KNOWLEDGE]]>
document.body:
111-1Ethnic cancer data for improved commissioning of health services

Written for the 'ethnicity and health' Annual Evidence Update 2009

 

 

Paula Lloyd

Associate Director

National Cancer Action Team

Return to index page

 

  

Introduction


The 2007 Cancer Reform Strategy [ref 1] launched the National Cancer Equality Initiative (NCEI) in the UK, supported by the National Cancer Action Team (NCAT).  One of the aims of the Initiative is to improve data collection, analysis and the use of resulting information.  To this end the NCEI and NCAT have been working with the National Cancer Intelligence Network (NCIN) to produce the first national in-depth analysis of cancer by ethnicity.  NHS Hospital Episode Statistics and national cancer register data have been combined in order to create a National Cancer Data Repository.

 

The first NCIN report based on this repository was published in June 2009 [ref 2], and presents a national ethnicity-based analysis of cancer related data for England.

 

Prior to the publication of the NCIN report, UK researchers had attempted to look at the incidence of cancer in South Asian people using various name based algorithms [refs 3, 4, 5].  There had also been attempts to look at specific tumours, such as prostate cancer, in men of African Caribbean descent [ref 6]; oral cancer in South Asians [ref 7] ; and more recently international variations for South Asians [ref 8].  However, a comprehensive national overview has not been attempted.

  

What do we know now?


The NCIN report provides incidence data for 18 specific sites of cancer, and analyses for white, South Asian and Black ethnic groups of cases diagnosed from 2002-2006 in England, although 25% of cases could not be assigned.  Overall cancer incidence was found to be lower in South Asian, Chinese and mixed race groups than whites.  However, some important specific differences were also identified:

  • Black males of all ages were more likely to have a diagnosis of prostate cancer than white males. (Age standardised Relative Risk (RR) between 1.26 and 2.48, based on different assumptions regarding patients with unknown ethnicity)  

     

  • Black males and black females had higher rates of cancers o f the stomach. (RR 1.14 – 1.74)
     

  • Black males and black females had a higher rate of liver cancer than white males and females. (RR 1.47 – 2.67)
     

  • Black males and black females had a higher rate of myeloma than white males and females. (RR 1.79 – 2.80)
     

  • Black females aged 65 and over were at a higher risk of cervical cancer than white females of the same age. (RR 1.13 - 2.50)
     

  • South Asian men and women had a higher rate of liver cancer than white males and females. (RR 1.47 – 2.43)
     

  • South Asian females 65 and over had an increased risk of cancer of the mouth (RR 1.18 – 1.97), whereas South Asian men may have a lower risk of getting cancer of the mouth than white men.
     

  • South Asian females aged 65 and over had a higher risk of cervical cancer than white females. (RR 1.15 - 2.29)  

Future Developments


This first national picture of how cancer affects minority ethnic populations offers a pivotal spring board from which further activities can be developed, including new research and work focused on particular ethnic communities.  It raises a number of important issues for commissioners around the notion of awareness and detection and screening programmes. There is an opportunity for commissioners to now ensure their services and programmes are fit for purpose in the light of this new evidence.

 

There are also a number of questions the NHS might now wish to address, nationally and locally: 

  • Do we have appropriate services flexible enough to cope with diversity?

  • Are there appropriately resourced services working within Primary Care with ethnic minority populations to inform them of the risk of cancer and provide appropriate awareness and early detection initiatives in culturally appropriate settings?

  • Are we able robustly to measure and monitor the impact of such programmes over time?

  • Can we improve ethnicity data collection further at a Trust level to improve the data pool? (data on ethnicity was available for only around 75% of cases)

  • How can commissioners best be supported on a practical level to think about diversity within the commissioning process?

The Cancer Reform Strategy provides a framework through initiatives like the National Awareness and Early Detection Initiative, NCEI, NCIN and the National Survivorship Initiative to start to address these issues.  Only through a focused and well coordinated approach will the NHS be able to start to pull the important pieces of the jigsaw together in a way that supports healthcare providers and commissioners, enabling them to develop and offer the most effective and appropriate services to all cancer patients.  The new ‘Principles’ document, launched at the start of October 2009, is an attempt to start this process, based on a review of current ‘best practice’ [ref 9]. 

 

References

  1. Department of Health. (2007). Cancer Reform Strategy. London: Department of Health.
    [view details]

  2. Cancer Research UK, National Cancer Intelligence Network (NCIN). (2009) Cancer Incidence and Survival by Major Ethnic Group England 2000 – 2006. London: Cancer Research UK.
    [view details]

  3. Winter, H., Cheng, K., K., Cummins, C. & R. Maric et al. (1999). Cancer incidence in the South Asian population of England (1990 – 92). British Journal of Cancer. Vol. 79, pt. 3-4, pp. 645-54.
    [view details]
     
  4. Farooq, S., Coleman, M., P. (2005) Breast Cancer Survival in South Asian Women in England and Wales.  Journal of Epidemiology Community Health. Vol. 59, pt. 5, pp. 402-6.
    [view details]
     
  5. Smith, L., K., Botha, J., L., Benghiat, A., & W. P. Steward. (2003). Latest trends in cancer incidence among UK South Asians in Leicester. British Journal of Cancer. Vol. 89, pp. 70-73.
    [view details]
     
  6. Chinegwundoh, F., Enver, M., Lee, E., & V. Nargund et al. (2006). Risk and presenting features of prostate cancer amongst African-Caribbean, south Asian and European men in North-East London. BJU International. Vol. 98, pt. 6, pp. 1216-20.
    [view details]
     
  7. Moles, D., R., Fedele, S., Speight, P., M., & R. S. Porter. (2007). The unclear role of ethnicity in health inequalities: The scenario of oral cancer incidence and survival in the British south Asian population. Oral Oncology. Vol. 43, pt. 8, pp. 831-4.
    [view details]
     
  8. Rastogi, T., Devesa, S., Mangtani, P., & A. Mathew et al. (2008). Cancer incidence rates among South Asians in four geographic regions: India, Singapore, UK and US. International Journal of Epidemiology. Vol. 37, pt. 1, pp. 147-60.
    [view details    ] 
     
  9. National Cancer Equality Initiative (NCEI). (2009). We can: reducing inequalities in commissioning cancer services. Principles and practical guidance for good equality working. London: National Cancer Equality Initiative (NCEI).
    [view details]      

 

Additional Cancer Resources

 

Bhala, N., Bhopal, R., Brock, A., & C. Griffiths et al. (2009). Alcohol-related and hepatocellular cancer deaths by country of birth in England and Wales: analysis of mortality and census data. Journal of Public Health. Vol. 31, pt. 2, pp. 250-7.

[view details] 

 

Iqbal, G., Gumber, A., Szczepura, A., & M. R. D. Johnson et al. (2008). Improving ethnic data collection for statistics of cancer incidence, management, mortality and survival in the UK. London: Cancer Research UK.

[view details] 

 

Koffman, J., Morgan, M., Edmonds, P., & P. Speck et al. (2008). Cultural meanings of pain: a qualitative study of black Caribbean and White British patients with advanced cancer. Palliative Medicine. Vol. 22, pt. 4, pp. 350-9.
[view details] 

 

Koffman, J., Morgan, M., Edmonds, P., & P. Speck et al. (2008). "I know he controls cancer": the meanings of religion among black Caribbean and White British patients with advanced cancer. Social Science and Medicine. Vol. 67, pt. 5, pp. 780-9.
[view details] 

 

Moser, K., Patnick, J., & V. Beral. (2009). Inequalities in reported use of breast and cervical screening in Great Britain: analysis of cross sectional survey data. BMJ. Vol. 338, pt. 7709, pp. 1480-1484
[view details]

 

Payne, S., A., Seymour, J., E., Chapman, A., & M. Holloway. (2008). Older Chinese people's views on food: implications for supportive cancer care. Ethnicity and Health. Vol. 13, pt. 5, pp. 497-514.
[view details] 

 

Redman, J., Higginbottom, G., M., A., & M., T. Massey. (2008). Critical review of literature on ethnicity and health in relation to cancer and palliative care in the United Kingdom. Diversity in Health and Social Care. Vol. 5, pt. 2, pp. 137-150.
[view details] 

 

Robb, K., A., Solarin, I., Power, E., & W. Atkin et al. (2008). Attitudes to colorectal cancer screening among ethnic minority groups in the UK. BMC Public Health.
[view details] 

 

Szczepura A, Price C, & A. Gumber . (2008). Breast and bowel cancer screening uptake patterns over 15 years for UK south Asian ethnic minority populations, corrected for differences in socio-demographic characteristics. BMC Public Health.
[view details] 

]]>

document.body:
An examination and comparison of the chracteristics of a community cohort of dually diagnosed (psychosis and substance abuse) individuals of black minority ethnic groups and white groups.

Dual diagnosis patients were identified through structured ratings by care managers. Social and clinical charateristic data of participants in the study was collated from staff and clients.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic differences in behavioural risk factors for stroke: implications for health promotion.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This study aimed to estimate the prevalence of four behavioural risk factors (smoking, drinking, exercise and weight) for stroke amongst black Caribbean, black African, and white ethnic groups. A reported willingness to change these behaviours was also explored.

A random sample of 311 black Caribbean, 300 white and 105 black Africans aged between 45 and 74 were surveyed. All participants were registered at one of sixteen general practices in south London.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic differences in cardiovascular drug response: potential contribution of pharmacogenetics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Since the early 1980's; clinical differences have been noted in the effects of blood pressure lowering drugs on people from different ethnic backgrounds. This review summarises the most widely recognised cardiovascular drugs with differential response by ethnicity and the evidence that may aid in our understanding of these differences.]]>

document.title: Ethnic differences in public health awareness, health perceptions and physical exercise: implications for heart disease prevention.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
This study explores whether the high variance in heart disease incidence amongst ethnic groups in the UK, particularly the higher mortality and morbidity in south Asians can be attributed to life-style and public health awareness.

A questionnaire based survey was distributed to 232 women attending an antenatal clinic in a city centre district general hospital. Ethnic groups included in the sample were: white (84), Afro-Caribbean (76) and Asian (south Asian or Indian subcontinent descent) (72).   

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic differences in the rates of BCG vaccination
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
With paediatric tuberculosis (TB) on the increase in the UK, the neonatal BCG vaccination is able to offer at least 65% protection.  This audit assesses the coverage of a selective neonatal BCG vaccination programme in Shropshire over a three year period.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic differences in the risks of adverse reactions to drugs used in the treatment of psychoses and depression: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This systematic review explores the evidence for ethnic differences in susceptibility to adverse reactions to drugs used to treat psychoses and depression.

MEDLINE (1951-2006), EMBASE (1974-2006) and PsycINFO (1950-2006) were searched for relevant studies.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic differences in the treatment of dual mental and substance disorders: a preliminary analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ A review of previous studies to identify differences between ethnic groups in prevelance and service use for dual mental and substance disorders.  Evidence is then presented from a longitudinal study conducted by the authors into the cost effectiveness of treatments for dual disorders with an emphasis on the differences in results between minority ethnic and white groups and the implications from this for treating dually disordered ethnic clients.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic disparities in coronary heart disease management and pay for performance in the UK
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,SERVICE SECTORS]]>
document.body:
This study examines the affect of a major pay for performance initiative in April 2004 on coronary heart disease management and intermediate clinical outcomes in a multiethnic population.

Two cross-sectional surveys were compared, one from before the introduction of the initiative (N = 2,891) and one after (N = 3,101).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic disparities in diabetes mangement and pay-for-performance in the UK: the Wandsworth Prospective Diabetes Study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,RACE EQUALITY,PEOPLE WITH LONG TERM & CHRONIC CONDITIONS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study examined disparities in management of people with diabetes within a multiethnic population in primary care before and after the introduction of a new contract introducing pay-for-performance rewards.  The study population included people of black Caribbean, black African, Indian, Pakistani and Bangladeshi backgrounds.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic diversity and mental health in London: recent developments
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
The need for change in mental health services particularly the experience and outcomes of care for black and minority ethnic communities has been well documented. This working paper collates evidence from published literature and telephone and face-to-face interviews with key informants.

The working paper includes information on:

  • The context
  • Key developments 1997-2003
  • The current situation
  • Black and minority ethnic women
  • Refugees and asylum seekers
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic diversity in type 2 diabetes
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES]]>
document.body:
This review assesses published data on the main ethnic groups in the UK Prospective Diabetes Study (UKPDS).

Ethnic groups included in the review are: white, Indian-Asians and Afro-Caribbeans.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic group differences in overweight and obese children and young people in England: cross sectional survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This study aimed to determine the percentage of children and young adults within different ethnic and socioeconomic groups who were obese or overweight.

A secondary analysis on 5689 children and young adults aged 2-20 years was conducted using data from the 1999 Health Survey for England.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic group disparities in 10-year trends in stroke incidence and vascular risk factors: the South London Stroke Register (SLSR)
document.publisher: Stroke: a Journal of cerebral circulation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Data monitoring trends are lacking for stroke risk amongst different ethnic groups, so this study looks at stroke incidence and modifiable stroke risk factors over a ten year period.

Changes in stroke incidence were investigated using the South London Stroke Register (SLSR). The SLSR is a population based register covering 271,817 inhabitants of South London. The ethnic makeup of the register is as follows: 63% white, 28% black and 9% other ethnic groups.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic inequalities in health and smoking behaviour: the role of social capital and social support
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,ETHNIC GROUPS,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,SOCIETY,SOCIOECONOMIC FACTORS,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,TOBACCO USE,SMOKING,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,POPULATIONS,GROUPS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This report examines levels of social capital and social support for white and minority ethnic groups in the UK and how these factors may contribute to ethnic differences in health and health-related behaviour. Three national surveys are analysed: the Health Survey for England (1993-95), the HEA Health and Lifestyles Survey (1992) and the HEA Survey of Black and Minority Ethnic Groups (1992) for adults from white, African, Caribbean, Indian, Pakistani and Bangladesh groups. The study focuses on variation in reported general health, psychosocial health, cigarette smoking and tobacco chewing.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic inequalities in health: the impact of racism
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE SECTORS,SERVICE DELIVERY,ETHNICITY,DISADVANTAGED GROUPS,PUBLIC HEALTH,RACE EQUALITY,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,CULTURAL IDENTITY]]>
document.body:
The key messages from this Better Health Briefing (Number 3) are:

 

  • People from minority ethnic groups can experience poor treatment due to negative attitudes regarding their character and abilities

  • Evidence of victimisation is difficult to establish as people respond to racist experiences in different ways

  • Services have an important role to play as a support for victims but also as a domain for racist experiences

  • Encouraging trust among service users and minority ethnic communities is important for establishing a supportive and protective environment for those potentially at risk of victimisation

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic inequalities in the treatment and outcome of diabetes in three English primary care trusts
document.publisher: International Journal for Equity in Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
Despite the fact that diabetes has a higher prevalence in south Asian people than white European people in the UK, there are no reports on the extent of ethnicity recording in general practice and few studies concerning the association between ethnicity and quality of diabetes care and outcomes.  This study aims to determine the association between ethnicity and healthcare factors in an English population.

Data was obtained in 2002 from all the general practices in three North West London Primary Care Trusts.  21,343 diabetic patients were identified and health data for them was used in the study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic minorities and prescription medication; concordance between self-reports and medical records
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
This study aimed to examine to which extent ethnic differences between self-reported data and electronic medical records (EMR) for GP's might be a validity issue or whether the records would reflect a lower compliance among ethnic minority groups.

A cross-sectional national representative GP study was carried using EMR data from 195 pratices. Self-reported data was collected through face-to-face interviews.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic Minority Demography, Disease Patterns and Pathways to Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES]]>
document.body:
This module is intended to complement the other modules of the course.  It deliberately adopts a more clinical and ‘factual’ approach in some respects, and may appear at times to reflect a ‘medical model’ of health, rather than the social approach.  However, we insist that a ‘social model’ should underpin all consideration of epidemiology, since many of the factors considered are socially constructed.  However, we need also to recognise that people do have real illnesses and require clinical treatment using medicine and surgery. This module intends to help the practitioner to consider some of the clinical issues with which he or she may be faced. Illness, or the ‘sick role’, like other disabilities, can be socially constructed.  Therefore, you should always be critical of the facts presented to you.

Like every other section of the course, we begin with some definitions, including consideration of the meaning of ‘ethnicity’ and ‘race’.  Those we present here may differ in some ways from those in use in other modules that is not to say that we consider the others as wrong or less useful. However, for the discussion we are having, these may be helpful in this context.  The reflective and alert practitioner must be prepared to balance different definitions of key concepts like these!  (From the Royal College of Nursing) 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic monitoring: is health equality possible without it?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
This 'better health briefing' (number 21) from the Race Equality Foundation has the following key messages:

  • The collection and use of ethnic group data enables health services to demonstrate a clear and localised understanding of where inequalities exist and how to address them.
  • There are no systematic data available for ethnic health inequalities due to the lack of mandatory ethnic monitoring across primary care.
  • Continuing poor compliance with race equality legislation gives particular cause for concern.
  • A strong regulatory framework and committed leadership are required for successful ethnic monitoring.
  • Examples of good practice exist but failure to use ethnicity data is a continuing barrier.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic variation in childhood asthma and wheezing illnesses: findings from the Millennium Cohort Study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
A study investigating whether asthma and wheeze illness during early childhood differs across ethnic groups.

Data on 14, 360 children from the UK Millennium Cohort Study was analysed. Interviews were conducted with parents whose children were aged approximately three and a half years of age.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic variations in incidence of asthma episodes in England & Wales: national study of 502,482 patients in primary care.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Although a great deal is known about international variations in asthma prevalence there is little known about variations in individual countries. This study investigates ethnic variations in incidence of asthma episodes in England and Wales with an emphasis on the impact of migration on the risk of developing asthma.

Using data from the Fourth National Study of Morbidity Statistics in General Practice, this study investigated ethnic variations in incident asthma consultations, and compared consultation rates between those born inside and outside the UK. Logistic regression models were used to examine the combined effects of ethnicity and migration on asthma incident consultations.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic variations in pathways to and use of specialist mental health services in the UK: systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES]]>
document.body:
Tackling inequalities of service use across ethnic groups is becoming increasingly important to policy makers and service providers. This systematic review aims to identify ethnic variations in pathways to specialist mental health services in the UK.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic variations in sexual behaviour in Great Britain and risk of sexually transmitted infections: a probability survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH,INFECTIONS,ADDED 2009,DEC 09]]>
document.body:
Many developed countries have reported ethnic variations in the rates of diagnosed sexually transmitted infections (STI's); this study uses data from the 2000 British National Survey of Sexual Attitudes and Lifestyles to investigate sexual behaviours and adverse sexual health outcomes in five ethnic groups in Great Britain.  

11,161 men and women aged 16-44 years were included in a stratified probability sample. Additional sampling meant that a more detailed analysis of 949 black Caribbean, black African, Indian and Pakistani participants could be conducted.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnic variations in UK asthma frequency, morbidity, and health-service use: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This systematic review explores evidence and aims to understand possible reasons for ethnic variations in asthma frequency, morbidity and health service use in the UK.

A systematic review was conducted using MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, PSYCHinfo, PREMEDLINE, HEALTHSTAR, Cambridge Register of Conference Abstracts, Dissertation and Thesis Database and the National Registry of Research. Websites of health authorities and bibliographies of identified reports were also searched.

]]>

This review discusses ethnicity and cardiovascular disease (CVD) in the UK and also provides recommendations based on a round table discussion of a mulitdisciplinary ethnicity and CVD consensus group.

Topics discussed include:

  • Current guidelines for ethnicity and CVD prevention
  • Smoking cessation
  • Hypertension
  • Dyslipidaemia
  • DM and metabolic syndrome
  • Ischaemic heart disease
  • Peripheral artery disease
  • Cardiac rehabilitation and public health issues

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnicity and cardiovascular risk: variations in people of African ancestry and south Asian origin
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
Mortality from CHD, stroke and end-stage renal failure are high in migrants of south Asian ethnicity in the UK. Conversely while stroke and end-stage renal failure are high in black migrants to the UK; CHD is low. This study investigates factors that may influence this variation.

CEEHD Note: This is a signal study that has led to further research.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnicity and coronary heart disease: making sense of risk and improving care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,NHS ACTIVITIES,POLICY,SERVICE SECTORS,QUALITY AND MONITORING,RISK MANAGEMENT,ACUTE SERVICES,SERVICE DELIVERY,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,QUALITY IMPROVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Key messages from this better health briefing (Number 16) include:

  • It is predicted that cardiovascular disease will become the dominant cause of death and disability across the globe over the next decade and beyond
  • Little is known as to why the five major coronary risk factors vary in potency across different ethnic groups
  • Although the relationship is complex ethnicity is recognised as a risk factor for developing coronary heart disease with people for minority ethnic groups in the UK differing from the general population in susceptibility to cardiovascular disease
  • Developing culturally appropriate services will increase people's awareness of coronary risk factors and support people to live a healthier lifestyle
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnicity and health: reviews of literature and guidance for purchasers in the areas of cardiovascular disease, mental health and haemoglobinopathies
document.publisher: NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,BLOOD DISORDERS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
These reviews were commissioned on behalf of the Research and Development Directorate of the NHS Executive West Midlands, in their capacity as the authority with the lead responsibility for the NHS R&D initiative on 'Ethnic Health'. The aim is to provide research based information and recommendations that can be implemented by the NHS as a whole. The three areas of focus are cardiovascular disease, mental health, and haemoglobinopathies.


Author's conclusions

Despite the considerable research activity in the area of ethnicity and health, purchasers and providers in health care lack clear guidance on health care needs and service organisation. The literature suggests that although cultural, genetic and social factors are important in certain diseases, access to appropriate health services can appreciably relieve this burden of disease. However, Britain's ethnic minority populations are to be found principally in the poorer regions, and inner cities, where health services are least well developed. They may also be among the least able to take advantage of the existing services because of a variety of barriers to access, ranging from language and culture, to prejudiced views of service purchasers and providers, and discriminatory institutional practices.


Bibliographic details

NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination; Social Policy Research Unit, University of York. Ethnicity and health: reviews of literature and guidance for purchasers in the areas of cardiovascular disease, mental health and haemoglobinopathies. Centre for Reviews and Dissemination (CRD), 1996; CRD Report 5: 224

]]>

This module explores the needs of people with learning disabilities, the needs of their carers, and the services available to meet those needs. It attempts to outline the kinds of services that are inclusive to all ethnic communities and the issues that can cause problems for service users, particularly those from minority ethnic groups. The focus of this module is on health and social care, though other areas are also touched upon. The module has been adapted as a teaching resource from a report on 'Learning Difficulties and Ethnicity' published by the Department of Health

and

document.body:
Despite high levels of known psychosocial risk, perinatal depression amongst black African women remains relatively under researched. This study examines the prevalence and psychosocial risks of perinatal depression as well as help seeking behaviours among this ethnic group.

In depth interviews were conducted with 12 participants who were selected from a sample of 101 black African women.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnicity and Mental Health Today
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.description: Professor Raj Persaud highlights the challenges of providing mental health care in a multicultural society in his article for the SLEH National Knowledge Week, published on World Mental Health Day, 2007.
document.body:
111-1Ethnicity and Mental Health Today

for SLEH National Knowldege Week 2007

Dr Raj Persaud

BSc MSc MB BS MPhil FRCPsych

Consultant Psychiatrist, The Maudsley Hospital London

Gresham Professor for Public Understanding of Psychiatry 

Ethnicity and Mental Health Today

Ethnicity has a major impact on mental health in a wide variety of ways. As a variable with significant implications for rates of psychiatric disorder, it has attracted increasing interest from medical research, as it may provide a clue as the aetiology or causation of psychological problems.

In the early years of research, attention often focused on whether varying rates of psychiatric disorders depended on the patients’ culture or birthplace or new country of settlement. Were reported variations accounted for by genuine contrasts in rates or were there alternative explanations?  For example was it possible that the words for emotions like depression might be easier to declare in some languages compared to others? Could it be some cultures were more 'psychologically minded' compared to others. It might be that in some cultures a person might declare physical symptoms of pain or distress associated with depression rather than emotions, and this might lead to misclassification by doctors.

In the end, the thrust of research using standardised instruments for measuring emotional and other mental states began to converge on the remarkable idea that rates of major mental illness might be astonishingly similar across completely different parts of the planet. The most famous study in this area was one conducted in collaboration with WHO across the world (see Sartorius 1996 below), which found startlingly similar rates of schizophrenia no matter what country was investigated.

However, there are varying rates found within countries. For example African-Caribbean people in the UK have been reported as suffering extraordinarily high rates of schizophrenia for reasons that still remain unclear. Some people argue behaviour which is acceptable in one culture is mislabelled in another as mental illness - but this is now probably a minority view within the academic field. An alternative view that has been proposed is that some cultures might smoke a lot of cannabis or chew khat, and this could also account for varying rates of mental illness.

Now interest is converging on pathways to care.  It is suggested that patients from some cultures, due to stigma around mental illness or difficulty engaging with services, experience longer periods of untreated mental illness.  This could account for varying rates of diagnosis, use of forced admission, or involvement of police.

What culture you originate from may also determine how much stress you experience, due to altered rates of unemployment or discrimination in a host culture. This may explain why being an emigrant has been found to be a particularly ominous risk factor for the development of major mental illness.

Another issue now arising is the possibility of contrasts in approach to treatment depending on your culture. For example, exorcism is considered appropriate in some cultures, but it has been deemed positively dangerous by some western doctors as deaths have been reported following beatings used to drive demons out of the mentally ill.

References and Resources

Prof Raj Persaud's podcast interview on Royal College of Psychiatrists website on ethnicity and mental health
(Prof Raj Persaud and Prof Swaran Singh)

Leaflets on depression in languages besides English - Look under the heading 'Materials in other languages:'

 

‘The Mind: a users guide’- A book pubished by the Royal College of Psychiatrists


W.L. Alan Fung, Dinesh Bhugra and Peter B. Jones, Ethnicity and mental health: the example of schizophrenia in migrant populations across Europe
Psychiatry, Volume 5, Issue 11, November 2006, Pages 396-401

N Sartorius, W Gulbinat, G Harrison, E Laska and C Siegel, Long-term follow-up of schizophrenia in 16 countries: a description of the International Study of Schizophrenia conducted by the World Health Organization
Soc Psychiatr Psychiatric Epidemiol, Volume 31, 1996, Pages 249–258

 

]]>

document.body:
This article focuses predominantly on people of south Asian, black Caribbean and black African descent to identify possible pathophysiological differences between ethnic groups for peripheral artery disease.

CEEHD Note: There is considerable heterogeneity of risk factors, and a lower than expected level of PAD in both south Asian and black groups but patterns observed in American populations (Asian Indian or black) do not appear in UK minority groups. Treatment options may need to be varied from protocols based on white British people.

There continues to be a lack of an adequate explanation for the disproportionately low rates of cadaveric organ donation amongst ethnic minorities. This paper explores how ethnicity shapes perceptions of identity and belonging that support organ donation discourse amongst a section of black British Caribbean people.

14 in-depth interviews were carried out with men and women of Caribbean descent living in South London, UK.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnicity questions and antenatal screening for sickle cell/thalassaemia [EQUANS] in England: a randomised controlled trial of two questionnaires.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,BLOOD DISORDERS,CANCER,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
This study involved a randomised controlled trial of two ethnicity screening questions used to ascertain risk of carrying genes associated with sickle cell and thalassaemia.  The screening questions were tested in low, mixed and high sickle cell prevalence areas.  Time taken in adminstration of the questions was also tested.

4,559 pregnant women were randomly allocated one of two ethnicity screening questions.  Questions were administered over a 10 month period in 4 geographical areas of England.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnicity, health and health behaviour: a study of older groups
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,ETHNICITY,ADULTS,OLDER PEOPLE,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,LIFESTYLE,POPULATIONS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This report summarises the main findings from a study of health inequalities among white, African Caribbean, Indian, Pakistani and Bangladesh adults aged 50 and above. Three large-scale British datasets are used to explore the relationship between age, ethnicity and health. Ethnic differences in alcohol consumption, cigarette smoking and tobacco chewing among older men and women are analysed and the likely contribution of these health-related behaviors to the health of these groups is discussed.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ethnicity, race, and health in multicultural societies: foundations for better epidemiology, public health and health care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Multi-ethnic societies now account for the majority of the industrialised world and with globalisation, increasing international travel and migration the world is set to become multi-ethnic within the next 20 to 30 years. This poses a great challenge for health services, they have to meet social, ethical, legal and policy obligations to deliver effective healthcare to ethnic minority groups.

This textbook aims to lay a foundation for those wishing to acquire the knowledge to meet these obligations.  

Topics discussed in the textbook include:

  • The concepts of ethnicity and race in health
  • Terminology and classifications for ethnic and racial groups
  • Challenges of collecting and interpreting data using the concepts of ethnicity and race
  • Defining health and health care needs using quantitative and qualitative data
  • Ethnic inequalities in health and health care
  • Principles for setting priorities for ethnic minority populations
  • Strategic approaches to health and health care services for ethnic minority groups

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Experiences of bullying and racial harassment among minority ethnic staff in the NHS
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,HEALTH SERVICE STAFF,NHS ACTIVITIES,WORKFORCE,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
This better health briefing (Number 14) has the following key messages:

  • Disproportionate experiences of bullying and harassment have been reported by minority ethnic staff in the NHS.
  • Most events of bullying and harassment are not directly reported to employers.
  • Experiences of bullying and harassment are associated with poor organisational and health outcomes.
  • Support has been found to alleviate the detrimental impact of bullying and harassment on organisational and health outcomes.
  • Efforts to target racist bullying and harassment need to be embedded into existing initiatives that tackle bullying and harassment.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Experiences of refugees and asylum seekers in general practice: a qualitative study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.description: The problem of poor access for those with inadequate support may be improved by better education and support for GPs in how to provide for refugees. Primary Care Trusts could also supply information to newly arrived refugees on how to access services.
document.body:
Background: There has been much debate regarding the refugee health situation in the UK.  However most of the existing literature fails to take account of the opinions of refugees themselves. This study was established to determine the views of asylum seekers and refugees on their overall experiences in primary care and to suggest improvements to their care.

Methods: Qualitative study of adult asylum seekers and refugees who had entered the UK in the last 10 years. The study was set in Barnet Refugee Walk-in Service, London.  Eleven semi-structured interviews were  conducted and analysed using framework analysis.

Results: Access to GPs may be more difficult for failed asylum seekers and those without support from refugee agencies or family. There may be concerns amongst some in the refugee community regarding the access to and confidentiality of professional interpreters. Most participants stated their preference for GPs who offered advice rather than prescriptions. The stigma associated with refugee status in the UK may have led to some refugees altering their help seeking behaviour.

Conclusion: The problem of poor access for those with inadequate support may be improved by better education and support for GPs in how to provide for refugees. Primary Care Trusts could also supply information to newly arrived refugees on how to access services. GPs should be aware that, in some situations, professional interpreters may not always be desired and that instead, it may be advisable to reach a consensus as to who should be used as an interpreter. A better doctorpatient experience resulting from improvements in access and communication may help to reduce the stigma associated with refugee status and lead to more appropriate help seeking behaviour.  Given the small nature of our investigation, larger studies need to be conducted to confirm and to quantify these results.

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,TRADITIONAL MEDICINE AND TREATMENTS]]>

Adult migrants from Zambia, Zimbabwe and South Africa were included in 11 focus groups and 20 repeat interviews undertaken between 2008 and 2009.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Factors affecting attitudes toward colorectal cancer screening in the primary care population
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
Regular screening for colorectal cancer (CRC) could significantly reduce morbidity and mortality for the condition; however uptake rates in the UK for CRC screening are currently less than 60%. This study investigates the factors that affect attitudes towards screening.

11, 355 patients aged 50-69 years registered at general practices in the West Midlands completed questionnaires. A multivariable logistic regression was then performed to identify factors that contributed to positive or negative attitudes towards screening.

The study found that patients with an Indian background tend to have a negative attitude towards screening while black-Caribbean patients tend to have a positive attitude. The study recommends that, "culturally relevant screening strategies should aim to increase knowledge of the symptoms and signs related to bowel cancer among south Asian ethnic groups" in the UK.

]]>

document.body:
The advent of induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) technology could revolutionize the way we study human liver biology allowing for "off the shelf" models of human liver disease.

This study shows, "the proof of concept that iPSC lines representing both male and female sexes and two ethnic origins can be differentiated to HE at efficiencies of between 70-90%, using a method mimicking a physiological condition." (Wiley)

CEEHD Note: this is a 'proof of concept' paper and as yet not directly applicable to treatment regimes or UK groups.


Authors: Gareth J. Sullivan, Gareth J.; Hay, David C.; Park, In-Hyun; Fletcher, Judy; Hannoun, Zara; Payne, Catherine M.; Dalgetty, Donna; Black, James R.; Ross, James A.; Samuel, Kay;  Wang,  Gang; Daley, George Q.;  Lee, Je-Hyuk; Church, George M.; Forbes, Stuart J.; Iredale , John P. ; Wilmut, Ian

document.body: <![CDATA[ Although the observed increased incidence of colorectal cancer on Ashkenazi Jews compared with other populations is currently unexplained it is likely to have a genetic component; with the I1307K APC polymorphism/mutation being carried by 6-8% of Ashkenazim increasing risk of colorectal cancer by 1.5-2 fold.  ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Genetics, religion and identity: a study of British Bangladeshis (2004-7)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CLINICAL GENETICS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION]]>
document.description: The 2001 Census recorded 283,063 Bangladeshis living in Britain; around 17% of the UK Muslim population, this major project is a study of British Bangladeshi Muslim families with genetic disorders. The project's main aims were: to discover how genetic information was transmitted between different generations, how families make decisions about genetic information in relation to health care and religious professional opinion and what role Islam played in shaping decision-making.
document.body:
This is a study of British Bangladeshi Muslim families with genetic disorders.

The study had several related aims:

  • to explore the role of Islam in the lives of British Bangladeshi Muslims in relation to genetic disorders. 
  • to understand the specific ways Bangladeshi Muslim families make sense of genetic disorders, including how they share this information with close or extended family members.
  • to build on previous work with Pakistani Muslims so as to identify the similarities and differences between these two communities.
  • the study also explored other cultural resources people draw on in dealing with genetic disorders.
  • issues of consanguineous and arranged marriages, which are prevalent among the British Bangladeshis and have implications for genetic disorders, were also explored.

20 families and 12 imams were included in the study, interviews and focus groups were conducted in Bangla, English and/or Sylheti.

Several publications have already emerged from this research with more planned for the future.

]]>

  • Conclusion
  • Suggested reading

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health and access to health care of migrants in the UK
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,CLIENT GROUPS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,ETHNIC GROUPS,DISADVANTAGED GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT,SERVICE DELIVERY,NHS ACTIVITIES,QUALITY AND MONITORING,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,RACE EQUALITY,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,HEALTH SERVICES,HEALTHCARE & HEALTH SERVICES,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,AUGUST 2010]]>
document.body:
Key messages from this 'Better Health' briefing (Number 19) are:

  • The UK population of those born overseas continues to grow and this has important implications for the planning and delivery of health services 
  • While government policy has concentrated on reducing ethnic inequalities in health, little emphasis has been placed on possible impacts for migrants of factors such as: country of birth, language, length of residence in the UK and immigration status
  • Although there has been some research focus on asylum seekers and refugees there has been less focus on broader categories of migrants
  • There is particular evidence of barriers to health care for some vulnerable migrants, with concerns over 'health tourism' having a negative effect on access to health care for migrants
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health and use of health services: a comparison between Gypsies and Travellers and other ethnic groups
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,GYPSIES AND TRAVELLERS]]>
document.body:
This study examines the health status of Gypsies and Travellers and compares it with other ethnic groups.

A cross-sectional questionnaire survey using validated standardised health measures was conducted with a sample of 516 participants (173 men, 343 women). Ethnic groups included in the study were: Gypsies and Travellers, Pakistani Muslims, African Caribbean and white adults.

]]>

The chapter includes:

  • Prevalence and incidence
  • Services available and their costs
  • Effectiveness of services and interventions

]]>

document.title: Health care needs of Travellers
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
This article discusses the health care needs of Travellers, issues discussed include:

  • Causes of poor health
  • Education
  • Access to health care
  • Health care provision for travellers
  • The use of specialist health visitors 
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health experiences of Chinese people in the UK
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Key messages from this better health briefing paper (Number 10) include:

  • The UK Chinese community is an heterogeneous ethnic group
  • General assumptions made about Chinese people can effect the understanding of their needs for health and social care services
  • A mixed approach to health and illness tends to be adopted by Chinese people
  • Older people, women and middle aged men working in the family catering industry are the most vulnerable to exclusion from health services
  • Insensitivity to Chinese people's health needs on the part of mainstream services has resulted in negative consequences
  • A better understanding of Chinese people's health beliefs is needed to improve practice
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health fair in a mosque: putting policy into practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This paper illustrates how a Muslim community in Edinburgh was encouraged to become involved in its own health care by holding a health fair at its mosque.

The health fair was organised with the Minority Ethnic Health Inclusion Project and held over two consecutive Fridays in May 2003, around 320 members of the community attended.  

]]>

document.body:

  • What is known about the health status of ethnic minority groups in Scotland?
  • Research ethics and methods
  • Priorities for future research in Scotland
  • Refernces
  • Appendices
]]>

document.title: Health needs of prisoners in England and Wales: the implications for prison healthcare of gender, age and ethnicity
document.publisher: Health and Social Care in the Community
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This literature review aims to identify the healthcare needs of prisoners in relation to gender, age and ethnicity.

17 databases were searched to identify relevant studies, standardised tools were then used to critically appraise identified studies for quality.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health promotion and prevention interventions in Pakistani, Chinese and Indian communities related to CVD and Cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
An international systematic review of health promotion interventions and preventative studies in Pakistani, Chinese and Indian communities related to CVD (cardiovascular disease) and Cancer.

A systematic search of the main electronic databases was undertaken. The scope of the review was refined after consultation with members of an advisory group. A total of 21 Interventions were identified with a further 7 studies consulted.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health services: knowledge, use and satisfaction of Afghan, Iranian and Iraqi settlers in Australia
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
This study examines the knowledge of, use of and satisfaction with local primary healthcare services by new arrivals to Australia from Ian, Iraq and Afghanistan.

Semi-structured interviews and focus groups were conducted with 98 new settlers from the selected countries.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: This is an Australian study and some findings may not transfer to UK practice.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health status of Chinese women in Northern Ireland: SF-36 health survey
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN]]>
document.body:
In contrast to the rest of the UK the largest minority ethnic group in Northern Ireland is Chinese. There are currently few research findings on the health status of Chinese in the UK, particularly in respect to women. This study aimed to investigate the general health status of Chinese women living in Northern Ireland and to provide suggestions for health promotion.

A questionnaire was conducted on 48 Chinese women between 2002 and 2003 including demographic measures, open ended questions and the SF-36 health survey (Hong Kong version). Data was analysed using the online scoring system, this was then coded and analysed using SPSS (version 11.0).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health status of gypsies and travellers in England
document.publisher: Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,GYPSIES AND TRAVELLERS]]>
document.body:
This study aims to develop the first valid and reliable estimate of the health status of gypsies and travellers in England.

An epidemiological survey using structured interviews was conducted with 293 gypsies and travellers of UK or Irish origin. A comparison sample of 260 participants (age and sex matched) were also included.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health status, health behaviour and healthcare use among migrants in the UK: evidence from mothers in the Millennium Cohort Study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Of considerable policy interest in the UK is the health of migrants and their access to healthcare.  While there is evidence relating to access and use of healthcare there has been little consideration as to the importance of birth abroad and length of residence in the UK.  This study examines indicators of health status, behaviour and healthcare use among mothers of infants in the Millennium Cohort Study according to birth status (UK or abroad), ethnic grouping and length of residence.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Health survey for England 2004: the health of minority ethnic groups
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,STATISTICS]]>
document.body:
The Health Survey for England (HSE) commissioned by the Department of Health provides regular information on aspects concerning the public's health that cannot be easily obtained elsewhere.

This survey; the second in the series to focus on ethnic minorities develops themes explored in the 1999 survey.

Ethnic groups covered in the survey include: black African, black Caribbean, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Chinese and Irish.

Also available to download:

Summary of key findings, PDF

Methodology and documentation, PDF 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Healthcare for Survivors of Torture
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
111-1Healthcare for Survivors of Torture

Written for the 'ethnicity and health' Annual Evidence Update 2010

 
Dr Nimisha Patel

Head of Audit and Evaluation, Research
(Medical Foundation for the care of victims of torture)

Reader in Clinical Psychology,
University of East London 		Dr Amanda Williams

Research Consultant,
(Medical Foundation for the care of victims of torture)

Reader in Clinical Health Psychology,
University College London

"The Medical Foundation is a charity which cares for some 2,000 survivors of torture every year. It produces data and research papers to maintain and enhance clinical care for those who have been abused. These cover different aspects such as the proper identification of victims, training others to become service providers so as to extend capacity worldwide, and examining new ways forward in the range of therapies. We rely on clinical volunteers to support our work and hope that this commentary will help stimulate debate on the subject and inform clinical practice."


Keith Best
Chief Executive
Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture

Healthcare for Survivors of Torture

Introduction

Torture is a deliberate assault upon the body, the psyche, the identity and the integrity of the person, aiming to dehumanise, degrade, destroy or debilitate and render the individual totally helpless. It is usually inflicted using a combination of methods, physical, psychological and sexual, often in adverse detention conditions and over several episodes. The health needs of torture survivors, adults and children, are varied, given the diverse experiences of torture, and as asylum seekers and refugees their experiences in exile. Further, children, both unaccompanied and in families have differing needs according to age and stage of development.

 

Impact of torture

The impact of torture can be physical and psychological, as well as affecting existential, spiritual, functional and interpersonal aspects of well-being, with clinical presentations being complex and diverse. Physical health problems related to torture have been widely-documented and can impact on all systems [refs 15, 19, 5, 10, 20], often producing long-term problems, particularly chronic pain [ref 26]. Psychological health problems are also widely documented (e.g. refs 18, 1, 11, 2). The impact of torture can extend beyond the individual to their family (e.g. affecting family relationships, parenting and functioning) and to their community, disturbing social cohesion and social networks and support, often by intentionally fostering terror, uncertainty, mistrust and suspicion of others.

 

Evidence

Most of the research on psychological and physical health difficulties experienced by torture survivors focuses on adults, describing their status before or without treatment or of clinical opinions and case studies (for reviews see ref 19). The very small proportion of outcome studies is dominated by case studies and clinical narratives, with few cohort studies and fewer controlled trials, with inconclusive findings. There is very little on children and adolescents, mainly accounts of group rehabilitation of child soldiers, or of broad initiatives for family health.

In summary, no single intervention is considered effective for torture survivors, who often present with multiple health and other needs. Treatment combining a range of interventions as part of a rehabilitation programme is considered to be beneficial, but specific contributions of component interventions is difficult to ascertain.

There are significant methodological limitations in existing outcome studies, including very small sample size, no control group, and varying definitions of diagnostic criteria [ref 19], which together with heterogeneous samples and interventions, plus different assessment measures, make comparisons difficult. In particular, psychological interventions largely use assessment or evaluation tools which are diagnosis-based, developed and standardised in the West for Western, English-speaking populations. Few of those, translated into the required language, show evidence of validity [refs 11, 23, 4]. Most current psychological outcome measures fail even to demonstrate linguistic or semantic equivalence, raising serious concerns about their validity for culturally diverse populations (e.g. refs 7, 17, 9, 8, 25).

A significant proportion of available evidence focuses on the effectiveness of particular psychological interventions with torture survivors with a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and depression (e.g. refs 13, 3). Further, studies of PTSD-specific treatments (as recommended by NICE PTSD Guidelines [ref 14]) do not include torture survivor samples. The diverse health difficulties, including complex trauma, experienced by torture survivors, beyond symptoms of PTSD or depression, are largely neglected. The impact on health of external and ongoing stressors (e.g. racism, homelessness, threat of return to the country where they were tortured, detention in the UK, legal processes for determining asylum) experienced by torture survivors is also rarely acknowledged.

The over-reliance on psychiatric diagnoses to represent the nature, severity and complexity of psychological health problems experienced by torture survivors is criticised for individualising, medicalising or psychologising the sociopolitical problem of torture, which is a human rights violation [refs 17, 22, 4]. Recent clinical experience with torture survivors also highlights how an exclusive reliance on psychiatric diagnoses and diagnosis-specific treatments can neglect the diversity and complexity of clinical presentations; the contributions of destitution, poverty, racism, social, housing, welfare, legal and other factors to health requires an integrative and sequenced approach to interventions [ref 12]. Furthermore, there is a risk of neglecting the meanings that survivors ascribe to their experiences, meanings which are culturally-shaped and central to the treatment process.

 

Service design and delivery principles

Provision and access to appropriate healthcare relevant to the needs of torture survivors is difficult. There are no statutory services specifically for torture survivors, although organisations such as the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture provide a range of services specifically for such patients. However, torture survivors, recognised or unrecognised, do use a range of statutory health services, including those offering healthcare to asylum seekers and refugees. The evidence indicates that, when compared to other asylum seekers and refugees, torture survivors tend to have more severe and enduring health problems and complex presentations. Thus, caution is warranted if generalising from the literature on these other populations.

General service design and delivery principles, on which there is broad consensus globally amongst specialist service providers for torture survivors, include:

  1. Services provided should be relevant to the diverse needs of adults, young people (including unaccompanied minors) and families, arising from the experiences of torture. This requires that services are interdisciplinary and integrated (able to address psychological, physical, social, welfare and educational needs impacting on well-being) and provided collaboratively with service users. Services must be offered with professional interpreters where necessary, as this is essential to quality assessments, examinations and treatment). The use of treatments recommended by NICE [ref 14], but still untested to date for torture survivors from non-Western populations, must be used with caution.  Careful consideration should be given to the cultural, social and political background of the torture survivor and to the context of torture as a human rights violation. The serious adverse impact of detention in the UK on the psychological health of adults and children requires recognition [ref 21] and attention [ref 6].

  2. Access to health and social care services should be timely, offered in a safe, secure and stable environment conducive to recovery, and ensure a prompt health assessment of torture survivors [refs 16, 5]. This should ensure adequate care to minimise risk of harm, and to prevent health difficulties related to torture becoming chronic and disabling; and that health needs and experiences of torture are documented [ref 24], as they may contribute to the legal protection of torture survivors claiming asylum in the UK. Services should be non-discriminatory and culturally appropriate and, wherever possible, provided within a human rights framework.

References

  1. Alayarian, A. Children, torture and psychological consequences. (2009) Torture,19 (2): 145-56.
    [view details]

  2. Basoglu, M., Jaranson, J.M., Mollica R, Kastrup M. (2001) Torture and mental health: A research overview. In: Gerrity, E., Keane, T.M. and Tuma, F., (Eds.) The mental health consequences of torture. NY: Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers.
    [view details]

  3. Bichescu, D., Neuner, F., Schauer, M. and Elbert, T. (2007) Narrative exposure therapy for political imprisonment-related chronic posttraumatic stress disorder and depression. Behaviour Research and Therapy.doi:10.1016/j.brat.2006.12.006.
    [view details]

  4. Bracken, P., Giller, J., Summerfield, D. (1995) Psychological responses of war and atrocity: Limitations of current concepts. Social Science and Medicine, 40 (8): 1073-82.
    [view details]

  5. Burnett, A. and Peel, M. (2001) Asylum seekers and refugees in Britain: The health of survivors of torture and organised violence. British Medical Journal, 322: 606-609.
    [view details]

  6. Cohen, J. (2008) Safe in our hands?: A study of suicide and self-harm in asylum seekers. Journal of Forensic and Legal Medicine, 15: 235–244.
    [view details]

  7. Elsass, P. Carlsson J, Jesperson, K, and Phuntsok, K. (2009). Questioning western assessment of trauma among Tibetan torture survivors. A quantitative assessment study with comments from Buddhist Lamas. Torture, 19 (3): 194-203.
    [view details]

  8. Gurr, R. and Quiroga, J. (2001) Approaches to Torture Rehabilitation. Torture, 11: 5-35.
    [download pdf] 431 kb

  9. Hollifield, M., Warner, T.D., Lian, N., Krakow, B., Jenkins, J.H., Kesler, J., Stevenson, J., Westermeyer, J. (2002). Measuring trauma and health status in refugees: a critical review. Journal of the American Medical Association , 288: 611-621.
    [view details]

  10. Jacobs, U. and Iacopino, V. (2001) Torture and its consequences: A challenge to clinical neuropsychology. Professional Psychology-Research and Practice, 32(5): 458-64.

  11. Johnson, H. and Thompson, A. (2008) The development and maintenance of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in civilian adult survivors of war trauma and torture: a review. Clinical Psychology Review, 28(1): 36-47.

  12. Miller, K, E, & Rasmussen A. (2010). War exposure, daily stressors, and mental health in conflict and post-conflict settings: Bridging the divide between trauma-focused and psychosocial frameworks. Social Science and Medicine. 70 (1): 7-16.

  13. Neuner, F., Kurreck, S., Ruf, M., Odenwald, M. Elbert, T., and Schauer, M. (2009). Can asylum-seekers with post-traumatic stress disorder be successfully treated? A randomized controlled pilot study. Cognitive Behaviour Therapy. Vol. 39, pt. 2, pp. 81-91.

  15. Norredam, M., Crosby, S., Munarriz, R., Piwowarczyk, L. and Grodin, M. (2005) Urologic complications of sexual trauma among male survivors of torture. Urology, 65(1): 28-32.
