document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Healthy ageing, healthy living project
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This is a report of a three year project conducted by Age Concern on behalf of the Department of Health which looked into increasing the participation of older people from non-mainstream groups in health promotion activity through volunteering.  The report is aimed at organisations looking to develop health promotion work with these groups.

The report includes:

  • Introduction
  • Accomplishments and successes of the project
  • The project
  • Aims and outcomes of the project
  • Background
  • Policy context
  • The "Ageing Well" project
  • Volunteering - what does the literature say?
  • Methodology
  • Resource development and dissemination
  • Steering group
  • Meetings, events and external contacts
  • Evaluation
  • Consultation and "Ageing Well" network
  • Recommendations
  • Conclusion
  • References
  • Appendices
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Healthy weight, healthy lives: consumer insight summary
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This report is a summary of the results of research carried out into family attitudes and behaviours relating to diet and activity.

Research into attitudes and behaviours towards diet and activity was also carried out in six ethnic minority communities as a seperate project; results and insights from this research are summarised at the end of each chapter of this report. Ethnic minority groups included in the report are: Pakistani, Bangladeshi, black African, Gujarati Hindu, Punjabi Sikh and black Caribbean.

This research is intended to be used by obesity/health weight teams within primary care trusts but is also of use to those involved in the commissioning or implementation of initiatives aimed at encouraging funding to improve the diet and increase levels of activity of families.

Topics discussed in the report include:

  • The National Marketing Strategy
  • Attitudes to health, weight and parenting
  • Attitudes and behaviours relating to healthy eating
  • Attitudes and behaviours relating to physical activity
  • How families differ: segmentatiion of families of children aged 2-10
  • Implications for local program design
  • Recommendations for communicating about diet and activity
  • Future work

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Hepatitis B incidence among south Asian children in England and Wales: implications for immunisation policy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
This article discusses the implications for a UK immunisation policy for hepatitis B (HBV) after analysing the level of incidence amongst south Asian children.

Acute HBV infections and risk factors reported by laboratories in England and Wales between 1st January 1988 and 31st December 2000 were analysed.   

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Hepatitis C in ethnic minority populations in England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study investigated the differing epidemiology of hepatitis C-related end-stage liver disese in ethnic minorities of black African, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Indian and Chinese origin in England.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome: infrequent bleeding and first report of Turkish and Pakistani kindreds
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,BLOOD DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome (HPS) is a rare disorder, this retrospective study investigates the clinical and haematoligical features of 23 cases of HPS.

Patient notes were reviewed and direct interviews were conducted with children of Pakistani and Turkish origin.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Hindu birth customs
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION]]>
document.body:
Many expectant mothers have fears and anxieties about their pregnancy. For Hindu pregnant women, these general concerns may be compounded by difficulties in communicating with healthcare professionals. This paper aims to provide clinicians with a basic understanding of Hindu birth customs to facilitate provision of culturally competent and sensitive care.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: HIV prevention among black Africans in England: a complex challenge
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,HIV/AIDS,SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,PREVENTION,INFECTIONS,MICROORGANISM,VIRUSES,HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS (HIV)]]>
document.body:
This better health briefing (number 13) has the following key messages:

  • The highest reported and undiagnosed heterosexually acquired HIV prevalence is amongst black African communities in England
  • The majority of black Africans in England are tested for HIV very late; a lot of cases have a high viral load and are unable to fully benefit from treatment.
  • The are more same-sex relationships than reported among black Africans in England.
  • The sexual health of black African communities in England is dependent upon diverse socioeconomic factors.
  • There are many unmet social and sexual health needs among black African communities in England.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 'Home from home': risk perceptions, malaria and the use of chemoprophylaxis among UK south Asians
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES]]>
document.body:
An average of 2,000 cases of malaria are reported in the UK each year with an over representation of ethnic minority patients.  This study examines the adherence to chemoprophylaxis among UK south Asians travelling to malarial regions in South Asia and East Africa.

Interviews using a questionnaire investigating the use of malaria prophylaxis, knowledge of malaria, risk perceptions and reasons for inadequate adherence to chemoprophylaxis, were conducted with 400 south Asians, with 200 interviews conducted in 1994 and 200 interviews conducted in 2004.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Hospice or home? Expectations of end-of-life care among white and Chinese older people in the UK.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body:
Full reference:  Seymour J, Payne S, Chapman A, Holloway M.  Hospice or home? Expectations of end-of-life care among white and Chinese older people in the UK.  Sociol Health Illn. 2007 Sep;29(6):872-90.

Accessing the full text:
NHS staff in England: available via NLH http://www.library.nhs.uk/Default.aspx
Other NHS staff: Check with your local NHS library http://www.hlisd.org/

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: How can health promotion interventions be adapted for minority ethnic communities? Five principles for guiding the development of behavioural interventions
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
Interventions adapted for minority ethnic communities are often termed "culturally sensitive" however the understanding of strategies for adapting behavioural interventions to minority ethnic communities is limited at best.   This systematic review investigates interventions for preventing coronary heart disease (CHD) including healthier diets, smoking cessation and promoting physical activity in Pakistani, Chinese and Indian communities in countries where they are the minority.

23,477 titles and abstracts were identified using electronic databases and key websites of these 17 papers met inclusion and quality criteria. Using the results of the systematic review the authors identified five principles for adapting behavioural interventions for minority ethnic communities.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: How does ethnicity affect the association between obesity and diabetes?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This paper examines the utility of body mass index, waist circumference and waist-to-height ratio in assessing diabetes risk across US White, US Black, Mexican American, English White, English Black, Bangladeshi, Pakistani, Indian or Chinese groups.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: How experiences and attitudes relating to female circumcision vary according to age on arrival in Britain: a study among young Somalis in London.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN]]>
document.body:
This study examines the association between age on arrival in the UK and experience of and attitudes relating to female circumcision among young, single Somalis living in London.

Quantitative data was obtained from 94 females and 80 males aged 16-22 living in Greater London.  Qualitative data was collected from 10 females and 10 males.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: How fair is Britain? equality, human rights and good relations in 2010
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,POLICY,SERVICE SECTORS,QUALITY AND MONITORING,INEQUALITIES,PUBLIC HEALTH,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,STATISTICS,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Although there have been great strides in combating disadvantage and discrimination over the past 40 years, the real world still falls short of the ideals of equality.  This review aims to provide an authoritative compilation of the available evidence about equalities in England, Scotland and Wales against 40 indicators agreed by the Equality and Human Rights Commission, the government and key institutions.

The review includes:

  • Foreword
  • A new landscape
  • Critical issues facing Britain today
  • Findings and challenges
  • Appendices

The executive summary and supporting evidence are also available to download.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: How physically active are south Asians in the United Kingdom?: a literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DIABETES]]>
document.body:

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 'I didn't do it cause I wanted a baby'
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,BIRTH]]>
document.description: sexual decision making, roles and choices in relation to early parenthood amongst black and minority ethnic young parents in England
document.body:
This study investigates sexual decision making amongst black and minority ethnic parents in relation to early parenthood.

Data was collected using focus groups and semi-structured interviews. 88 young people, 10 mothers of the young people and 41 service providers were included in the study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 'I don't see any point in telling them': attitudes to sharing genetic information in the family and carrier testing of relatives among British Pakistani adults referred to a genetics clinic.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SHARED DECISION MAKING,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This paper looks at factors that facilitate or can impede the sharing of genetic information within a sample of British Pakistani families.

Participant observation and interviews were conducted with 66 families of Pakistani origin referred to a genetics clinic in Southern England.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 'I got pregnant, I was so like...crying inside...': experiences of women of Pakistani ancestry seeking contraception in the UK
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study focused on the experience of Muslim women of Pakistani ancestry in accessing services and the views of health and community workers with contraceptive services.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 'I had to cry': exploring sexual health with young separated asylum seekers in East London
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,OTHER]]>
document.body:
Concerns have been raised about the sexual health and exploitation of young asylum seekers in the UK; this study aims to find ways to improve the situation.

In-depth interviews and small focus groups were carried out with 17 young and unaccompanied asylum seekers. In-depth interviews were also carried out with 10 health professionals working in the borough of Hackney, East London.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 'I know about one treatment where they keep the egg somewhere': British South Asian community understandings of infertility and its treatment
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This paper discusses some findings from the study of ethnicity and infertility carried out in the UK, which explored the experience of infertility in British south Asian communities.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: I know he controls cancer: the meanings of religion among Black Caribbean and White British patients with advanced cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION]]>
document.body:
Previous research has provided evidence that religion and spirituality can affect psychosocial adjustment to cancer; this study looks at the role of religion and spirituality among black and minority ethnic patients with cancer in the UK.

Semi-structured interviews were carried out with 26 Black Caribbean and 19 White British cancer patients living in South London. Christianity is the only religion referred to in the artcle.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Immunogenicity of routine vaccination against diphtheria, tetanus, and Haemophilus influenzae type b in Asian infants born in the United Kingdom
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This study aims to determine the immunogenicity of routine vaccination against diptheria, tetanus and Haemophilis influenzae b (Hib) in Asian infants born in the UK, and whether maternal antibody supression occurs.

A cohort study with 80% power, with 95% confidence limits of 34 south Asian infants enrolled at two general practices in Reading was conducted.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Impact of a cardiovascular risk control project for south Asians (Khush Dil) on motivation, behaviour, obesity, blood pressure and lipids
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
In 2002 Khush Dil was set up to measure CVD risk factors in south Asians. An in-service evaluation using 140 subjects assessed its impact.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Impact of Ramadan fasting on renal allograft function
document.publisher: The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
Fasting during Ramadan is a religious duty for all healthy adult Muslims. This study aims to find the effect of Ramadan fasting on allograft function.

19 kidney transplant recipitants who voluntary chose to fast during Ramadan where compared with 20 recipitants who had not fasted for 3 years.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Implementation of universal newborn bloodspot screening for sickle cell disease and other clinically significant haemoglobinopathies in England: screening results for 2005-7
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,ETHNICITY LINKED DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
A report on the early results of the National Health Service Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia screening programme.

Screening results from April 2005 and March 2007 are presented, which include data from almost 1.2 million infants.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving consultations in general practice for Somali patients: a qualitative study
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This paper looked at the benefits patients of the Somali community perceived in receiving a personalised audio recording of information in their own language as a reminder of the advice they had been given during their consultation with a health professional. ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving ethnic data collection for statistics of cancer incidence, management, mortality and survival in the UK
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ A systematic review of ethnic data collection for statistics of cancer incidence that also includes, a health professionals perception of ethnic data collection, the views of a patient focus group consisting of members of ethnic minorities that are members of community centres and places of worship and a look at groups who are actively looking at how to collect and use ethnicity data. Recommendations are also provided.  ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving ethnocultural competence of hospital staff by training: experiences from the European 'Migrant-friendly Hospitals' project
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,DOCTORS,NURSES,SERVICE SECTORS,SECONDARY / HOSPITAL CARE]]>
document.body:
One of the most widespread measures to deal with ethnocultural diversity in healthcare seems to be cultural competence training for staff. This paper presents experiences from hospitals in 8 states of the European Union.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving health and social care support for carers from black and minority ethnic communities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Key messages from this 'Better Health' briefing (number 20) include:

  • Structural disadvantage and the marginilisation of 'race equality' within social policy compounds already inadequate support for black and minority ethnic carers
  • The black and minority ethnic voluntary sector has a key role in aiding carers from black and minority ethnic backgrounds
  • The diversity between and within communities is often overlooked because of the assumption that black and minority ethnic carers are an homogenous group
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving health care quality for racial/ethnic minorities: a systematic review of the best evidence regarding provider and organization interventions
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY]]>
document.body:
A systematic literature review to synthesize the findings of controlled studies that evaluate interventions targeted at health care providers to improve quality of health care for ethnic minorities.

Literature was searched form 1980 to June 2003 to identify relevant randomised controlled trials and concurrent controlled trials.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving interpreting in clinical communication: models of feasible practice from the European project 'Migrant-friendly Hospitals'
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,SECONDARY / HOSPITAL CARE,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Migrant populations and ethnic minority groups who are non-local language speakers often cannot communicate effectively enough with their clinicians to receive the necessary information about their care.

This paper presents a report from 9 European hospitals who developed, implemented and evaluated professional interpreter services to improve communication between non-local language speakers and clinical staff.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving pathways into mental health care for black and ethnic minority groups: a systematic review of the grey literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,VOLUNTARY AND COMMUNITY SECTOR]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Black and ethnic minority (BME) patients often rely on third sector and non-statutory sector services to provide pathways in and out of care.  These organisations often provide information on how to best serve BME groups, improve access to services and develop innovative methods to improve pathways to recovery; however very little of this information is published through formal channels.  This paper systematically reviews this 'grey literature' to identify keys areas that can aid practice.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving patients: getting lifestyle advice to Asian patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
A section of the Improving Patients bulletin that concerns improving communication between the cardiac rehabilitation team at New Cross Hospital and their Asian patients.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving the quality of palliative care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
The Key messages from this Better Health Briefing (Number 1) are:

 

  • Palliative care is mainly used by people with cancer
  • Access to palliative care can be restricted by a lack of understanding amongst professionals about appropriate referral criteria
  • Use of palliative care services can be adversely affected by misunderstanding or fears about death and dying
  • People with life-limiting illnesses who do not speak English or Welsh face significant difficulties in communicating with professionals in palliative care
  • There are no national standards for the training of palliative care professionals in transcultural care
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Improving uptake of breast screening in multiethnic populations: a randomised controlled trial using practice reception staff to contact non-attenders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
An investigation into whether a two hour training program for GP reception staff could improve uptake of patients who had previously failed to attend breast screening. The study also looked at whether all ethnic groups benefited equally.

A randomised control trial in the London borough of Newham was conducted involving 2064 women aged 50-64 years who had previously failed to attend breast screening. Ethnic groups included in the study were: white (37%), Indian (17%), Pakistani (10%), black (14%), Bangladeshi (6%), Chinese (1%) and of other ethnic groups (4%). 16% of participants did not report their ethnicity.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Including culturally diverse samples in health research: a case study of an urban trial of social support.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
This study describes the recruitment procedures of an ethnically diverse sample between 1999 and 2001 in a study of social support and familiy health in a disadvantaged urban area of the UK.

 

731 out of 1,263 eligible women were successfully recruited to the study.  45 languages other than English were spoken by the participants, 14% needed an interpreter and 30% spoke English as a second language.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Increasing response rates amongst black and minority ethnic and seldom heard groups: a review of literature relevant to the national acute patients' survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,GETTING INFORMATION,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This report prepared by the Picker Institute Europe on behalf of the Healthcare Commission presents the findings of a literature review on increasing survey response rates amongst black and minority ethnic and seldom heard groups.

While response rates for the NHS inpatient surveys are relatively high for a postal survey (59% in 2005), response rates amongst young people and black and minority ethnic groups remain low.  The review identifies a range of difficulties when trying to include certain groups in health postal surveys.

The report includes:

  • Executive summary
  • Introduction
  • Context of the review
  • Why do variations in response rates matter?
  • Why are response rates lower amongst certain groups?
  • Strategies for increasing response rates amongst black and minority ethnic and seldom heard groups
  • Measuring the impact of strategies for increasing response rates amongst black and minority ethnic and seldom heard groups
  • The implications of this review for the acute patients survey
  • Appendices
  • References

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Increasing response rates amongst black and minority ethnic and seldom heard groups: report of a consultation with stakeholders on increasing response rates to the national inpatients survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This report is a summary of a consultation with stakeholders about increasing response rates amongst black and minority ethnic (BME) and seldom heard groups in the NHS acute inpatient survey.  The consultation was conducted by the Picker Institute on behalf of the Healthcare Commission.

The report includes:

  • Introduction
  • The stakeholder consultation
  • Thematic analysis of comments made during the consultation
  • Recommendations
  • Appendices
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Indications of public health in the English regions: ethnicity and health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY]]>
document.body:
This report, the fourth in the series provides a widespread regional analysis of existing inequalities in health and health care between ethnic groups in England.

The report includes:

  • Executive summary
  • Introduction and background
  • Ethnic monitoring: how good is it?
  • The distribution of ethnic minority communities across the regions
  • Determinants of health indicators
  • Population health status indicators
  • Priority public health intervention indicators
  • Effectiveness of partnership indicators
  • Patient experience and workforce indicators
  • References
  • Appendices
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Indigenous ethnic minorities and palliative care: exploring the views of Irish Travellers and palliative care staff
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,GYPSIES AND TRAVELLERS]]>
document.body:
An investigation into Irish travellers views and experiences of specialist palliative care and the knowledge and experience that palliative care professionals have of Irish travellers.

A mixed approach of qualitative and quantitative methods was used in the study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Inequalities experienced by Gypsy and Traveller communities: a review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,GYPSIES AND TRAVELLERS]]>
document.body:
This review draws together evidence from a wide range of gypsies' and travellers' experiences to set out clearly the full extent of the inequalities and discrimination they face.  The review of existing evidence provides a basis to address these inequalities.

The review includes:

  • Executive summary
  • Introduction
  • Accommodation and employment
  • Health, substance abuse and self-harm
  • Education, early years and children's experiences
  • Social work and domestic violence
  • Criminal justice and legal services
  • Political participation, community cohesion and religion
  • Wales and Scotland
  • Racism, human rights, gender, age, disability and sexual orientation
  • Conclusion
  • References
  • Appendices
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Inequalities in maternal health: national cohort study of ethnic variation in severe maternal morbidities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,SECONDARY / HOSPITAL CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This study aims to describe on a national basis ethnic differences in severe maternal morbidity in the UK.

A national cohort study with 686 participants was conducted using the UK Obstetric Surveillance System (UKOSS). All hospitals with consultant led maternity units were included in the study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Inequalities in rates of gonorrhoea and chlamydia between black ethnic groups in south east London: cross sectional study.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES]]>
document.body:
This cross sectional study examines differences in population based rates of gonorrhoea and chlamydia amongst black ethnic groups in Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham health authorities.

Records of episodes of gonorrhoea and chlamydia between 1st January 1994 and 31st December 1995 were retrieved from 11 genitourinary clinics in south and central London. Yearly incidence rates were calculated for residents of Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Inequalities in reported use of breast and cervical screening in Great Britain: analysis of cross sectional survey data
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This study investigates the relationship between reported use of breast and cervical screening services by women and sociodemographic characteristics.

A cross sectional multipurpose survey was conducted with 3185 women aged 40-74 years.

The study found that white British women are significantly more likely to have a cervical smear than women from other ethnic groups.

CEEHD Note: The results from this study cannot be generalised to all minority ethnic groups: the data were insufficient to distinguish between minority groups.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Infant care practices related to cot death in Turkish and Moroccan families in the Netherlands
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,WOMEN]]>
document.body:
cot death risk compared to Dutch infants. In contrast Moroccan infants had a risk of cot death that was approximately three times lower compared to Dutch infants during the same period. This study shows that these differences have disappeared, while differences still exist in infant care practices between these ethnic groups. At 28 well-baby clinics, questionnaires were distributed for this sample selection. The response was 82%. Data were collected on 55 Turkish, 54 Moroccan, and 210 Dutch families.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Infertility counseling for Orthodox Jewish couples
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body:
An examination of traditional Jewish concepts and practices of reproduction that also aims to define problems that may arise in infertility treatment for Orthodox Jewish people who follow the Jewish codes of conduct (Halachah).

Orthodox and Ultraorthodox (Haredi) Jewish couples being treated at an academic-affiliated fertility clinic situated in an observant Jewish community were included in the study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Infertility issues for south Asian women
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This article presents a discussion of some of the social, medical and psychological issues surrounding infertility for women who come from a south Asian background.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Inflammatory markers and growth in south Asian and European origin infants in Britain: the Manchester children's growth and vascular health study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This study tests the hypothesis that circulating C-reactive protein (CRP) and interleukin 6 (IL 6) is higher in healthy British born infants of south Asian origin than in infants of European origin in the first two years of life.

South Asian (n=74) and European (n=129) infants were followed prospectively from birth.

The study concludes that south Asian infants aged two years and under have significantly lower CRP compared with European infants of the same age and that inflammatory markers are not useful indicators of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in infants of two years and under with such markers not being as elevated as expected in south Asian infants.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: A later study investigating the emergence of ethnic differences in blood pressure during adolescence and resulting links to CVD is available here.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Influence of moving to the UK on maternal health behaviours: prospective cohort study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study compared health behaviours during pregnancy (smoking and alcohol consumption) and after birth (initiation and duration of breast feeding) between British/Irish White mothers and mothers from ethnic minority groups of Pakistani, Bangladeshi, Black, Black Caribbean, Indian or mixed background.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Influence of practices' ethnicity and deprivation on access to angiography: an ecological study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Past studies from primary care have found reduced access to angiography for lower social class groups, this study looks at the influence of ethnicity and social deprivation on access to angiography in general practice.

An ecological study measuring ethnicity and socioeconomic status in 143 general practices in East London, UK was carried out.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Influences of ethnicity on perinatal and child mortality in the Netherlands
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,WOMEN]]>
document.body:
An investigation into the differences in child mortality and perinatal death between different ethnic groups in the Netherlands.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on data collected between 1990 and 1993 in the national obstetric registry which comprised of 569, 743 birth certificates and death certificates of 0 to 15 year olds collected between 1979 and 1993 comprising 20, 211 deaths.

CEEHD Note: This study was conducted in the Netherlands

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Inhaler technique in Turkish people with poor English: a case of information discrimination?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION]]>
document.body:
A comparison of metered dose inhaler (MDI) technique between users with poor English and users with fluent English. Two interventions were also compared: a translated patient information leaflet with support from an interpreter and a mulitmedia touch screen system.

105 fluent English speakers and 69 Turkish speakers with poor English were included in the study. From the group with poor English 34 participants received the multimedia system intervention and 35 received the patient information leaflet plus interpreter intervention.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Innovative methodologies: can we learn from including people with dementia from south Asian communities?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ South Asian people with dementia are routinely excluded from literature concentrating on service use or the experience of living with dementia.  This paper examines methods used by a study that aimed to find ways to make contact with south Asian people with dementia and discover why they are excluded from research on service use or the experience of living with dementia.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Interactions between a deaf child for whom English is an additional language and his specialist teacher in the first year at school: combining words and gestures
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,OTHER]]>
document.body:
A description of the interactions between a nursery-aged prelingually deaf child from a Somali speaking family where English is an additional language and his specialist teacher.

The interactions were recorded at four consecutive time points during the first year at school.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Intercultural palliative care: do we need cultural competence?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Detailed engagement with models of cultural competence is comparatively recent in palliative care nursing. This article presents the findings from a development project on elders and carers from 'minority ethnic' groups, funded by the Department of Health, to increase awareness of palliative care and to improve understanding of the needs of these groups of service users.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Intergenerational continuities of ethnic inequalities in general health in England
document.publisher: Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Although previous research suggests that ethnic minority groups are more likely to suffer a poorer health profile than the general population, it is still unclear whether these inequalities pass through subsequent generations. This study aims to discover to what degree if any ethnic inequalities are passed from the first generation to the second.

Data from the 1999 and 2004 health surveys for England was used to identify 4,492 first generation and 5,729 second generation members of six ethnic minority populations. 18,407 surveyed people of white ethnicity were selected as a reference group.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Interpretation & Language Support
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY]]>
document.description: In an article contributed to SLEH National Knowledge Weed, Jan Cambridge of the National Register of Public Interpreters examines the risks of poor communication in healthcare.
document.body:
111-1Interpretation & Language Support

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2007

Jan Cambridge
M.C.I.L, M.A., R.P.S.I.

Former Chair,
National Register of Public Interpreters

Language Support in the NHS

(Return to Knowledge Week index page)

We all know that language is fundamental to communication.  Language support is fundamental to communication between healthcare providers and people of non-English-speaking background (NESB, in Australian) who may have low English-speaking proficiency (LEP). Most of us now know that such support ought to be provided by trained and qualified, specialist linguists (as was highlighted in the enquiry following the death of Victoria Climbié). This does not negate the need for a personal support system to be present where available and appropriate.

Both patient and clinician still need an interpreter, and the patient still needs written information in an appropriate form.  That form may actually be audio media, rather than paper based, especially where there is no written form of the person’s strongest language, as is the case for Mirpuri, Sylhetti, or Roma.  Indeed, the Jamaican language has hitherto not had a written form, although work is being done to develop one at the University of the West Indies Jamaica Language Unit, (reference 8 below). Nevertheless, this project is currently aimed at resolving procedural difficulties in Courts and police stations in Jamaica, and the Cassidy-le-Page writing system is also being taught by the Jamaica 2000 (J2K) project in Birmingham.

While there is a growing body of evidence already represented on the SLEH, NHS policy on language support is vague as to how and by whom support services should be provided. If we are going to develop coherent and safe services for all our “LEP” populations and their healthcare providers, we need to consider what evidence there is and ensure that as much of it as possible is readily available.  There are models overseas we could usefully consider copying or adapting. For example, Sydney’s hospitals have a 70% uptake of interpreter services among culturally and linguistically diverse people, because clinical staff are bound by State policy to offer the service.  Consent forms, for example, must have a sticker showing that an interpreter was present in order to be valid.  People may phone the Service Provider and request that an interpreter is booked to accompany them to a consultation.  In New South Wales, the word “interpreter” is defined as someone registered with NAATI (reference 5), and it is only “interpreters” who figure in state policy. Ghazala Mir (4) points out the need for clear and comprehensive policies in terms of language support. 

"No patients within our sample were offered interpreting support or made aware that this was available." Mir G (2003).

We also need to think about translation of information materials, and their most appropriate form. Some cultures are used to transferring information orally; others are not. There is very little evidence on best practice, but most NHS information providers rely on ‘back-translation’ (asking someone to translate back into English) as the only check on a translation. Back translation is seen by professional linguists as a very expensive and unreliable way of producing other language written text.

Standards are crucial and benchmarks are key to those. The government has produced work on standards in interpreting and translating, as well as in working across cultures (CILT 2005 and others 2).  The interpreter standards have been available for some time and can be accessed at the CILT site (Bancroft 2005 1).

A recent issue of the journal Diversity in Health & Social Care carries a salutary paper on the need to influence policy regarding use of professional interpreters (Irshad 2007 3). Its discussion brings to mind research for the DfES, which included figures on how long it takes a learner to achieve ‘A’-level standard in English from a standing start (Schellekens 2001 7).

Readers may find it useful to refer also to the National Qualifications Framework (6) to gain some idea of what that level means in practice. Many are surprised to learn what a speaker can reasonably be expected to be capable of, in terms of understanding and making themselves understood, with that level of a foreign language.

Key stakeholders in the field are beginning to discuss the possibility of professional and clinical standards for provision of language support and it to be hoped that SLEH will be able to report on new research and guidance during the coming year.

References and Resources

  1. Bancroft, M. (2005) The Interpreter's World Tour. An Environmental Scan of Standards of Practice for Interpreters. IN NCIHC (Ed.), The California Endowment.  Can be seen as a 54 page pdf.

  2. CILT (2005) National Standards in Interpreting. London, The National Centre for Languages, (CILT), National Occupational Standards in Languages, Interpreting, Translation and Intercultural Skills.  View at the CILT website.

  3. Irshad, Tasneem; Worth, Allison; Sheikh, Aziz. (2007) 'Are translation and interpretation services a necessity or a luxury?' in Diversity in Health & Social Care Vol 4,2 pp. 87-89(3).  Available through IngentaConnect.

  4. Mir G (2003). Communication, Knowledge and Chronic Illness in Pakistani Communities (RCET177). The Research Findings Register.

  5. NAATI  -  National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters

  6. QCA National Qualifications Framework. Qualification and Curriculum Authority (QCA).The regulatory body for public examinations and publicly funded qualifications

  7. Schellekens, P. (2001) English Language as a Barrier to Employment, Education and Training. London, DfEE

  8. University of the West Indies, Jamaican Language Unit 

Other Useful Links

www.dhi.gov.au/clearinghouse multicultural health information
www.dhi.gov.au/tmhc Transcultural Mental Health Centre (NSW)
www.mmha.org.au Multicultural Mental Health Australia

]]>

Diabetes is four times more common amongst ethnic minority groups than the general population. This study looks at the specific issues of engaging people and evaluating interventions by using wriiten questionnaires with older ethnic minority groups.

An evaluation of an adapted verion of the X-PERT patient program was carried out using questionnaires and interviews.

]]>

document.body:
This study aimed to increase the uptake of breast screening by ethnic minority patients in three inner city GP practices.

Interventions, identification of ethnic language groups, GP endorsement letters, translated literature and language support were used to increase attendance.

]]>

]]>

document.title: Involving south Asian patients in clinical trials

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Iron deficiency anaemia in women of south Asian descent: a qualitative study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,BLOOD DISORDERS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN]]>
document.body:
Menorrhagia is considered to be the most common cause of iron deficiency anaemia in women of reproductive age living in the UK.  It has been suggested however that the high prevalence of this condition in south Asian women is due to religious and cultural restrictions on certain foods.  This qualitative study explores possible reasons for this high prevalence in south Asian women.

Semi-structured interviews were conducted with women of Indian and Pakistani descent living in a town in North West England.  

]]>

document.title: Is there equity of service delivery and intermediate outcomes in south Asians with type 2 diabetes? Analysis of DARTS database and summary of UK publications
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,SERVICE DELIVERY]]>
document.body:
With doubts being cast about whether diabetes care is equitable across UK ethnic groups, this study examined processes and outcomes in south Asians with diabetes and also reviewed relevant UK literature.

Name search methods were used to identify south Asians in a regional diabetes database. Prevalence rates, processes and outcomes of care were measured between November 2003 and December 2004. Standard literature search techniques were used for the literature review.

]]>

CEEHD Note: This editorial is intended for a US audience and some findings may not transfer to UK practice.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: This is a US study and some findings may not transfer to UK practice.

  • Gender identitiy

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Long-term ill health, poverty and ethnicity
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH LONG TERM & CHRONIC CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This better health briefing (Number 8) has the following key messages:

  • The social and economic consequences of long-term ill health are greatest for deprived groups and certain minority ethnic groups. These groups face the highest rates of long-term ill health and worklessness and are also most marginalised from support services

  • Coping with and managing a long-term health condition is strongly affected by the family and household context. But health and welfare services often focus only on the individual, which can be problematic for patients and their family members

  • Social support is key in helping people to come to terms with and manage a long-term health condition. However, many long-term sick people find it hard to maintain their usual social contact and face difficulties in participating in group-based interventions

  • Although many long-term sick people do want to work, policies and services aimed at encouraging people into employment can be problematic as work can impact negatively on their health. Caring obligations create conflicting priorities within households

  • The take-up of sickness-related benefits among eligible people is low, particularly for minority ethnic groups. For many people, the benefits system is experienced as complex, unpredictable and stressful. Wider access to specialist support is required.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Mapping rapidly changing minority ethnic populations: a case study of York
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING]]>
document.body:
The minority ethnic population of the UK is continually growing with rapid growth in some cities and rural areas.  York has been identified as one of the cities in which this rapid growth is taking place.  This is a report of a project that used a range of research techniques and data sources to map the ethnic minority population of York.

The report includes:

  • List of tables and figures
  • Executive summary
  • Background to the project
  • A brief history of minority ethnic settlement in York
  • Methodology: how the research was approached
  • Quantitative data
  • Qualitative data
  • Conclusions and recommendations
  • References
  • Appendices
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Mental health of refugee children
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,OUTCOMES,EDUCATION,EDUCATION,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,POPULATIONS,SETTINGS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,CHILDREN,YOUNG PEOPLE,MENTAL & BEHAVIOURAL DISORDERS,DEPRESSION,POST TRAUMATIC STRESS,ETHNICITY,LANGUAGE,DISADVANTAGED GROUPS,ETHNIC GROUPS,GEOGRAPHY,INTERNATIONAL ISSUES,GOVERNMENT & LAW,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,LAW,SERVICE PROVISION,EDUCATIONAL SETTINGS,SCHOOLS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ The UK is facing a major increase in the number of people seeking<SUP> </SUP>asylum each year, of whom approximately a quarter are children.<SUP> </SUP>The stressors to which refugees are exposed are described in<SUP> </SUP>three stages: (1) while in their country of origin; (2) during<SUP> </SUP>their flight to safety; and (3) when having to settle in a country<SUP> </SUP>of refuge. The evidence concerning the impact of displacement<SUP> </SUP>on children’s mental health is reviewed and a framework<SUP> </SUP>for conceptualising the risk factors is proposed. The available<SUP> </SUP>literature shows consistently increased levels of psychological<SUP> </SUP>morbidity among refugee children, especially post-traumatic<SUP> </SUP>stress disorder, depression, and anxiety disorders. The principles<SUP> </SUP>underlying the delivery of mental health care for these children<SUP> </SUP>are also considered. It is argued that much primary prevention<SUP> </SUP>can be undertaken in the school context. Some key aspects of<SUP> </SUP>British immigration law are examined and the tension between<SUP> </SUP>the law and the best interests of the child principle is discussed.<SUP> </SUP>There is particular concern for the plight of unaccompanied<SUP> </SUP>children. Attention to the mental health needs of this vulnerable<SUP> </SUP>group is urgently required.]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
The primary focus of this report is on surveillance data from England, Wales and Northern Ireland for 2004 on non-UK born cases of a number of infectious diseases. It is important to note that many migrants to the UK are at no greater risk of infectious diseases than the UK born population.

The report aims to provide a resource to health professionals and those with an interest in migrant health, there is also background information on migration to the UK and the general health needs of migrants; the report also makes recommendations for public health action to improve the health of migrant communities.

Throughout the report the term "migrant" is used in line with United Nations (UN) definitions.

Topics discussed include:

  • An introduction to migration and migrant health
  • Tuberculosis
  • HIV
  • Hepatitis B
  • Malaria
  • Other Infections
  • Key British legislation affecting migrants
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Minorities within minorities: beneath the surface of south Asian participation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Looking at the South Asian community in Bradford, this project researches participation issues and explores how identity affects people’s ability to voice their concerns, within their own communities and to statutory agencies.

Drawing on interviews and participant observation in Bradford and focusing on issues such as culture, place of origin, sexuality, mental health and disability the report highlights some key issues for service providers and also for the south Asian community itself.

Key findings from the report include:

  • The south Asian minority community is not homogenous: recognising this could help foster positive social change and equity
  • Formal mechanisms for participation can often reproduce social barriers to participation
  • Existing forms for minority participation do not enable minorities within minorities to be heard and resources allocated to meet their needs
  • Organisations which are genuinely embedded amongst the minorities in question could be effective partners for meeting their needs
  • Commissioned research on minorities within minorities is not always translated into action, which can lead to frustration

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Moving from ‘Delivering Race Equality’ to public mental health: a policy update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
111-1Moving from ‘Delivering Race Equality’ to public mental health: a policy update

Written for the 'ethnicity and health' Annual Evidence Update 2009

 

Professor Kamaldeep Bhui
MD FRCPsych

Professor of Cultural Psychiatry & Epidemiology
Wolfson Institute of Preventive Medicine
Queen Mary University of London

 

 

Return to index page

The Delivering Race Equality (DRE) programme (refs 1, 2) in England is coming to an end in 2010, and is already being absorbed as a part of the broader equalities programme.  The original aspirations still need to be championed because they remain highly relevant.  However, there is as yet no universal agreement that a separate race equality strand or policy is appropriate.  This uncertainty remains even though, to date, integrated equalities and mental health policies have not included sufficient detail, resources, or priority to successfully address ethnic inequalities.


Recent developments
Several recent developments relevant to mental health policy need to be recognised.

Firstly, the evidence base is being advanced proactively. A policy review of inequalities in health care is now underway under the leadership of Professor Sir Michael Marmot (ref 3). This surely will at long last adequately address ethnic inequalities and their interaction with other characteristics (refs 4, 5) by which power and status and wealth – and hence also health, are patterned.

Secondly, the National Service Framework for Mental Health has come to an end, and New Horizons (ref 6) is now promoted as the way forward. This takes a dramatically different approach, emphasising preventive actions at various stages of the life course to effectively avoid the development of health problems, including mental illness. Preventive interventions are often complex in nature. Those showing the most promise include interventions targeting schools (ref 7), parents of school children and parents to be, the populations at risk of physical and sexual violence, and violence in general (ref 8), people with at-risk social circumstances and at-risk mental states, and people at risk because of family histories and perhaps having one or more at risk social or mental state characteristics. Evidence is now required on the effectiveness of such preventive interventions in addressing the needs of ethnic minority populations. The proposed work around transitions from child and adolescent services to adult services is welcome, as is the vision that mental health literacy and self management skills will improve over time, although both will need to address ethnic inequalities. There is also no clarity on how secondary care services will improve quality of care to all populations, irrespective of their minority status.

Thirdly, although there are specific actions which seek to manage stigma and discrimination in the community, there is still insufficient attention given to ethnic inequalities in health status and service experience (ref 9). There is a reality to the everyday difficulties caused by mental distress and a need to critically evaluate ‘recovery models’ and the ‘social model’ of illness that at times verges on denying the presence of disabilities whilst engaging in an anti-psychiatry prejudice that seems out of place in modern, multidisciplinary NHS services. Thus, well intentioned moves to promote greater opportunity for recovery and well being for all may further compound social exclusion of people who suffer with disabling mental ill health. There are also many necessary adjustments needed in the workplace to optimise employment opportunities for people with mental illness.


Future Needs
New Horizons (ref 5) currently lacks substance and detail on what the balance of priorities will be between services, public mental health, social interventions and social policy. Indeed, if we are to take the ‘social model’ of health seriously, successful rehabilitation and preventive action should (for example) include teaching at-risk people about financial self-management as well as social and interpersonal skills. Also, if the work does not include special targeted provisions for the most needy and disempowered, the new policy will simply increase inequalities as those least able to benefit previously will lag behind even further compared with those who make best use of public mental health interventions. Adjustments are needed in society, as well as in health and social care, to ensure equal opportunity and successful living in communities.

As NHS Evidence and the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) aspire to unite the approaches and evidence bases of both health and social care traditions, these are realities that need to be addressed explicitly in the area of mental health. There is, however, no mention in the new policy of the aspirations of those living with mental illness to live without discrimination, or of institutional or structural racism, or of the significant evidence base that suggests ethnic inequalities warrant remedial attention (see additional resources below).

The challenge now will be how best to support commissioners, as well as those working in social care, to make use of the developing evidence base on ethnicity and mental health in order to guard against (and even reverse) any possible trends towards increased inequalities, in the light of the new public mental health agenda. Above all we need commitment, considered and well informed policy and service development, and highly skilled workforces that are equipped with the evidence and knowledge to make a difference to the lives of people living with mental distress.

 

References

  1. Department of Health. (2005). Delivering Race Equality in Mental Health Care: A Summary. An action plan for services - A model for reform. London: Department of Health.
    [view details]

     
  2. Department of Health. (2005). Delivering race equality in mental health care: an action plan for reform inside and outside services and the Government’s response to the independent inquiry into the death of David Bennett. London: Department of Health.
    [view details]

     
  3. Post 2010 strategic review of health inequalities (the Marmot Review).
    [view details]

     
  4. Cooper, C., Morgan, C., Byrne, M., & P. Dazzan et al. (2008). Perceptions of disadvantage, ethnicity and psychosis. British Journal of Psychiatry. Vol. 192, pt. 3, pp. 185-90.
    [view details]

     
  5. McGuire, T., G., & J. Miranda. (2008). New evidence regarding racial and ethnic disparities in mental health: policy implications. Health Affairs. Vol. 27, pt. 2, pp. 393-403.
    [view details]

     
  6. Department of Health. (2009). New Horizons: Towards a shared vision for mental health. Consultation. London: Department of Health.
    [view details]

     
  7. Goodman, A., Patel, V., & D. A. Leon. (2008). Child mental health differences amongst ethnic groups in Britain: a systematic review. BMC Public Health. Vol. 8, pt. 258.
    [view details]

     
  8. Chandler – Oatts, J., & L. Nelstrop. (2008). Listening to the voices of African-Caribbean mental health service users to develop guideline recommendations on managing violent behaviour. Diversity in Health and Social Care. Vol. 5, pt. 1, pp. 31-41.
    [view details]

  9. Rudell, K., Bhui, K., & S. Priebe. (2008). Do 'alternative' help-seeking strategies affect primary care service use? A survey of help-seeking for mental distress. BMC Public Health. Vol. 11, pt. 8, pp. 207-.
    [view details]

 

Additional Resources

  • Ashton, L., & J. Moore. (2009). Guide to providing mental health care support to asylum seekers in primary care. London: Royal College of General Practitioners.
    [view details]

  • Bhui, K., S., & K. McKenzie. (2008). Rates and risk factors by ethnic group for suicides within a year of contact with mental health services in England and Wales. Psychiatric Services. Vol. 59, pt. 4, pp. 414-20.
    [view details]

  • Bowers, L., Simpson, A., Nijman, H., & C. Hall. (2008). Patient ethnicity and three psychiatric intensive care units compared: the Tompkins Acute Ward Study. Journal of Psychiatric and Mental Health Nursing. Vol. 15, pt. 3, pp. 195-202.
    [view details]
     
  • Shah, A. (2008). Estimating the absolute number of cases of dementia and depression in the black and minority ethnic elderly population in the United Kingdom.  International Journal of Migration Health and Social Care. Vol. 4, pt. 2, pp. 4-15.
    [view details]
     
  • Singh, S., P., et al. (2008). Black and minority ethnic people are more likely to be detained under the Mental Health Act 1983—no clear evidence why: a systematic review. Evidence Based Mental Health. Vol. 11, pt. 61.
    [view details]
     
  • Trusswell, D., & R. Bryant – Jeffries. (2009). Delivering race equality focused implementation site project 2005 - 2008: evaluation report. London: NHS: Central and North West London Foundation Trust.
    [view details] 
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Mtetezi: developing mental health advocacy with African and Caribbean men
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,PEOPLE WITH MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,OUTCOMES,MENTAL & BEHAVIOURAL DISORDERS,MEN,ETHNIC GROUPS,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,PUBLIC HEALTH,RACE EQUALITY,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,APRIL 2010]]>
document.body:
This knowledge review published by the Social Care Institute for Excellence has two elements:

  • A research review using research reports and service descriptions to establish what is known about the provision of mental health advocacy for African and Caribbean men.
  • A practice survey of organisations providing mental health advocacy to African and Caribbean men to establish what is currently being provided and what is needed. Focus groups conducted with African and Caribbean men and case studies involving two different localities were also used.

The result of the research review indicated that there is a significant gap in high quality evidence for mental health advocacy for African and Caribbean men and that there is a negative relationship between mental health services and African and Caribbean men. The research review also found serious gaps in advocacy provision for Black and Minority Ethnic (BME) communities as a whole.

The practice survey discovered that mental health advocacy for African and Caribbean men is commonly provided as an element of BME mental health services as a whole and that these services tend to be rooted in the community. The survey also discovered a lack of formal monitoring of ethnicity in mental health services so uptake of advocacy services by African and Caribbean men was hard to establish. There was a consensus drawn from the survey that advocacy is important for African and Caribbean men to feel they are being heard.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Multi-disciplinary/multi-agency partnerships across cultures: a health perspective
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Structure Of The Module

The module is made up of two overlapping sections:

Section one defines terms and legislation relating to users and carers involvement in social and health care development and delivery. It describes perceptions of family and paid carers and roles and responsibilities. It explains the role of the family in social and health care provision using examples from children's nursing.

Section two defines and sets the parameters for collaborative working, partnership and community involvement aspects of the module. It provides relevant literature to underpin these concepts and ways of working.

Some of the main features of the module include use of practical activities and memos aimed at helping the readers to grasp the key points considered in each subsection.

AIM AND LEARNING OUTCOMES

The Aim of the module is to increase sensitivity to cultural differences and encourage understanding of multidisciplinary / multi-agency partnerships across cultures.

On completion of the module the reader will be able to:

  • Identify and discuss needs of users and carers across cultures and communities as part of effective service delivery
  • Appraise partnership-working practices; their dimensions and their suitability in promoting cultural diversity in care delivery
  • Explore and debate the nature and types of collaborative working practices for social and health service planning in a diverse community
  • Discuss and analyse cultural influences on modes of advocacy and empowerment, recognising threats and opportunities in working; with and for minority groups
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Multi-language translation and cross-cultural adaptation of the OARSI/OMERACT measure of intermittent and constant osteoarthritis pain (ICOAP).
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,MUSCULOSKELETAL]]>
document.body:
A multi-language translation and cross cultural adaptation of the intermittent and constant osteoarthritis pain (ICOAP) questionnaire for use by patients with hip and knee osteoarthritis.

The translation process involved an independent translation by two or three persons, this was followed by a consensus meeting to decide upon a preliminary version of the translated questionnaire, a backwards translation back to English was then conducted; a final version was then produced by a multi-disciplinary consensus committee which was then pre-tested by 10-20 members of the target group.

The questionnaire was translated into the following languages: Czech, Dutch, French (France), German, Italian, Norwegian, Spanish (Castillan), North and Central American Spanish, Swedish. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: National Screening Committee policy - sickle cell disorders screening (in newborns)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,BLOOD DISORDERS]]>
document.description: The National Screening Committee's Policy on screening for sickle cell disorders (in newborns)
document.body:
111-1National Screening Committee policy - sickle cell disorders screening (in newborns)

[Compiled by the National Screening Committee, July 2006]

 

Sickle cell disorders

 

Population:
Neonatal

 

Primary test:
Blood spot

 

National Screening Committee Policy Position - July 2006*:

Screening for sickle cell disease is being introduced for all newborn babies in England. By April 2005 coverage was estimated at about 87%.

 

Considerations were based on two HTA reports on these diseases.

 

* This policy will be reviewed in 2007/8

 

Significant change since May 2005?

No

 

National Screening Programme

There is a NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme at Guy's, King's and St Thomas' School of Medicine

 

Evidence leading to Policy:

HTA 1999, :Vol 3, no. 11 "Antenatal and neonatal haemoglobinopathy screening in the UK: review and economic analysis"

 

HTA 2000, Vol 4, no. 3 "Screening for sickle cell disease and thalassaemia: a systematic review with supplementary research"

 

Child Health Subgroup Report December 2003

 

Wales: screening is not offered

 

Scotland: a National Resource Centre for Ethnic Minority Health (NCREMH) report is currently being considered by the Scottish Health Executive Dept and will inform the decision on Scottish policy in this area

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Nutritional composition of the diets of south Asian, black African-Caribbean and white European children in the United Kingdom: the child heart and health study in England (CHASE)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DIABETES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET]]>
document.body:
There is growing evidence that the increased risks of coronary heart disease (CHD), type 2 diabetes and central obesity in south Asian adults and the increase risks of type 2 diabetes and general obesity in black African-Caribbean adults emerge in early life with nutrition being a key factor.  Using 24 hour recalls of dietary intake this study examines the variations in nutritional composition of the diets of south Asian, black African-Caribbean and white European children.

A cross-sectional survey of 2,209 children aged 9-10 years was conducted in 85 primary schools in London, Birmingham and Leicester.  Ethnic groups included in the study were: south Asian (558), black African-Caribbean (560) and white European (543).

]]>
