document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Obesity and South Asian Children
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIABETES,TYPE 2,OBESITY,PEOPLE FROM ETHNIC MINORITIES,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,CONDITION MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Obesity and South Asian Children

Written for the 'ethnicity and health' Annual Evidence Update 2009

 

 

 Dr Monica Lakhanpaul

 Dr Deborah Bird

Senior Lecturer,
Department of Medical and
Social Care Education,
University of Leicester

Consultant Paediatrician,
Children's Community Health Service
for Leicester, Leicestershire

Clinical Research Fellow
Department of Medical and
Social Care Education,
University of Leicester

Honorary Specialist Registrar
in Community Paediatrics,
Leicester City PCT

Return to index page

Obesity in childhood has been referred to by the World Health Organisation as a ‘Global Epidemic’ with over 22 million sufferers. In the UK, rates of obesity are significantly higher for Asian / Asian British children (refs 1, 2) compared to white British children.

Overweight/obese children are at higher risk of insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes (T2DM or NIDDM), metabolic syndrome, coronary artery disease, some cancers, breathing problems and arthritis and psychological problems (ref 3).

 

Defining obesity

In adults, Body Mass Index (BMI) >25 defines overweight and >30 obesity, although the World Health Organisation recently recommended that in Asian populations, adults with BMI>23 should be considered overweight and therefore at higher risk of obesity (ref 6). The Indian Health Ministry recently announced a national adjustment in adults to BMI>23 defining overweight and BMI>25 defining obesity (ref 4). Similar changes have not yet been adopted for south Asians living in the UK.

For children there is no worldwide accepted definition of obesity and no ethnically adapted definitions, although the adult standards are commonly used. Waist circumference is an independent predictor of insulin resistance, lipid levels and blood pressure in children (refs 5, 6). Therefore, the International Diabetes Federation recommends the use of waist measurement in defining obesity (ref 3) in preference to BMI. For adults, the definitions have been adapted for ethnicity, however in children their recommendation of waist circumference >90th centile to define obesity applies to all ethnicities, although the use of ethnicity-specific centile charts is advocated.

Genetics

Parental obesity is a significant predictor of child obesity, independent of diet or activity. More than 400 genes or gene markers have been identified with a role in obesity (ref 7). The Fat mass and obesity associated (FTO) gene is strongly associated with both obesity and type 2 diabetes in white adults and children (ref 8) but evidence in Asian populations has been conflicting. Recently, both Sanghera et al (ref 9) and Yaknik et al (ref 10) found that variants in FTO gene predisposed south Asian adults to type 2 diabetes but without a clear correlation to BMI. Other genes reported to have a relationship to insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes (but not necessarily BMI) in the south Asian adult population include FOXA2 (ref 11), INSIG2 (ref 12), IRS-2 (ref 13).

Lifestyle

In last year’s evidence update Hanif summarised the evidence concerning the relationships between traditional south Asian diets, physical inactivity and central adiposity in adults (ref 14). In children, familial perceptions of ‘healthy’ weight, activity levels and food choices impact upon childhood obesity. Khunti et al demonstrated that children from ethnic minorities have lower levels of physical activity (ref 15) than white European contemporaries, although activity levels were poor in general. They also found that dietary habits were generally unhealthy in children of all ethnicities.

In addition, ‘normal’ weight may be viewed differently within cultures, families or generations. In a multi-ethnic UK sample of 14-15 yr olds, boys and children from ethnic minorities were most likely to underestimate their level of obesity (ref 16).

Treatment

Luttikhuis et al (ref 17) recently published a Cochrane review of 64 RCTs comparing obesity interventions programmes in children. They concluded that ‘family based lifestyle interventions with a behavioural programme’ were most effective. They also concluded that Orlistat and sibutramine should have a role in weight management in obese adolescents but not younger children. No studies of surgical interventions for children met their inclusion criteria. The ethnic composition of the included studies is not recorded and ethnicity is not considered as a separate variable.

Intervention programmes

A recent Department of Health report (ref 18) specifically recommended that interventions for minority ethnic groups should be culturally appropriate and involve engagement with extended family members and community leaders. This correlates with the findings of Luttikhuis et al (ref 17), and suggests that participatory approaches to obesity intervention development are most likely to succeed.

Tackling obesity requires lifestyle change across the entire life course (ref 19). Such change takes time, discipline, perseverance and effort and it needs to be permanent. This is a considerable challenge for any intervention. The best chance of success in encouraging lifestyle modifications can be achieved by motivating and empowering children in the context of the family and community in which they live. This is most easily achieved when the ideas respond to existing parental and community aspirations and cultural ideals. Since ‘good health’ rather than overweight has been shown to be the main concern of parents of overweight children (ref 20), good health may be the appropriate focus for collaboratively designed interventions for overweight children and their families in minority ethnic populations.

 

 

References

  1. Saxena S, Ambler G, Cole TJ, Majeed A. Ethnic group differences in overweight and obese children and young people in England: cross sectional survey. Arch.Dis.Child. 2004;89(1):30-6.
    [view details]

  2. Department of Health. 2007/8 school year headline results. 2008:1-62.
    [view details]

  3. Zimmet P, Alberti KG, Kaufman F, Tajima N, Silink M, Arslanian S. The metabolic syndrome in children and adolescents - an IDF consensus report. Pediatric Diabetes 2007;8(5):299-306.
    [view details]

  4. Diabetes UK. Obesity threshold is lowered for people in India. 2009.  Accessed August 27th, 2009.
    [view details]

  5. Bacha F, Saad R, Gungor N, Arslanian SA. Are obesity-related metabolic risk factors modulated by the degree of insulin resistance in adolescents? Diabetes Care 2006;29(7):1599-604.
    [view details]

  6. Lee S, Bacha F, Arslanian SA. Waist circumference, blood pressure, and lipid components of the metabolic syndrome. J.Pediatr. 2006;149(6):809-16.
    [view details]

  7. Newell A, Zlot A, Silvey K, Arail K. Addressing the obesity epidemic: a genomics perspective. Preventing Chronic Disease 2007;4(2):A31.
    [view details]

  8. Frayling TM, Timpson NJ, Weedon MN, Zeggini E, Freathy RM. A common variant in the FTO gene is associated with body mass index and predisposes to childhood and adult obesity. Science 2007;316(5826):889-94.
    [view details]

  9. Sanghera DK, Ortega L, Han S, Singh J, Ralhan SK. Impact of nine common type 2 diabetes risk polymorphisms in Asian Indian Sikhs: PPARG2 (Pro12Ala), IGF2BP2, TCF7L2 and FTO variants confer a significant risk. BMC Medical Genetics 2008;9:59.
    [view details]

  10. Yajnik CS, Janipalli CS, Bhaskar S, Kulkarni SR, Freathy RM. FTO gene variants are strongly associated with type 2 diabetes in South Asian Indians. Diabetologia 2009;52(2):247-52.
    [view details]

  11. Tabassum R, Chavali S, Dwivedi OP, Tandon N, Bharadwaj D. Genetic variants of FOXA2: risk of type 2 diabetes and effect on metabolic traits in North Indians. J.Hum.Genet. 2008;53(11-12):957-65.
    [view details]

  12. Carulli L, Rondinella S, Lombardini S, Canedi I, Loria P. Review article: diabetes, genetics and ethnicity. Alimentary Pharmacology 2005;22(2):16-9.
    [view details]

  13. Bodhini D, Radha V, Deepa R, Ghosh S, Majumder PP. The G1057D polymorphism of IRS-2 gene and its relationship with obesity in conferring susceptibility to type 2 diabetes in Asian Indians. Int.J.Obes. 2007;31(1):97-102.
    [view details]

  14. Hanif W. Type 2 diabetes and obesity in the south Asian population. 2008.
    [view details]

  15. Khunti K, Stone MA, Bankart J, Sinfield PK, Talbot D. Physical activity and sedentary behaviours of South Asian and white European children in inner city secondary schools in the UK. Fam.Pract. 2007;24(3):237-44.
    [view details]

  16. Standleya R, Sullivana V, Wardle J. Self-perceived weight in adolescents: over-estimation or under-estimation? Body Image 2009;6(1):56-9.
    [view details]

  17. Oude Luttikhuis H, Baur L, Jansen H, Shrewsbury VA, O'Malley C. Interventions for treating obesity in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009(1):CD001872.
    [view details]

  18. Department of Health. Healthy Weight, Healthy Lives: Consumer Insight Summary. 2008;285214.
    [view details]

  19. Stender SRS, Burghen GA, Mallare JT. The role of health care providers in the prevention of overweight and type 2 diabetes in children and adolescents. Diabetes Spectrum 2005;18(4):240-248.
    [view details]

  20. Goodell S, Pierce MB, Bravo CM, Ferris AM. Parental perceptions of overweight during early childhood. Qual.Health Res. 2008;18(11):1548-55.
    [view details]
]]>

document.body:
The role of food in a social, cultural and therapeutic context takes on increasing significance as people face cancer and the end of life. This study investigates the beliefs of older Chinese people on the influence of food on cancer and its role in supporting cancer care.

A two phase qualitative study involving 46 older Chinese people was conducted. Phase one involved participation in focus groups; phase two involved semi-structured interviews conducted in Cantonese or Mandarin as appropriate.

document.title: Opportunities for and barriers to good nutritional health in minority ethnic groups
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This review is concerned with factors that promote healthy eating among minority healthy groups living in Great Britain, concentrating on South Asians, African-Caribbean and Irish, covering the entire life-cycle of the three ethnic groups in the study. The understanding of healthy eating messages varied widely across groups and knowledge of foods high in complex carbohydrates, fibre, fat and saturated fat was often poor across all ethnic groups. Other issues such as diet in pregnancy, birthweight, iron and vitamin D defficiency, rickets and tuberculosis were taken into consideration. Attention was particularly paid to coronary heart disease (CHD), diabetes and obesity.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Oral Health and Ethnicity: dental caries and oral cancer
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ORAL HEALTH,CANCER,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,OUTCOMES,YOUNG PEOPLE,CHILDREN,ETHNICITY,ORAL HEALTH DISORDERS,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,TOBACCO USE,SMOKING,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,HYGIENE,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,2008-OCTOBER,2008,AGE GROUPS,POPULATIONS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,GROUPS,RACE,DENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
111-1Oral Health and Ethnicity: dental caries and oral cancer

Written for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2008 

 

Professor Raman Bedi


Head, International Centre for Child Oral Health

Director, Global Child Dental Health Taskforce, King's College London

Co-Director, WHO Collaborating Centre for Disability, Culture and Oral Health, University College London 

Oral health is a broad landscape and in this article I will focus upon dental caries and oral cancer as these two are the most widely documented conditions when ethnic oral health variations are explored.

 

Dental caries

Together with the common cold, dental caries is perhaps the most prevalent disease of modern man but, unlike the cold, its effects invariably leave behind defects that are permanent.  Dental caries prevalence among the UK’s children has decreased dramatically over that past 3 decades. According to ONS data, in 2003 (the most recent year for which survey data are available) less than half of all five year olds (43%) had obvious decay experience (DMFT) in the primary dentition; 57% were free from decay. With regard to trends in DMFT in permanent teeth (older age groups), 14% of eight years olds had DMFT in the permanent dentition, compared to 34% of 12 year olds and almost half (49%) of 15 year olds [ref 1].

 

The proportion of children and young people in the overall population with obvious  experience of decay in the permanent teeth has decreased in all age groups over the past 20 years. For example, in 1983 81% of all 12 year olds had DMFT in 1983.  This was reduced to 52% in 1993 and 34% in 2003 [ref 1].

 

Although these improvements are impressive, there is concern that dental health of young children is becoming a growing problem.  In addition the overall improvements seen have not been the experience of all children and the evidence shows that minority ethnic and low income groups are still suffering poorer oral health [ref 2].  This inequality has been documented since the 1970s with the South Asian community being the group most investigated in terms of ethnic differences [ref 2].  There is little literature on oral health within the new migrant communities from Eastern Europe or for any minority ethnic groups who do not live in deprived areas.

 

The evidence with regard to minority ethnic groups and dental caries shows that there are four important aspects which should be considered.  These are religious background, the ability of the mother to speak English, the fact that older “Asian” children may not have the same inequality in dental health as younger children, and finally that little is known about the dental health and dental service usage of older members of the South Asian community [refs 3 & 4].

 

The main conclusion from the available evidence is that dental caries, as a lifestyle disease, has marked social and ethnic inequalities with lower social class groups and some South Asian groups experiencing more disease.  Over and above this, certain minority ethnic groups in deprived areas have worse disease levels than their white counterparts.  In a recent study in Glasgow, examining changes over a decade in caries experience amongst children in deprived areas, aged 4-5 years, significant improvements in caries and oral health were observed amongst white children over the decade, and although less marked, these were mirrored amongst South Asian children [ref 5].

 

Oral cancer

The picture with regard to oral cancer and minority ethnic groups is currently unclear in the UK.  Most oral cancer is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and it is customary to include cancers of the lip, tongue, gum, floor of the mouth and unspecified parts of the mouth in this category.

 

Evidence from the literature suggests that there is marked inter-country variation in both the incidence and mortality from these cancers. There is also growing evidence of intra-country ethnic differences, mostly reported in the UK and USA. These variations among ethnic groups have been attributed mainly to specific risk factors, such as alcohol and tobacco (smoking and smokeless), but dietary factors and the existence of genetic predispositions may also play a part.  Variations in access to care services are also an apparent factor.  However, the true extent of ethnic differences in oral cancer is masked by the scarcity of available information [ref 7].

 

Previous research had shown that South Asians residing in the south east of England had greater incidence rates of oral cancer than the majority population.  However, a recent study exploring the south-east England cancer registry data showed no evidence of decreased survival between South Asians and the white community.  Indeed there was evidence that British South Asian males have significantly better survival than their non-south Asian peers in the south east of England [ref 7].

 

As well as the fact that some minority groups may use cancer services less frequently, the overall knowledge of oral cancer and early signs remains poor [ref 8].  In a UK national adult survey, when asked whether they had heard of mouth cancer, respondents’ knowledge of early signs and risk factors showed that whereas 95.6% said they had heard of mouth cancer, their awareness of early signs was low; for example, only 33.8% recognized that white patches in the mouth were a sign.  The large majority understood that smoking and chewing tobacco were risk factors (84.7% and 80.1% respectively) but only 19.4% recognized alcohol use as a risk factor [ref 8].

 

Since smokeless tobacco use in this country is largely confined to the South Asian community it can be assumed that oral cancer risk will be higher in people who indulge in this habit.  However, this may vary depending on the product.  Seven UK brands of smokeless tobacco, including a tooth cleaning powder, and four international brands of smokeless tobacco have been tested for a range of toxins and known carcinogens.  The researchers found 10 of the 11 brands tested had detectable levels of tobacco specific nitrosamines, which are proven carcinogens, and that these levels varied 130-fold.  All had detectable levels of benzo(a)pyrene, another proven carcinogen (with around 175-fold variation) and several toxic metals (with nearly 150-fold variation) [ref 9].  All the tobacco products tested are likely to be hazardous to users' health.

 

In summary, ethnic variations in oral cancer within the UK community remain unclear.  There are problems with reporting and the quality of ethnic data in cancer registry data.  There is a need to better define ethnic variations in oral cancer and the use of related health services.

References

  1. Pitts N, and Harker, R (2005). Obvious decay experience. Children's  Dental Health in the United Kingdom 2003, Office for National Statistics.  [download pdf]

  2. Office of Public Management (2005) A futures study of dental decay in five and fifteen year olds in England. London: Office of Public Management.   [download pdf]

  3. Bedi R. Lewsey JD, Gilthorpe MS  Changes in oral health over ten years amongst UK children aged 4-5 years living in a deprived multiethnic area.  British Dental Journal 2000; 189: 88-92. [view abstract]

  4. Dhawan N, Bedi R    Transcultural oral health care: 6. The oral health of minority ethnic groups in united kingdom – a review. Dental Update 2001; 28: 30-34. [view abstract]

  5. Conway DI, Quarrell, I, McCall, DR, Gilmour H, Bedi, R, Macpherson LM.  Dental caries n 5-year-old children attending multi-ethnic schools in Greater Glasgow - the impact of ethnic background and levels of deprivation.  Community Dental Health. 2007; 24:161-5.  [view abstract]

  6. Scully C, Bedi R.  Ethnicity and oral cancer. The Lancet Oncology 2000: 1: 37-42.  [view abstract]

  7. Moles DR, Fedele S, Speight PM, Porter SR. The unclear role of ethnicity in health inequalities: the scenario of oral cancer incidence and survival in  the British South Asian population. Oral Oncology. 2007 Sep;43(8):831-4. 2007.   [view abstract]

  8. West R, Alkhatib MN, McNeill A, Bedi R.  Awareness of mouth cancer in Great Britain.  British Dental Journal 2006 Feb 11;200(3):167-9   [view abstract]

  9. McNeill A, Bedi R, Islam S,   Levels of toxins in oral tobacco products  Alkhatib MN,  West R  in the  UK.  Tobacco Control. 2006 Feb;15(1):64-7.  [view abstract]
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Our Vision Too: Improving the access of ethnic minority visually impaired people to appropriate services; building a supported community referral system.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,EYES AND VISION]]>
document.body:
Aims

This study sought to raise awareness of sight loss issues and services in black and minority ethnic communities and voluntary sector groups working in those communities.

An additional aim was to raise the capacity of specialist visual impairment (VI) service providers to recognise the specific needs of people from black and minority ethnic (BME) groups, and establish the best ways of meeting these.

 

Methods

The full project report contains the findings from a review of literature and current research, and describes the process undertaken in the project. Community fieldworkers were trained and conducted ‘focus group’  discussions in their communities, giving information to group members.

An action research model was adopted, leading to a series of ‘Sight Loss Information Fairs’. An evaluation study followed up these activities.

 

Evidence base

The literature review noted the poor evidence base generally in relation to minority groups and sight loss. There has been a recent growth of information through secondary analysis of Visual Impairment registers. Whilst the prevalence of agerelated sight loss appears to be lower in minority ethnic groups, this may be attributed to their younger age profile.

High levels of diabetes lead to an expectation of worse eye health. There are more cases of juvenile inherited eye conditions, raised levels of glaucoma in African Caribbean populations, and more experience of cataract among people of South Asian origin.

 

The ‘visual impairment’ research literature tends to ignore issues of race and ethnicity. Similarly the literature relating to ‘race relations and ethnic diversity’ largely excludes attention to sight loss.

 

There is consensus that there is apparent under-use of services by minority groups, and possibly under-registration. This is linked to low levels of knowledge and failure to recognise needs that can be addressed.

 

Some service providers have been concerned about this but there is little evidence of strenuous effort to raise uptake. Improvement in service uptake requires assertive outreach, cultural competence, and partnership with voluntary organisations run by minority ethnic groups. Many attempts have been made to improve the situation but problems have arisen from short-term funding and closure of projects. New or recent research and development projects have so far been poorly reported on in accessible literature and there were few reports of evaluations. All studies tend to

underline previous findings, largely referring to low awareness. More recent research has shown some specific housing needs from BME people with visual impairments, notably a greater level of housing need than comparable white users, and stronger family ties.

 

]]>

document.title: Paediatric mortality related to pandemic influenza A H1N1 infection in England: an observational population-based study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
The pandemic influenza A H1N1 infection disproportionately affected young people, this study analyses paediatric mortality to inform clinical and public health policies for future influenza seasons and pandemics.

Daily reporting systems and cross-checking of records, with validation from laboratory results or death certificates were used to identify deaths related to A H1N1 infection from June 26th, 2009 to March 22, 2010.

The study found that mortality rates for Bangladeshi and Pakistani children were higher than for white British children.   

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: It is important to note that the authors cannot explain the reasons for the rise in deaths for certain ethnic groups and that areas with low ethnic diversity were equally affected by the infection.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Pain and suffering as viewed by the Hindu religion
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION]]>
document.description: Religion and spiritual practices are among the resources used by patients to cope with chronic pain.
document.body:
This article presents the major concepts of Hinduism related to pain and suffering as well as reviewing Hindu traditions that deal with pain and suffering.

Practitioners can offer potentially helpful concepts to all patients by becoming more familiar with Hindu views of pain and suffering.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Palliative care and ethnic minorities in Britain
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body:
111-1Palliative care and ethnic minorities in Britain

An urgent need to improve the evidence base

 

This week the Palliative & Supportive Care Specialist Library has highlighted the issue of Pain in its Annual Evidence Update [visit the library]. SLEH offers a few comments in support of their conclusion that (while) “there is evidence for interventions to improve end of life care, many important issues lack quality evidence … across the range of terminal conditions”.

Variations in access and utilisation

The relative lack of access to, and uptake of, palliative care services by members of black and minority (BME) ethnic groups was established more than a decade ago, (ref 1) but, as suggested in Margaret Goodman’s editorial for the SLEH 2007 National Knowledge Week (ref 2) the process of change has been slow, both in developing the knowledge base to underpin development of a culturally competent palliative care service, and of widening awareness of, demand for, and referral to those services among members of the BME communities.   It has also been difficult to document change, although there have been many positive developments, and we are aware that many hospices, as well as the two major charities associated with palliative nursing care, have strong commitment to meeting these needs and improving access.  Further, training materials such as those developed by the PROCEED project (ref 3) have become available, and textbooks for staff in the sector (ref 4, 5), as well as nursing-oriented articles describing the cultural and religious beliefs or preferences of minority groups for end-of life care provide ample resources for initial training and in-service professional development.  See the review 'Diversities in Approach to End-of-life' (ref 6).

 
 Photo by Alana Jonez
In fact, given the numbers of ‘toolkits’ or checklists and informative descriptive articles available (ref 7), there can be little excuse for practitioners in this field of healthcare not to deliver culturally sensitive care!  However, the majority of the published literature is precisely that – descriptive, and there is a lack of evidence of impact, or evaluations of changes in practice to show that quality of life or care has been enhanced, or that perceptions and uptake of the services have improved.  Indeed, few have even taken a comparative perspective. The paper by Koffman & Higginson, considering Black Caribbean people in London, is a rare exception (ref 8), as is the qualitative study by Owens & Randhawa of South Asian people in Luton (ref 9).

Finally, we must consider the implications for the NHS if monitoring data do not show an increase in the use of palliative care services, whether in hospices or through community-based nursing and other forms of care.  It may be that BME patients (the word ‘users’ seems inappropriate here) are still choosing not to access these services, whether through the voluntary sector or the NHS, or it may be that primary and secondary care providers are failing to refer them to these services. However, the National Cancer Action Team, and its new Equality Initiative announced in the Cancer Reform Strategy, (ref 10) will need to take a close interest in this issue – while recognising that other conditions (some of which may be more common in minority ethnic groups) are also best managed through the palliative care pathway. In particular, we would draw attention to issues surrounding the haemoglobinopathies such as Sickle Cell disease (ref 11).


Where do we go from here?

There does not seem to be much connection between the research base and developments in practice – and the apparently extensive research into ‘pain’ measurement (much of it in the area of Rheumatology – (see ref 12 for an example) needs to be linked into developments in pain management and indeed, applied to the spectrum of minority ethnic groups that exist in Britain. This might also be linked usefully to the management of long-term disorders such as Sickle Cell, which can be associated with excruciating pain but does not appear to be mentioned much in the literature relating to ‘palliative and supportive care’. Indeed, as noted in the most recent Cochrane reviews listed by the Palliative & Supportive Care Library, there are no relevant quality trials into pain management and sickle cell! We look forward to locating more materials such as that from Ekblad and colleagues exploring staff cultural competence in palliative care (in Sweden) – (ref 13).

The NLH Specialist libraries as a group are committed to locating and developing a ‘database of uncertainties’ to inform future research agendas and welcome feedback from our users (Please use this link - Contact Us - or the 'Contact Us' button above if you would like to raise ethnicity-specific issues).

References

  1. Hill D, Penso D, 1995 Opening Doors:  improving access to hospice and specialist palliative care services by members of the black and minority ethnic communities.  Occasional Paper 7, National Council for Hospice and Specialist Care Services [view details]

  2. Goodman, Margaret. [internet] 2007 ‘End of life care: for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2007’.   [view detail] 
     
  3. PROCEED: Professionals RespOnding to CancEr and Ethnic Diversity, is a project led by Prof Joe Kai of Nottingham University, and Jackie Beavan of Birmingham University and its reports and resources can be obtained via Cancer Research UK.  [view resource]
     
  4. Faull C, Carter Y, Woof R (Eds) 2005 Handbook of Palliative Care Maldon, Mass: Blackwell  [view summary] 
     
  5. Firth S 2001 Wider horizons: care of the dying in a multicultural society. London: National Council for Hospice and Specialist Palliative Care Services [view abstract]
  6. Jones, Kip [internet] 'Diversities in approach to end-of-life:  a view from Britain of the qualitative literature'.  Centre fro Evidence in Ethnicity, Health & Diversity (CEEHD) [view detail]
  7. 'Making practice-based learning work' general resources in 'Ethnicity and Culture' [view resource list] 
  8. Koffman J.  Higginson IJ. 2001 'Accounts of carers' satisfaction with health care at the end of life: a comparison of first generation black Caribbeans and white patients with advanced disease' Palliative Medicine.  15(4):337-45  [view abstract]
  9. Owens A.  Randhawa G. 2004 ''It's different from my culture; they're very different': Providing community-based, 'culturally competent' palliative care for South Asian people in the UK' Health & Social Care in the Community  12(5):414-21  [view abstract]
  10. National Cancer Action Team, and its new Equality Initiative announced in the Cancer Reform Strategy, [view strategy papers] 
  11. Wright J, Bareford D, Wright C, Augustine G, Olley K, Musamadi L, Dhanda C, Knight C. (2004) 'Day case management of sickle pain: 3 years experience in a UK sickle cell unit'. British Journal of Haematology 126 (6):878-80 [view abstract]

  12. Vlaar AP.  ten Klooster PM.  Taal E.  Gheith RE.  El-Garf AK.  Rasker JJ.  van de Laar MA. 2007 'A cross-cultural study of pain intensity in Egyptian and Dutch women with rheumatoid arthritis'.   Journal of Pain  8(9):730-6  [view abstract]

  13. Ekblad S, Marttila A, Emilsson M 2000 'Cultural challenges in end-of-life care: reflections from focus groups interviews with hospice staff' in Stockholm Journal of Advanced Nursing 31,3 :623-630 [view abstract]
     
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Palliative care for Sikhs
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This article provides an overview of the palliative care needs of Sikh patients. It describes the basis of Sikh beliefs and practices and discusses pratical aspects of caring for terminally ill Sikh patients and their families. Issues before and after death are considered and the importance of an individual approach is highlighted.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Palliative care: the experience of informal carers within the Bangladeshi community
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,DEATH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study investigates the experiences of Bangladeshi informal carers living in the UK, associated with caring for a dying relative. Palliative care nurses working with Bangladeshi families need to be aware of the additional stresses that these families may experience and be able to offer strategies to enable them to cope with them.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Parental attitudes towards the management of asthma in ethnic minorities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,ACCIDENT & EMERGENCY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
Children from black and minority ethnic (BME) groups have a relatively high rate of attendance at accident and emergency (A&E) departments in the UK. This study investigates whether parents beliefs and management of childhood asthma contributes to their children's greater use of hospital services.

A questionnaire survey was conducted with minority ethnic parents accompanying 150 children (aged 3 -9 years of age) in asthma clinics and A&E departments in three London hospitals.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Pathways to diagnosis for black men and white men found to have prostate cancer: the PROCESS cohort study.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
This population-based retrospective cohort study investigates whether access to diagnostic services can account for the higher incidence of diagnosed prostate cancer in black men as compared to their white counterparts.

Prostate cancer was ascertained by hospital records along with a multitude of other sources. Race and other factors that may influence prostate cancer diagnosis were assessed by a questionnaire and a review of hospital records.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Patient focus public involvement providing more personal information to the NHS
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.description: This report provides a detailed account of a patient-public involvement activity that the Equality Diversity Programme carried out through collaboration with statutory, community and voluntary organisations.
document.body:
Although primarily a resource targeted for NHS Scotland, the report is relevant for all NHS Health Organisations concerned with the engagement of patients in giving equality and diversity information to support their healthcare.

This report provides a detailed account of a patient focused public involvement  activity that the Equality Diversity Programme carried out through collaboration with statutory, community and voluntary organisations.  A nine-month project was undertaken to involve patients and gain their opinions about the collection of diversity data by the NHS

Fifteen focus groups were carried out in community centres, day care centres, restaurant, town halls and other local authority premises, and a questionnaire was used.

For supporting documentation, including links to a 4.7 mb pdf of the Introduction, Patient Survey Questionnaire (Word), findings of a pilot survey and an ethnic monitoring toolkit, see also:  http://www.isdscotland.org/isd/3392.html

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Patient Involvement - The Meaning of Choice in the NHS
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.description: Frances Chinemana, Patient and Public Involvement Development Manager for NHS Direct, reflects on patient empowerment and public involvement in a multicultural society.
document.body:
111-1Patient Involvement - The Meaning of Choice in the NHS

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2007

Frances Chinemana

Patient and Public Involvement Development Manager
NHS Direct

The Meaning of Choice in the NHS

In many cultures, the idea of choice in respect of health care is an alien concept, and one which is often not practicable to implement. Culturally determined concepts of illness and health will influence health care behaviour, underpinned by issues of gender, status and access to disposable income. So raising awareness about choice in a multi-cultural society like our own is about more than translating leaflets or preparing videos about the Choose and Book service. Even these activities would make a start, though – but there is little evidence to suggest that they are commonplace, even in the inner cities and areas of greatest diversity. And as long as ethnicity monitoring is incompletely implemented across the health service, we will never know what changes have occurred, in terms of individual’s access to health care, and the choices they have made.

The new NHS Choices website (reference 1 below), although the person pictured could belong to one of the UK’s minority ethnic groups, does little to help minority ethnic groups to understand how to exercise choice in health care, as none of the materials are in languages other than English. Some hospital trusts indicate that they provide interpreter support for medical consultations, but there is virtually no signposting on the Choices website to specific services for minority ethnic groups. For example, there is only one mention of the Asian Smoking Quitline, in relation to giving up smoking for Ramadan.

The Healthcare Commission’s review of the 2004/2005 patients surveys (2) found that: "Patients from black and minority ethnic groups were more likely than white patients to report negative experiences.  Specifically, this finding relates to the patient’s level of involvement in decisions about their care, as well as their experience of medical staff talking in front of them as if they were not there. Asian patients responded more negatively than white patients in general."   So, we do not properly support choices about health care for these groups, and once they have accessed care, do not support their involvement. This lack of support extends to formal patient and public involvement: again, there is virtually no evidence to suggest that the health service is proactively engaging across the diversity of health care users.

As I write, we are marking Black History Month, which for the NHS is always the focus for a celebration of the diversity of the work force. It is high time to extend this focus to service users and to provide them with the appropriate information and resources to make choice a reality.

References and Resources 

  1. The NHS Choices website:
    NHS Choices

  2. A pdf of the following can be downloaded from the Healthcare Commission website. The link  will take you to the relevant page.

    'Review of BME coverage in the Healthcare Commission patient survey programme' at the Healthcare Commission webpage

    Or go directly to the pdf in a new window.

  3. 'Patient Focus Public Involvement Providing More Personal Information to the NHS'

    Although primarily based on research conducted for NHS Scotland, the above report may be of wider use for all NHS Health Organisations tasked with the collection of patient-related equality and diversity information to support achievement of their healthcare equity goals.  A pdf of the report can be found on the website of the National Health Services Scotland 'Equality and Diversity Information Programme (EDIP)' pages.

    Access the report through the link to:
    National Health Services Scotland 'Equality and Diversity Information Programme (EDIP) pages'.

    Or use this direct link to pdf of the report (about 5mb) - opens new window.

  4. The following resource contains a case study of an initiative in Tower Hamlets concerned with ways of reaching into the Bengali community.  It can be downloaded at the Department of Health website.  The link below leads to the relevant page.

    Choice matters 2007–08: putting patients in control

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Patient satisfaction with different interpreting methods: a randomized controlled trial
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
As a result of increasing numbers of limited-English-proficient (LEP) patients a number of different interpreting methods for these patients have been developed.  This randomised controlled trial evaluates the impact of interpreting method on patient satisfaction.

1,276 patients at a primary care clinic were included in the trial, patients were either assigned to the remote simultaneous medical interpreting (RSMI) method or the usual and customary (U&C) interpreting method.

SCEH Note: This is a US study and some findings may not transfer to UK practice.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Patients' experiences and expectations of general practice: a questionnaire study of differences by ethnic group
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
Previous research has highlighted variations in morbidity, mortality and health needs by ethnic group, this study looks at the experience and expectations of different ethnic groups in their general practice consultation.

604 consecutive patients who described their ethnic group as white British, black African, black African Caribbean or Vietnamese were included in a cross-sectional survey that took place in one general practice in a mulitcultural area of London.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Patterns of mortality among Bangladeshis in England and Wales.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,STATISTICS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This study investigates the patterns of mortality among Bangladeshis living in England and Wales.

Indirect standardization was used to derive standardized mortality ratios using national mortality data from 1988 to 1992.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Patterns of physical activity and relationship with risk markers for cardiovascular disease and diabetes in Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi and European adults in a UK population.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET]]>
document.body:
This study investigates whether the differences in physical activity between European, Indian, Pakistani and Bangladeshi populations in the UK may contribute to the differences in the prevalence of diabetes and cardiovascular disease for these groups.

A cross-sectional population study of European, Indian, Pakistani and Bangladeshi men and women aged between 25 and 75 years was carried out in Newcastle upon Tyne.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Patterns of smoking cessation in the first 3 years after stroke: the South London Stroke Register
document.publisher: European Journal of Cardiovascular Prevention and Rehabilitation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Stroke survivors have a high risk of recurrent strokes and other vascular events. Smoking cessation is recommended as a secondary prevention for stroke, this study looks at patterns of smoking cessation after stroke.  

Data was derived form the South London Stroke Register, with complete smoking data from 363 survivors of stroke between 1995 and 2003. Stroke survivors who were smoking at the time of stroke and alive three years later were included in the study. Self reported smoking status was measured at the time of stroke, at 3 months, 1 year and 3 years after stroke.

CEEHD Note: This article is based on UK ethnic minority population, but should be interpreted carefully since it does not provide sufficient detail of the ethnic sub-groups involved.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: People from black and minority ethnic (BME) communities and vision services: a good practice guide
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EYES AND VISION,LOW VISION,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,EYES AND VISION,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES,CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This good practice guide is aimed at assisting those who commission and provide health and social care services to black and minority ethnic (BME) people with sight loss.

Topics covered include:

  • Equalities and policy framework 
  • Needs at a local level
  • Raising the level of awareness
  • Screening and early detection
  • Engouraging access
  • Culturally sensitive services
  • Planning future services with BME communities
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: People like us: ethnic group density effects on health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Previous studies have discovered a "group density" effect on health that results in members of a community living in an area with a higher proportion of their own racial or ethnic group tending to have better health than those living in areas with a low proportion of their own racial or ethnic group.  This study evaluted previous research on this effect with an aim to stimulating further research.   ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 'People make assumptions about our communities': sexual health amongst teenagers from black and minority ethnic backgrounds in east London
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This study explored sexual behaviour and relationships among Black and minority ethnic teenagers in east London; examined how these relationships are shaped by culture, gender, peer norms and religion; and described the implications for sexual health policy and practice in urban, multicultural areas.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: People with learning disabilities in Scotland - health needs assessment report 2004
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES]]>
document.body:
The Health Needs Assessment was undertaken in response to the first recommendation of  Promoting Health, Supporting Inclusion: The National Review of the Contribution of All Nurses and Midwives to the Care and Support of People with Learning Disabilities.

 

The recommendations within the health needs assessment report were aimed at reducing health inequalities and promoting social inclusion; they are informed by evidence from across Scotland, the experiences of service users and their carers, published research and Scottish and international experience.  

 

The report contains:

  • Foreword
  • Executive Summary
  • Contents
  • Part One: Introduction
  • Part Two: The evidence
  • Part Three: Improving the health of children, adults and older adults with learning disabilities in Scotland
  • Summary of Recommendations
  • References
  • Appendices
  • Figures
  • Tables
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: People with learning disability and mental health care: influence of ethnic background
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ LEARNING DISABILITIES,MENTAL HEALTH,MENTAL HEALTH,ADULT CONDITIONS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.body:
111-1People with learning disability and mental health care: influence of ethnic background

 Written for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2008 

   

Dr Satheesh Kumar Gangadharan

Consultant, Leicester Partnership NHS Trust

Dr Sabyasachi Bhaumik

Consultant in Learning Disability

Chair, RCPsych Faculty of LD

Honorary Senior Lecturer
University of Leicester

 

There is considerable stigma and discrimination associated with learning disability (LD) and mental health problems in people from ethnic minority backgrounds. Services often offer a ‘tokenistic’ approach in meeting the individual’s socio-cultural needs, resulting in under-usage of service and creating a general environment of ‘lack of engagement’.

 

Evidence from mental health research shows that the pathway to care is significantly different for people from black and minority ethnic (BME) communities compared to their white (so-called Caucasian) counterparts.  People from BME communities have higher rates of compulsory admission, longer average lengths of stay, and are more likely to be prescribed drugs or ECT rather than psychotherapy or counselling (ref 1). Certain BME communities access mental health services less than the white population (ref 2). Although the situation has somewhat improved in the last decade or so, evidence still points to a significant difference in service use. The experience of people from BME communities in services received is still very different to that of white people. A recent national patient survey report pointed to the need for further improvement in services for people from ethnic minority backgrounds, including access to non-invasive therapies and better recording of their ethnicity status by the services (ref 3).

 

There is a widely held belief among professionals that BME communities enjoy the support of joint family networks and therefore may not require services in the same way as the white people. However available research evidence does not support this myth. One study in a south Asian population showed that societal attitudes towards disability and the fear of obligation prevented families from seeking help from wider social networks (ref 4).

 

Photo by Paulo Fehlauer License

Ethnicity and LD is a relatively under researched area. Available evidence suggests significant issues in support provision for people with LD from BME communities. A study using the Leicestershire LD register found that people with LD from south Asian backgrounds had significantly lower skills levels, indicating the need for a higher level of support. Although they had the same level of psychological morbidity, they used psychiatric services, residential care and respite care less than the white population (ref 5).

 

Contrary to the popular view, very few carers of people with LD from BME communities have support from extended families (ref 6). Material disadvantage, high need for services and lack of informal support were highlighted as the burning issues faced by families of people with LD from BME background.  A survey of two local authorities by Hatton et al (ref 7) showed that 61% had little confidence in services and 48% felt that they were not receiving enough services to comment. Only 17% were confident that services would help at the time of crisis.

 

A recent analysis of data from Leicestershire Learning Disability register showed that carers of people with LD from south Asian background experience higher levels of stress and self reported depression.  On the whole the evidence points to low service use by families of people with LD from ethnic minority communities in spite of high unmet needs for services. This seems to contribute significantly to a high level of stress for the carers and possibly psychological and physical consequences (ref 8).

 

A number of factors seem to contribute to low service use by people with LD from BME communities. Lack of appropriate information about services, staff without appropriate skills and services not being able to meet the religious and cultural needs of the users are some of these. There is an information vacuum created by lack of appropriate information, available information not being in an accessible format and not using the appropriate channels to reach the communities (ref 9).

 

There is still a considerable gap in the currently available literature about the nature of changing ethnic minority populations.  Many health districts have not carried out any appropriate service mapping exercises and may have become stuck at the stage of tokenism as far as service provision for people with LD from BME communities is concerned. There is a need for a radical revision of how services are delivered to people with LD from diverse ethnic minority backgrounds.

 

While significant improvements have been made by certain organisations such as the “Valuing People Support Team” team (ref 10), percolation of these initiatives to service level seems to be inadequate still.  There is a need for more cohesive action by all services together to improve access to and experience of services by people from BME communities. This should include a clear strategy for staff training on diversity, facilitating active participation of users and carers from BME background in stakeholder discussions and services developing partnerships with community and voluntary organisations. Direct payments and individualised budgets may provide an opportunity for increasing the range of culturally appropriate services available. Most importantly more research is required to understand the views of people with LD from BME communities and their carers about the culturally appropriate way of meeting their needs.

 

The Royal College of Psychiatrists Faculty of LD plans to establish a national forum in relation to BME issues in LD in partnership with
Professor Mark Johnson (De Montfort University), the Valuing People Support Team, user/carer groups and voluntary organisations and relevant networks such as National Learning and Disability and Ethnicity Network (NLDEN) (ref 11), Association for Real Change (ARC) (ref 12),  the Ethnicity Training Network (ETN), (ref 13) and the National Advisory Group on Learning Disabilities and Ethnicity (NAGLDE) (ref 14) in order to produce a policy & good practice guideline in this area along with promotion of national research.

 

We hope that such initiatives will receive the wider support from Department of Health, Department of Social Services and BME communities.

References

  1. Ethnic variations in pathways to and use of specialist mental health services in the UK:  systematic review, Kamaldeep  Bhui, Stephen Stansfeld, Sally Hull, Stefan Priebe and Funke Mole, Gene Feder. The British Journal of Psychiatry (2003) 182: 105-116.
    [full text]
  2. Healthcare Commission et al, 2007. "Count me in" 2007: results of the 2007 National Census of Inpatients in Mental Health and Learning Disability Services in England and Wales.  London:  Commission for Healthcare Audit and Inspection
    [view details]

  3. Ethnic variations in the experiences of mental health service users in England, Results of a national patient survey programme, Veena S. Raleigh, Robert Irons, Emma Hawe, Sarah Scobie, Adrian Cook, Rachel Reeves, Ann Petruckevitch and Juliette  Harrison, British Journal of Psychiatry ( 2 0 07), 191, 3 0 4- 312 .
    [full text]

  4. Do they look after their own?: informal support for south Asian carers. Savita Katbamna, Waqar Ahmad, Padma Bhakta, Richard Baker and Gillian Parker, Health & Social Care in the Community 12(5):398-406, 2004
    [view abstract] 

  5. Prevalence, morbidity and service need among south Asian and white adults with intellectual disability in Leicestershire, UK
    C. W. McGrother, S. Bhaumik, C. F. Thorp, J. M. Watson, N. A. Taub 
    JIDR Volume 46 Issue 4, Pages 299 – 309, 2002
    [view abstract]

  6. Supporting South Asian families with a child with severe disabilities: a report to the Department of Health: executive summary, Chris Hatton, Yasmeen Akram, Robina Shah, Janet Robertson, Eric Emerson, Institute for Health Research, Lancaster University, 2002
    [view summary]

  7. Informal carers of adolescents and adults with learning difficulties from the south Asian communities: family circumstances, service support and carer stress, Chris Hatton, Sabiha Azmi, Aamanda Caine and Eric Emerson, British Journal of Social Work, Vol 28, 6, 821-837, 1998.
    [view abstract]

  8. A comparative study of stress and unmet needs in carers of South Asian and white adults with intellectual disability, John Devapriam, Bala Raju, Satheesh Gangadharan and Sabyasachi Bhaumik,  in press 2008.

  9. Learning disability and ethnicity: report to the Department of Health, 2000. Ghazala Mir, Andrew Nocon, Waqar Ahmed and Lesley Jones, London: Department of Health. 2000
    [view details]

  10. Valuing People Support Team [website]

document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,COLORECTAL (BOWEL) CANCER,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
Current evidence indicates that there are disparities in uptake rates for screening programmes between UK ethnic minority groups and the white population.  This study explores the barriers to the uptake of sigmoidoscopy (FS) screening among ethnic minorities in the UK.

A total of 53 participants took part in nine focus groups.  Ethnic groups included in the study were: African-Caribbean, Gujarati Indian, Pakistani and white British.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Perceptions of community services among Asian and white stroke survivors and their carers: an exploratory study.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES]]>
document.body:
Previous research on stroke survivors has found high levels of dissatisfaction with specific components of care received in hospital and at home. Differences between ethnic groups, however, have previously not been investigated.  The aim of the study was to compare experiences of community services among Asian and white stroke survivors in Leicester.  

Content analysis demonstrated that the experience of stroke were similar for Asian and white stroke survivors.  There were reported shortcomings in the information provided by both groups on: recovery from stroke and the type and range of services available in their community.  There were also difficulties identifying professionals who were responsible for their care. Feelings of isolation and depression were more common in the Asian sample.

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,SERVICE SECTORS]]>
document.body:
This opinion piece discusses the increase in the imprecise label of "Asian" in predicting responses to drugs. Examples of this imprecision include the wide geographical interpretation of the term "Asian", the use of the term in risk factors for prescription medicine and fact that patients are not always aware that the term refers to them. The author concludes that in the least we need to better define racial labels so that inappropriate generalisations are not made from narrow criteria.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Politics of diversity
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Ethnic diversity is a defining characteristic of contemporary societies - an indisputable truth about the 'demographics' or makeup of the population living in any one country.  What is not so indisputable is the concept of multiculturalism - the complex mix of politics, attitudes and beliefs, which shape how a society understands and seeks to manage that diversity.  These concerns lie at the heart of this module.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Primary health care services for children from minority ethnic groups
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,CHILDREN,ETHNIC GROUPS,SERVICES,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
Aim/Principal research question

The aims of the research were to examine barriers to children’s utilisation of primary health care services among minority ethnic groups within the East London area, and to identify parental roles and attitudes toward their children’s use of primary care services. A particular emphasis was to assess the extent to which language was an obstacle to receiving appropriate primary care. These objectives were achieved by conducting interviews with General Practitioners and focus groups with parents from a number of minority ethnic communities.

Findings

1 Lack of concordance in languages spoken by the GP and children’s parents is the principal barrier to effective use of primary health care services.

2. ‘Ethnic’ patterns in access to services are partly a function of migration history. Migrant groups who do not speak English fluently and who have recently arrived in this country experience greater difficulties in using primary health care services than longer established groups. Considerable evidence of unmet need exists for these groups, especially Somali patients.

3. Bilingual children from minority ethnic groups frequently act as informal interpreters between the GP and parents, when their parents have little or no fluency in English. Considerable uncertainty exists among GPs and among the children’s parents concerning the acceptability and effectiveness of children acting as interpreters, e.g. concerns about misdiagnosis.

4. Where there is linguistic dissonance between GPs and parents, both parties express a preference for trained Health Advocates to attend and mediate consultations.

5. The administrative arrangements of GPs’ practices, and particularly their appointment systems, were a major obstacle to accessing services for all minority ethnic groups. ‘Walk-in’ systems were generally preferred over booked appointment systems by all parents.

6. Greater use of Accident and Emergency departments occurs among children of parents who are not fluent in English, because of lack of Health Advocates and difficulties obtaining out-of hours care.

Conclusions

The study identified that considerable unmet primary health care needs exist for minority ethnic children, particularly among recently established non-English speaking minority groups. The provision of trained bilingual Health Advocates is essential to ensure equitable and effective health care for the whole population. There are major problems associated with minor children acting as informal interpreters in GP consultations for their parents, other relatives and in relation to their own health.

 

]]>

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Professional uncertainty and disempowerment responding to ethnic diversity in health care: a qualitative study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS]]>
document.description: Data from the study was from 18 focus groups with a purposive sample of 106 health professionals of differing disciplines, in primary and secondary care settings, working with patient populations of varying ethnic diversity in the Midlands of the UK. The study suggests potential mechanisms by which health professionals may inadvertently contribute to ethnic disparities in health care.
document.body:
Background

While ethnic disparities in health and health care are increasing, evidence on how to enhance quality of care and reduce inequalities remains limited. Despite growth in the scope and application of guidelines on “cultural competence,” remarkably little is known about how practising health professionals experience and perceive their work with patients from diverse ethnic communities. Using cancer care as a clinical context, we aimed to explore this with a range of health professionals to inform interventions to enhance quality of care.

Methods and Findings

We conducted a qualitative study involving 18 focus groups with a purposive sample of 106 health professionals of differing disciplines, in primary and secondary care settings, working with patient populations of varying ethnic diversity in the Midlands of the UK. Data were analysed by constant comparison and we undertook processes for validation of analysis. We found that, as they sought to offer appropriate care, health professionals wrestled with considerable uncertainty and apprehension in responding to the needs of patients of ethnicities different from their own. They emphasised their perceived ignorance about cultural difference and were anxious about being culturally inappropriate, causing affront, or appearing discriminatory or racist. Professionals' ability to think and act flexibly or creatively faltered. Although trying to do their best, professionals' uncertainty was disempowering, creating a disabling hesitancy and inertia in their practice. Most professionals sought and applied a knowledge-based cultural expertise approach to patients, though some identified the risk of engendering stereotypical expectations of patients. Professionals' uncertainty and disempowerment had the potential to perpetuate each other, to the detriment of patient care.

Conclusions

This study suggests potential mechanisms by which health professionals may inadvertently contribute to ethnic disparities in health care. It identifies critical opportunities to empower health professionals to respond more effectively. Interventions should help professionals acknowledge their uncertainty and its potential to create inertia in their practice. A shift away from a cultural expertise model toward a greater focus on each patient as an individual may help

]]>

]]>

document.title: Project Joy: faith based cardiovascular health promotion for African American women
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
A test on the impact on cardiovascular risk profiles of African American women aged 40 years and over after participating for a year in one of three church based nutrition and physical activity groups.

The three groups involved either a standard behavioural group intervention, the same intervention supplemented with spiritual strategies or self help strategies.

529 women from 16 churches were enrolled in the study.

CEEHD Note: This is an American study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Promoting safer male circumcisions for British Muslims
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,BIRTH]]>
document.body:
Male infant circumcision is the most common surgical procedure in the world, it is commonly performed in Britain by Jewish and Muslim communities for religious reasons. However the procedure is currently not availble on the NHS, this paper considers the faith background to circumcision in UK muslim communities and discusses methods of reducing risks for the procedure.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Promoting social support and social networks among Irish pensioners in South London, UK
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,VOLUNTARY AND COMMUNITY SECTOR,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
An exploration into the activities of an Irish-led voluntary project seeking to minimise social isolation amongst Irish elderly people living in a deprived borough of South London.

Data was collected through 19 semi-structured interviews, observation of project activities and analysis of member case files. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Psychiatric services for black and minority ethnic older people
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,NHS ACTIVITIES,POLICY,SERVICE SECTORS,MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES,SERVICE DELIVERY,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE,INNOVATION AND IMPROVEMENT,CHANGE MANAGEMENT,ENGAGEMENT,LEADING IMPROVEMENT,SAFER CARE]]>
document.body:
This report examines the mental health needs of black and minority ethnic older people and the psychiatric services that are offered to this group as well as focusing on the main changes that have occurred in this area since the original Royal College of Psychiatrists report (2001).

The report includes:

  • Executive summary and recommendations
  • Introduction
  • Definition of black and minority ethnic older people
  • Demographic changes
  • Review of influential publications and policies
  • Research relevant to mental health needs of black and minority ethnic older people
  • Current examples of good practice
  • Revision of recommendations
  • Summary
  • References
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Race and Racism in Northern Ireland
document.publisher: Office of the First Minister and Deputy First Minister
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
The report contains pages on health and ethnic minorities in Ireland and says  "While there has been a number of research studies investigating minority ethnic people’s experiences and needs in relation to health services, there is very little empirical data charting the general health patterns of the minority ethnic population in Northern Ireland (Paris et al. 1995).

Unfortunately, the research by Dunn and Irwin (1996) did not focus on this area. With the exception of Irish Travellers, the only empirical study of current levels of health relates to the Chinese elderly (Braid and Gadd 1999) which found that those studied enjoyed a relatively high level of independence and fairly good levels of health. The types of illnesses and problems faced by this group were those that were to be found among the elderly more generally. However the research did point out that such problems were likely to become more acute in the future as the average age of the Chinese population increases.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Race equality guide 2004: a performance framework
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Following the introduction of the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000 the Commission For Racial Equality commissioned a review of progress on implementing the law across the public sector1 in England and Wales. The report found that overall the health sector had made less progress than other public services. This confirmed the findings of two earlier reports commissioned by the former Director of Health and Social Care for London and the Commission For Racial Equality both of which showed highly variable levels of performance on race equality in London and across the English NHS respectively.

In response, the Department of Health and English SHA Chief Executives agreed to develop a practical guide to support NHS organisations to make  real progress and fulfil their role of promoting social justice through implementing the requirements of the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000 (RRAA) to:

  • Promote equality of opportunity
  • Promote good relations between people of different racial groups
  • Eliminate unlawful discrimination

As the largest provider of public services and the largest employer in the UK, the NHS has huge potential to bring about race equality, harmonious race relations and greater social justice. To achieve this, the NHS needs to move beyond processes and targets and concentrate on better outcomes for patients and staff. NHS policy is increasingly focused on flexible responsive services to meet the needs of patients. Workforce policies such as Improving Working Lives and the Vital Connection similarly set out how the NHS must capitalise on and promote everyone’s skills and value difference and diversity as assets to be cultivated. The Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000 is a natural extension of these themes and should be seen as legislation which will assist organisations to deliver their broader agenda.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Race equality management
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES]]>
document.body:
Aims

The aims of this module are:

  1. To enable understanding of the rationale and principles of race equality management.
  2. To develop an understanding of the current concepts and terminology concerned with race equality management, including managing diversity.
  3. To enable the use of some pragmatic tools for putting race equality management into practice.
  4. To explore how health institutions can embrace race equality management.

Outline Of The Module

This module contains discussion of the following:

  • The context of race equality in Britain, legislation policy and terminology
  • Equality management and diversity management.
  • Changing occupational culture.
  • Policy and planning.
  • Employment  - recruitment and selection, retention, training, grievance and disciplinary, appraisal.
  • Service delivery and customer care.
  • Consultation, partnerships and multi-agency work.
  • Marketing and corporate image.
]]>

document.body:
