The chapters cover legal framework, DoH Race Equality Scheme and its coverage, implementation and monitoring of this scheme and has a detailed discussion on action plan. The policy also contains number of useful tables and annex.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Race Relations Act 1976
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,LEGISLATION,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,POLICY,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,RACE EQUALITY,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
The act makes it illegal to discriminate against or harrass applicants for employment, workers and former workers on the grounds of nationality and colour, or ethnic, or racial, or national group.

The act led to the creation of the Commission for Racial Equality which has since been supplemented by the Equality and Human Rights Commission.

 

In 2000 the act was ammended to include the police and other public authorities and can be viewed on the following link:

Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000

 

In 2003 the act was again ammended to incorporate two pieces of European legislation: The Race Directive and The EC Equal Treatment Framework Directive. The 2003 ammendment can viewed on the following link:

The Race Relations Act 1976 (Amendment) Regulations 2003

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Racism: what is in a word?
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.description: Professor Kamaldeep Bhui presents a challenging aspect of mental healthcare provision by raising the 'unmentionable' issue of racism as an explanation for failure to act in an article contributed to SLEH National Knowledge Week.
document.body:
111-1Racism: what is in a word?

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2007 

Professor Kamaldeep Bhui
MD FRCPsych

Professor of Cultural Psychiatry & Epidemiology
Wolfson Institute of Preventive Medicine
Queen Mary University of London

(Return to Knowledge Week index page.)
Racism: what is in a word?

British mental health policy in general has named ethnic or racial disparities as a major target problem for at least three decades. The terms used to describe this include ethnic inequalities, ethnic disparities, ethnic variations and cultural and racial inequalities, amongst others. Greater emphasis has been given to this topic since social inequalities alone have been demonstrated to explain only part of the disparity in risk of mental health problems. Service users also reporting disrespectful treatment and reporting discrimination in services have added to the demand for a remedy.

Despite mention of prioritising ethnic disparities in policy and service provision over a decade ago, little action was actually taken to implement policy recommendations or to respond to the changing picture of migration, and take account of multiple forms of acculturation.

Between 1999 and 2003, a series of policy documents emerged which were devoted entirely to this issue. Previous efforts at integrated policy had failed, and were never followed through. Now service users were consulted, and they were promised that NHS organizations and staff, and the Department of Health (DH) were serious about tackling the issue. Two stand-alone policy documents were born: ‘Inside Outside’ and ‘Delivering Race Equality’. These were heavily influenced by service users, the grey and published literature, and by multiple forms of evidence as well as social trends in care practices.

Regrettably, there was limited resource for service development or workforce re-design and development emergent from these actions. A split between policy and operational delivery yet again undermined potentially effective policies. There was great emphasis placed on the provision of more information to persuade those who still did not believe that disparities warranted action, or that ethnic codes could be collected in routine practice. The ‘Count Me In’ census was supposed also to act as a driver for change and as a means to measure interagency co-operation to improve care experiences. However, at the same time as the ‘Delivering Race Equality Action Plan’ emerged and began to be delivered, and the ‘Count Me In’ census reported, resistances emerged.

Is institutional racism the right word or paradigm? Concern about the harmful effects of the term, in the absence of confidence in effective service development, has distracted those wanting to tackle ethnic inequalities. A series of high profile publications in the BMJ in 2006 and 2007, and in the Psychiatric Bulletin (October 2007), set out the arguments - many of which deny racism a role. Some of these arguments are in fact rehearsals of the discourse from the 1980s, but have found a new voice in the current era where it is hoped that social inequalities alone will address ethnic disparities in care experiences. A new argument now proffered is that the use of the term ‘institutional racism’ was not helpful and stigmatized services and people who use them. The DH changed its position, forgetting the service users who had been consulted, the promises that had been made, and that the public and service users wanted improvements.

Should we abandon the term racism? Should editors decide to no longer publish materials with the word racism, or with evidence of racism in their findings, even if racism is proffered as an explanation for ethnic differences? There is substantial evidence from systematic reviews and primary quantitative studies that racism is detrimental to mental health. Service users who are victim to this form of prejudice have said for a long time that their experience of being discriminated against on the basis of race, religion, culture and ethnic group is pernicious and undermines both their mental health and trust in a system with which they must co–operate, and through which they must receive care.

Does the word offend, and carry a history of vulgarity and violence? Does it remind people of a crude act of hatred against another? Is it subject to scientific study, or are we likely to encounter pseudoscientific rationales grounded in a positivistic scientific paradigm to the neglect of people’s lived experience and to the wealth of information that mental health institutions are not as caring as they should or could be.

Whilst the UK has been a leader in thinking and knowledge on this issue, fear of a word and fear of not knowing how to manage it appear to be driving people to explore other paradigms. These paradigms do not encompass the historical tones of the word racism. What does the word do to your mind if you are accused, what does it do to the patient or professional who feels powerless to overcome a force that is clearly socially unjust, but explained away as a social phenomenon that indicates either a need for more treatment or an inherent difference in vulnerability to illness by racial or ethnic patterns. In part, the psychodynamics of race thinking already indicate that such a debate results in emotionally charged, value-laden expressions of missions and destiny, and righteousness often blinded to new information and interaction in the shared space of communication. People in such a position may feel persecuted, experiencing ‘bionic’ breaks in linking thoughts and words, resulting in a sense of perplexity and paralysis to act or to challenge.

The final question is how do we not turn a blind eye, not end up in psychic retreats, but engage with the realities of racism, individual or institutional, and consider the evidence on whether and to what extent inequalities can be apportioned to racism.

References and Resources

  1. The following Department of Health (DH) publication can be downloaded in several languages from this DH page:
    'Inside Outside: Improving mental health services for black and minority ethnic communities in England'

  2. Can be downloaded from the Department for Health website:
    Delivering Race Equality: a framework for action

  3. The first ‘Count Me In’ census was in 2005. You can read the report and detailed results of the 2005 census, the 2006 census and subsequent papers at the Mental Healthcare Commission website. Follow these links below:

    'Count Me In' - 2005
    'Count Me In’ - 2006

  4. Website:
    British Medical Journal

  5. Website for October issue:
    Psychiatric Bulletin – October 2007

  6. Coker, N. (Ed) 2001 Racism in medicine: an agenda for change London, King's Fund Publishing.

  7. Karlsen, S., Nazroo, J. 2004 'The relationship between racism, social class and physical and mental health among different ethnic groups in England' Ethnicity & Health 9(1) :S46-47 (and delivered at International Conference, Rotterdam, June 2004).

  8. Marwaha, S., Livingston, G. 2002   "Stigma, racism or choice. Why do depressed ethnic elders avoid psychiatrists?" Journal of Affective Disorders 72(3) :257-265. 
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Ramadan education and awareness in diabetes (READ) programme for Muslims with type 2 diabetes who fast during Ramadan
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET,RELIGION]]>
document.body:
The majority of Muslim diabetic patients are unaware of complications during fasting for Ramadan. This study aims to determine the affect of Ramadan-focused education on weight and hypoglycemic episodes during Ramadan in a type 2 diabetes Muslim population.

A retrospective analysis of two groups was conducted; group A attended a structured education program encompassing information on such topics as physical activity, meal planning and dosage while group B did not.  

]]>

  • Potential medical problems

Rates and standardised mortality ratios (SMRs) following contact with mental health services were calculated using national statistics data from 1996 to 2001. Ethnic groups included in the study were: black Caribbean, black African, south Asian and white.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Reducing health inequalities for lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans people from Black and minority ethnic communities - briefings for health and social care staff
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,ETHNICITY,PUBLIC HEALTH,RACE EQUALITY,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,GAY MEN,BISEXUALS,LESBIANS,TRANSSEXUALS,ALLIED HEALTH PROFESSIONALS,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,HEALTHCARE & HEALTH SERVICES,POLICY,RACE,SEXUALITY,CULTURAL IDENTITY,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body:
The DH has published a series of easy read guides to help commissioners, service planners and frontline staff deliver healthcare to LGBT people. They cover various health topics and offer advice on caring for people of different ages, from various ethnic backgrounds, as well as those with disabilities. Improving access to care is also featured in the guides.

 

Lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans (LGBT) people experience a number of health inequalities which are often unrecognised in health and social care settings. These briefings are intended to show that LGBT people can be younger, older, bisexual, lesbians, gay men, trans, from black and minority ethnic (BME) communities and disabled, and to dispel assumptions that they form a homogeneous group.

 

They aim to inform the delivery of appropriate services and to support health and social care professionals in their everyday work with LGBT people by providing fundamental awareness and evidence of LGBT needs in relation to health.

 

The briefing number 12 is specifically about LGB people from Black and minority ethnic communities, however providers and commissioners may need to read that in the context of the set of all briefings about LGB health inequalities. For complete set of briefings please click here

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Referring clients for medico-legal reports
document.publisher: Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
This guidance provided by the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture (MFCVT) provides information to representatives and organisations that need to refer victims of torture seeking asylum to the UK to the MFCVT for a medico-legal report in support of their case.

The following information is included:

  • The legal implications of producing and submitting a medico-legal report
  • The procedure of referral for the production of the report
  • Basic information the MFCVT requires to produce a report
  • The relationship between the timing of the referral to the MFCVT, the asylum process and funding from the 'Legal Services Commission'.
  • Fees for the production of the report

Links are included throughout the guidance to useful organisations, specific paragraphs of UK asylum policy, and other relevant documents.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Religion or belief: a practical guide for the NHS
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION]]>
document.body:
This guidance document is part of a group of equality guides produced by the Department of Health, giving practical advice to NHS organisations to help them comply with equality legislation, understand the role of religion or belief in a healthcare context, and integrate this knowledge into single equality schemes (SESs).

The guidance includes information on:

  • The current policy context.
  • Key areas to consider in employment, including: recruitment, training, healthcare chaplains, and proselytising.
  • Key areas to consider in providing services, such as: diet, modesty and other matters, contraception, palliative care, and end of life concerns.
  • How to integrate issues on religion or belief into action planning for single equality schemes.
  • A list of resources
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Religious beliefs about causes and treatment of epilepsy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS,PEOPLE WITH LONG TERM & CHRONIC CONDITIONS,TRADITIONAL MEDICINE AND TREATMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study explored the influences of spiritual and religious beliefs on explanation of the cause of epilepsy, and the choice of treatment in people of South Asian origin who have epilepsy.

 

The study includes Muslims, Sikhs, and Hindus with epilepsy, carers (family members, friends); health professionals (specialist GPs, neurologists, specialists nurses, social workers, community GPs); and two focus groups including South Asians without epilepsy.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Religious circumcision and the Human Rights Act
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,RELIGION,BIRTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Renal Transplantation and Ethnicity
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,GASTROENTEROLOGY,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,KIDNEY DISEASES,TRANSPLANT OPERATION,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,TRANSPLANTATION,ASSESSMENT/SELECTION,DONOR,RECIPIENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Renal Transplantation and Ethnicity

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2008

 

Robert Higgins

FRCP MD MBBCh


Consultant Nephrologist,
Department of Nephrology and Transplantation,
University Hospital
Coventry

Renal transplantation is the best treatment for established renal failure. There are over 20,000 patients alive with a kidney transplant in the UK, and over 500,000 worldwide.  The incidence of renal failure affects the demand for renal transplantation, and this varies considerably by ethnicity (ref 1). Although this variation has often been perceived by Western researchers as high rates of renal failure amongst those of black or south Asian ethnicity, an international perspective suggests that it may be that those of white ethnicity have a low rate of renal failure compared to most other ethnic groups (ref 2).

 

Disparities affecting ethnic minority groups
An excess in the demand for transplantation in those of non-white ethnicity is compounded by reduced donation rates. In the UK, as in many western countries, the rate of deceased organ donation is lower in non-white ethnic groups than in the white majority population (ref 3). During a study period in 2003-4, 4% of the UK population was of south Asian ethnicity, compared to 13% on the transplant list, and 1% of deceased donors (ref 1). The reasons for the reduced donation rates are not fully clear; a reduced family consent rate is important, but also it is possible that there are proportionately fewer suitable organ donors on intensive care units from non-white ethnic groups.


 

Clinical differences
The distribution of tissue types (human leucocyte antigens, HLA) is important, since matching donor and recipient types improves clinical outcomes. As there are variations between combinations of tissue types by ethnic group, a strong matching policy tends to reduce the numbers of organs transplanted between ethnic groups. One study in the UK showed that under the strict tissue type matching policy in place in the 1990’s, those of non-white ethnicity had half the chance of getting a transplant compared to those of white ethnicity (ref 3). Blood group distribution can also affect transplantation. Amongst those of south Asian ethnicity, blood group B is common, and this reduces the chance of getting a blood group identical transplant. In the UK, this has been balanced by allowing a certain number of blood group O kidneys to be transplanted into those of blood group B each year (ref 1).

 

Development in policy
The 2006 kidney allocation policy in the UK was a significant departure from the previous policy, allocating kidneys preferentially by recipient waiting time, rather than HLA matching. The development of this allocation policy was informed by an equity working group, and the impact of ethnicity on transplant rates is now ameliorated, and any ongoing effects monitored at least annually (ref 1).

Photo by delayed gratification - License

Living donor transplantation is increasing in volume in most countries, and internationally accounts for as many transplants as from deceased donors. It is less clear how ethnicity affects the numbers of living donors coming forwards in the UK, but one randomised study in the USA indicated that a culturally sensitive education programme could increase enquiries from potential living donors in the African-American community (ref 4).

 

Inequality in outcome
Outcomes after transplantation are also affected by ethnicity. In the USA it has been clear for some years that early acute rejection and long term graft survival are worse in patients of African American ethnicity than of white ethnicity. The reasons for this seem to include an increased immune responsiveness, partly explained by worse HLA matching between donor and recipient, and also worse outcomes associated with social status (ref 5). In the UK, graft survival is also worse in those of black ethnicity compared to those of white ethnicity, but those of south Asian ethnicity do not seem to be disadvantaged (ref 1). Quality of life is also linked to ethnicity, but this may be associated with the social status of a particular ethnic group, rather than differences in the outcome of a transplant (ref 6). Other complications of transplantation are associated with ethnicity, especially new onset diabetes after transplantation, which is more frequent in those of black and south Asian ethnicity (refs 7, 8). There is a need to design large randomised trials that will determine whether any of the choices in immunosuppressive therapy that have become available recently will benefit particular ethnic groups.

 

International differences
On an international perspective there are significant variations in access to and results of transplantation (ref 9). As expected, transplantation may be less well developed in poorer countries, but even amongst wealthy nations variations exist with some countries (eg Japan) where deceased donor transplantation seldom takes place, and others (eg France, Spain) where living donor transplantation is infrequent. These differences are mostly accounted for by political, social and economic factors, rather than genetic differences between populations. However, particularly given the recent increase in commercial transplantation, mostly in poorer countries, development of best practices in transplantation on an international basis is a priority.

In summary, as with other areas of society and medicine, ethnicity is an important factor impacting on the practice of renal transplantation, with both cultural and biological differences between ethnic groups affecting access to, and the results of, renal transplantation.


References

  1. Rudge C, Johnson RJ, Fuggle SV, Forsythe JL; Kidney and Pancreas Advisory Group, UK Transplant NHS BT. Renal transplantation in the United Kingdom for patients from ethnic minorities. Transplantation. 2007 May 15;83(9):1169-73
    [view abstract]

  2. Feehally J. Ethnicity and renal disease. Kidney Int. 2005 Jul;68(1):414-24.
    [information on access] institutional subscription may be required

  3. Higgins RM, West N, Edmunds ME, Dukes DC, Kashi H, Jurewicz A, Lam FT. Effect of a strict HLA matching policy on distribution of cadaveric kidney transplants to Indo-Asian and white European recipients: regional study. British Medical Journal 1997; 315: 1354-1355
    [link to full text]

  4. Rodrigue JR, Cornell DL, Kaplan B, Howard RJ. A randomized trial of a home-based educational approach to increase live donor kidney transplantation: effects in blacks and whites. Am J Kidney Dis. 2008 Apr;51(4):663-70.
    [view abstract]

  5. Press R, Carrasquillo O, Nickolas T, Radhakrishnan J, Shea S, Barr RG. Race/ethnicity, poverty status, and renal transplant outcomes. Transplantation. 2005 Oct 15;80(7):917-24.
    [view abstract]

  6. Bakewell A, Higgins RM, Edmunds ME. Does ethnicity influence perceived quality of life of patients on dialysis and following renal transplant? Nephrology Dialysis Transplantation 2001; 16: 1395-1401
    [link to full text]

  7. Dooldeniya MD, Dupont PJ, He X, Johnson RJ, Joshi T, Basra R, Johnston A, Warrens AN. Renal transplantation in Indo-Asian patients in the UK. Am J Transplant. 2006 Apr;6(4):761-9
    [link to full text]

  8. Montori VM, Basu A, Erwin PJ, Velosa JA, Gabriel SE, Kudva YC  Posttransplantation diabetes: a systematic review of the literature. Diabetes Care. 2002 Mar;25(3):583-9
    [link to full text]

  9. Danovitch GM. Cultural barriers to kidney transplantation: a new frontier. Transplantation. 2007 Aug 27;84(4):462-3.
    [view details]

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Report on the self reported experience of patients from black and minority ethnic groups
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY]]>
document.body:
Report and analysis of the experience of patients in black and minority ethnic groups.

This 31 page report examines variations in the self-reported views of NHS patients from different ethnic groups. These results give an insight into the areas of NHS service provision where experience of the service looks different to patients from different ethnic groups.

Results are based on data from the National Patient Survey programme, led by the Healthcare Commission.  The report reveals that Asian and Chinese groups were less likely to give positive responses about services, while black patients’ views were more mixed.  It includes a statistical analysis of results.

Link to key points 

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This study investigated the ethnic profile of six clinical trials conducted by the Northern and Yorkshire Clincial Trials and Research Unit to determine the representation of south Asian people in randomised controlled trials.

The study found that south Asian participants comprised 1.7% of total participants for the six trials. The study concludes that south Asian people are under represented in clinical trials.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Results of a faith-based weight loss intervention for black women
document.publisher: Journal of the National Medical Association.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
Obesity is a risk factor for a variety of chronic diseases. Although weight loss may reduce these risks, weight loss programs designed for black women have yielded mixed results. Studies suggest that religion/spirituality is a prominent component of black culture. Given this, the inclusion of religion/spirituality as an active component of a weight loss program may enhance the benefits of the program. The role of religion/spirituality, however, has not been specifically tested as a mechanism that enhances the weight loss process.

This paper presents the results of "Faith on the Move," a randomized pilot study of a faith-based weight loss program for black women. The goals of the study were to estimate the effects of a 12-week culturally tailored, faith-based weight loss intervention on weight loss, dietary fat consumption and physical activity. The culturally tailored, faith-based weight loss intervention was compared to a culturally tailored weight loss intervention with no active faith component. Fifty-nine overweight/obese black women were randomized to one of the two interventions. Although the results were not statistically significant, the effect size suggests that the addition of the faith component improved results. These promising preliminary results will need to be tested in an adequately powered trial. (Cochrane text)

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: Please be aware that this resource is based on non-UK populations, and may not be directly transferable to the UK.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Review article: diabetes, genetics and ethnicity
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ There is evidence that the prevalence of insulin resistance and diabetes has increased dramatically over the past few decades in western countries this is now evident in countries that are adopting a western lifestyle. Previous studies in multiethnic populations suggest that some ethnic groups may have a predisposition to diabetes, this review looks at the evidence available for the influence of genetic factors in relation to insulin resistance and diabetes and ethnicity.  ]]>

document.title: Review of diabetes management and guidelines during Ramadan
document.publisher: Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,RELIGION]]>
document.body:
This review of diabetes management and guidelines during Ramadan includes information on:

  • The physiology of fasting
  • The pathophysiology of fasting in patients with diabetes
  • Current evidence of diabetes and fasting
  • Management of patients with type 1 diabetes
  • Management of patients with type 2 diabetes
  • Recommendations on the management of diabetes during fasting

'Fasting', 'diabetes' and 'Ramadan' were used as keywords to search Pubmed databases.  73 articles published between 1989 and 2009 were identified, these were then classified according to hierarchy of evidence.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Rheumatoid arthritis and ethnic minorities in Britain
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,MAJOR INFLAMMATORY,RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL]]>
document.description: An urgent need to improve the evidence base
document.body:
111-1Rheumatoid arthritis and ethnic minorities in Britain

An urgent need to improve the evidence base

For the first time, the Conference of the British Society for Rheumatology and the allied British Health Professionals in Rheumatology, meeting in Liverpool this week, will hold a dedicated discussion session on ‘Ethnicity’. Chair of the session, Dr Ash Samanta will be arguing for more attention to the topic on three grounds: the changing population demography of the UK, the variations in this disease across minority ethnic groups, and the need to recognise a statutory obligation to address ‘racial’ and ethnic inequality.

We also welcome the the Musculoskeletal Specialist Library's National Knowledge Week on Rheumatoid Arthritis, including an Annual Evidence Update. [visit the Musculoskeletal Specialist Library]

Photo by Sparky              License     

Variations in prevalence:
Confusingly, there is little reliable evidence on prevalence or incidence of RA in minority populations either in UK or in their countries of origin: at present it might be lower in the Indian subcontinent and Far East [ref 1], higher in Jamaica and Latin America [ref 2] or somewhere inbetween [ref 3]. Basically, it seems that no-one really knows whether it is ethnic group, location, class and occupation or ‘competing conditions and diagnostic artefact’ that explains these observed variations.

Ethnic differences in disease:
To add to this mass of uncertainty, there seems to be some evidence of differing presentations, natural history and response to treatment among some ethnic groups [refs 4-6]. Again, this impression is based on patchy data from a diversity of differing locations and groups – only one ethnic group (apart from the White majority) has been studied in overwhelming detail, and that (the Pima Indians) is a Native American society which is little represented in UK populations [ref 7].

Where do we go from here?
There are so many significant gaps in the research evidence that nearly any research will be helpful – but it must be of high quality, record ethnicity in sensitive ways, and if possible, be linked to practical interventions and patient information that is ‘culturally competent’. At present, all we can locate that seems to speak to the concerns of our users are highly technical papers on variations in bio-chemistry, or studies validating differing instruments to measure pain and quality of life [refs 8-9]  which while useful, do not address these needs.

The NLH Specialist libraries as a group are committed to locating and developing a ‘database of uncertainties’ to inform future research agendas and welcome feedback from our users (Please use this link - Contact Us - or the 'Contact Us' button above if you would like to raise ethnicity-specific issues).

References

  1. Chandrasekaran AN, Radhakrishna B. Rheumatoid arthritis and connective tissue disorders: India and South-East Asia. Balliere's Clinical Rheumatology 1995  9,1 :45-57 [view abstract]

  2. Mijiyawa M.  Epidemiology and semiology of rheumatoid arthritis in Third World countries. Revue du Rheumatisme 1995  62,2:121-126 [view abstract]

  3. Hameed K, Gibson T.  A comparison of the prevalence of rheumatoid arthritis and other rheumatic diseases amongst Pakistanis living in England and Pakistan.  British Journal of Rheumatology 1997 36, :781-785  [view abstract]

  4. Graham TB, Glass DN.  Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis: ethnic differences in diagnostic types. The Journal of Rheumatology 1997  24,9 :1677-1678  [view abstract]

  5. Jacono J, Jacono B, Cano P, Segami M, Rubin L.  An epidemiological study of rheumatoid arthritis in a northern Ontario clinical practice: the role of ethnicity. Journal of Advanced Nursing 1996  24 :31-35  [view full text]

  6. Griffiths B, Situnayake D, Clarke B, Tennant A, Salmon M, Emery P.  Racial origin and its effect on disease expression and HLA-DRB1 types in patients with rheumatoid arthritis: a matched cross sectional study.  Rheumatology 2000; 39: 857-864  [download pdf]

  7. Samanta A, Samanta J, Johnson MRD, Brooks N.  2005  Rheumatoid arthritis in minority ethnic groups: patterns of disease, clinical and sociocultural features among British South Asians.  Diversity in Health & Social Care 2,2 :99-118  [view detail]

  8. Bedi GS,  Gupta N,  Handa R.  Pal H,  Pandey RM.   Quality of life in Indian patients with rheumatoid arthritis.  Quality of Lift Research 2005  14(8):1953-8 [view abstract]

  9. Vlaar AP,  ten Klooster PM,  Taal E,  Gheith RE,  El-Garf AK,  Rasker JJ,  van de Laar MA.  A cross-cultural study of pain intensity in Egyptian and Dutch women with rheumatoid arthritis.  Journal of Pain 2007 8(9):730-6  [view abstract]
]]>

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory condition that may lead to long term disablility, attention to ethnic variation adds an important dimension to the understanding of the disease by health professionals as well as improving clinical outcomes.

This study finds that published medical literature about RA pays little attention to south Asians or other minority ethnic groups in the UK.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Rubella seroprevalence in pregnant women in North Thames: estimates based on newborn screening samples
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,INFECTIONS,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH,VACCINE PREVENTABLE DISEASES,RUBELLA,POPULATION GROUPS,ADULTS,PREGNANT WOMEN,MICROORGANISM,VIRUSES,RUBELLA VIRUS,OCT 09,ADDED 2009]]>
document.body:
Routine screening for rubella susceptibility is important so that women found to be susceptible can be offered immunisation in the post partum period. This study demonstrates the use of newborn dried blood spot samples that are linked to routine vital statistics datasets to monitor the susceptibility to rubella in pregnant women and investigates maternal characteristics as determinants of rubella seronegativity.

18,882 newborn screening blood spot samples were used. The study found that mothers born abroad particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia were more likely to be seronegative than UK born mothers. The study recommends that vaccination is targeted specifically at migrant women and their families.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Schizophrenia and ethnic minorities in Britain
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH]]>
document.description: An urgent need to improve the evidence base
document.body:
111-1Schizophrenia and ethnic minorities in Britain

An Urgent Need to Improve the Evidence Base

We welcome attention paid to schizophrenia by the Mental Health Specialist Library in their Schizophrenia Annual Evidence Update 2008.  This has been an issue which has exercised much debate among those concerned with the health of ethnic minorities in Britain. [link to Mental Health Specialist Library Schizophrenia Annual Evidence Update] 

This is perhaps one area where we have more data on ‘ethnic differentials’ than any other health topic, but still no satisfactory explanations or interventions and policy changes to address the inequalities found.

UK data: 

The national survey “Count Me In” [see references below] continues to show raised levels of admission – 22% of inpatients in the 2007 report were of ‘BME’ origin, and overwhelmingly of Black (African-Caribbean, Black British or Mixed Black) origin – also still frequently under ‘forensic’ non-voluntary admission.  These patterns have been repeated over every year of the survey and in all data reviewed by us.

Ethnic differences in mental health:

It is well established that mental health is a condition that might be culturally defined – or at least, where cultural expressions of distress vary and the use of language as both a diagnostic and therapeutic tool is critical.  Throughout recent research history in Britain, there have been many studies demonstrating that people of South Asian descent are rarely found using ‘mental health services’ (Patel 2003), while those, especially young males, of African-Caribbean descent are more likely to be found diagnosed with affective disorders, but surprisingly perhaps, rarely with depressive disorders. The general literature associates schizophrenia in particular with migration and social exclusion (references: Hutchinson 2004; Eaton 2000) and shows also that these effects are found across Europe, although tantalisingly that different migrant minorities appear to be the most at risk in different states.

 

Photo by Erik Herrera License

A number of hypotheses for these differentials have been proposed: clearly, it seems that migration itself is a risk factor, and that genetic explanations (that people of Black/African-Caribbean background are of higher risk) do not hold water (Hutchinson, Ramcharan, Ghany 2003:  Sharpley et al 2001), but that social environmental factors – possibly including the experience of racism, are increasingly likely (Mahy et al 1999), especially when considering rates in the originating “source areas” of UK migrant populations (Hickling 2005).

Where do we go from here?

There remain significant gaps in the research evidence. One of these is any evidence of interventions that have proven effective in prevention of these differentials – and the other is of treatments. We would therefore draw readers' attention to the recent review by the Race Equality Foundation (Keating 2007) and a guide from the Social Care Instituite for Excellence (Newbigging 2008).  It was interesting, in this context, to locate a paper from India that suggests that schizophrenic conditions are both found, and conventionally treated, in the Indian sub-continent, although rarely referred to in South Asian populations in Britain (Patel & Andrade 2003). Selten and colleagues (2007) propose that ‘social defeat’ has a biochemical effect – and we might ask therefore if there is any evidence that social interventions to raise morale and improve socio-economic outcomes, reduce the incidence of this condition in the identified at-risk populations, and that low rates in other migrant populations are attributable to higher social success rates?

Note: we also would like to encourage readers to support the James Lind Alliance and Swansea University survey to identify uncertainties about mental health treatment and care.  [visit the survey page]  The NLH Specialist libraries as a group are committed to locating and developing a ‘database of uncertainties’ to inform future research agendas and welcome feedback from our users (Please Contact Us if you would like to raise ethnicity-specific issues.)
 

References 

Count me in 2007:  results of the 2007 national census of inpatients in mental health and learning disability services in England and Wales. (2007) Published by: 2007 Commission for Healthcare Audit and Inspection. ISBN:  978-1-84562-165-0   [view detail]

Eaton, W.; Harrison, G.  'Ethnic disadvantage and schizophrenia'. Acta Psychiatrica Scandinavica Vol 102(Suppl407) Dec 2000, 38-43.  [view abstract]

Hickling, F. W. 'The epidemiology of schizophrenia and other common mental health disorders in the English-speaking Caribbean'. Pan American Journal of Public Health 18(4-5): 256-62. 2005 [view abstract]

Hutchinson G.; Haasen, C. 'Migration and schizophrenia: the challenges for European psychiatry and implications for the future'. Social Psychiatry & Psychiatric Epidemiology 39(5): 350-7.  [view abstract]

Hutchinson, G.; Ramcharan,C.; Ghany, K. 'Gender and ethnicity in first admissions to a psychiatric unit in Trinidad'. West Indian Medical Journal 52(4): 300-3. 2003  [view abstract]

Keating, Frank; (2007) African and Caribbean men and mental health.  London: Race Equality Foundation (Better Health Briefing 5)  [view detail]

Mahy, G. E.; et al. 'First-contact incidence rate of schizophrenia on Barbados'.  British Journal of Psychiatry 175: 28-33.  1999 [view abstract]

Newbigging, Karen; et al. (2008). Commissioning and providing mental health advocacy for African and Caribbean men. London: Social Care Institute for Excellence (SCIE Resource guide 10) [view detail]

Patel, V.; Andrade, C. 'Pharmacological treatment of severe psychiatric disorders in the developing world: lessons from India'. CNS Drugs 17(15): 1071-80. 2003  [view abstract]

Stelten, J.-P.; Cantor-Graae, E.; Kahn, R.S. 'Migration and schizophrenia'. Current Opinion in Psychiatry Vol 20(2) Mar 2007, 111-115.  [view abstract]

Sharpley, M.; et al.  'Understanding the excess of psychosis among the African-Caribbean population in England'. British Journal of Psychiatry Vol 178(Suppl40) Apr 2001, s60-s68.  [view abstract]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Screening for Cancer
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,CULTURAL COMPETENCE]]>
document.description: Julietta Patnick (Director, NHS Cancer Screening Programmes) considers issues associated with effective delivery of screening to minority ethnic populations.
document.body:
111-1Screening for Cancer

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2007

Julietta Patnick CBE BA(Hons) FFPH
Director
NHS Cancer Screening Programmes

Cancer Screening Programmes

The NHS Cancer Screening Programmes (NHSCSP) currently offer programmes for breast screening of women aged 50 and over and cervical screening for women aged 25-64, as well as a new bowel cancer screening for both men and women aged 60 and over. Screening can identify cancer at an early stage, when there is a better chance of successful treatment and recovery. In the case of cervical screening, cell changes can be detected even before cancer has the chance to develop.

In terms of the UK’s ethnic minority populations, evidence has been in existence for some time of lower uptake by certain groups for breast and cervical screening, although much of this evidence is dated. Research from other parts of the world also reports lower uptake of cancer screening by minority ethnic populations, including reports from the United States for Black Americans and from Europe for immigrant populations.  However, few studies correct uptake figures for differences in deprivation, so the possibility of socio-economic status acting as a confounding variable cannot be discounted.

In the UK, the main reasons for low uptake by ethnic minority populations are consistently reported as being lack of knowledge and poor clinical communication, (references 1, 2, 3, and 4). The NHSCSP has commissioned work looking at access to screening for minority groups which draws similar conclusions, (references 5 and 6) .

In 2004, a report from the National Screening Committee on Ethnic issues in screening emphasised a number of key areas for improvement in cancer screening (reference 7). These included that all people invited for screening must be given the information they need to make their own decision about whether to attend or not. Ensuring public access to information is one of the specific duties imposed upon the NHS by the Race Relations Amendment Act. A number of leaflets are produced by the NHSCSP to help individuals understand the screening process, what results may be received from screening, and what happens if a potential problem is detected. These leaflets outline the benefits and disadvantages of screening, so that each person can make up their mind to attend (or not), based on what factors are most important to them. The key information leaflets are now available in 18 languages (plus English) at references 8, 9 and 10 below.

Because people from ethnic minority communities may be unable to read information, even if provided in their own language, key screening leaflets have also been recorded onto CD in the top six most requested languages - Arabic, Bengali, Cantonese, Polish, Punjabi and Urdu - (plus English).  These can be accessed at references 11, 12, and 13 below.

The 2004 National Screening Committee report, along with much research, emphasised the importance of ensuring that materials are culturally sensitive. The NHSCSP has commissioned a DVD on breast screening, developed via a participatory action research project involving both health professionals and members of the language communities represented (Mirpuri, Sylheti, Cantonese and Mandarin). The DVD is available to staff working within the NHS (details at reference 14).

Research evidence on the effectiveness of various interventions to improve cancer screening uptake by minority groups appears to indicate that a combination of access-enhancing and individual-directed strategies is most likely to be effective (reference 15). From individual studies, there is some evidence to support use of training programme for GP receptionists, mailing of translated literature (with physician endorsement), peer educators (community health educators), use of ethnic media, photoessays (pictures with translated text) and use of mobile mammography to bring services closer to communities (reference 7).

In 2006, the NHS Bowel Cancer Screening Programme was launched, and this will be fully rolled out across England by mid-2009. An evaluation of uptake by ethnic minority populations, commissioned as part of the English Pilot for this new programme, indicated significantly lower uptake by south Asian populations, even after correction for deprivation and other demographic factors (reference 16). The NHSCSP has funded a 3D medical animation DVD, with both physician and patient information, to show the colonoscopy procedure including the identification and removal of bowel polyps. The DVD is presented in English, Bengali, Cantonese, Gujarati, Punjabi and Urdu online.  (Access it through reference 17.)

To date, the NHS SLEH has identified a selection of useful electronic resources to help address ethnic issues related to cancer screening and is actively seeking new research and good quality information on approaches to support improved cancer screening uptake.

Over the coming year, we expect that these will be added to every month, and that new research will assist not only those involved in existing breast and cervical screening programmes but also those implementing the new bowel cancer screening programme nationally. We also hope that users will provide feedback on these materials and recommend new or well-evaluated resources of their own to share.

 

References and Resources

  1. Barriers to effective uptake of cancer screening among black and minority ethnic groups 
    Link to PubMed

  2. Breast screening and ethnic minority women: a literature review
    Link to PubMed

  3. Breast health information needs of women from minority ethnic groups
    Link to PubMed

  4. Woman to Woman: promoting cervical screening amongst minority ethnic women in primary care
    Link to Specialist Library reference

  5. Inequalities of Access to Cancer Screening: a literature review
    NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website
  6. Straight Talking: communicating breast screening information in primary care
    NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website
  7. Ethnic issues in screening
    SLEH website

  8. Breast Screening - the facts 
    Leaflets in several languages at the NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website 

  9. Cervical Screening - the facts
    Leaflets in several languages at the NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website
     
  10. Bowel Cancer Screening - the facts
    Leaflets in several languages at the NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website

  11. Breast Screening
    Audio-visual recording on CD in several languages at the NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website

  12. Cervical Screening
    Audio-visual recording on CD in several languages at the NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website

  13. Bowel Cancer Screening
    Audio-visual recording on CD in several languages at the NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website

  14. DVD - Breast Screening 
    Available through the NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website 
     
  15. The effectiveness of interventions to promote mammography among women with historically lower rates of screening
    Summary on this site.
     
  16. Download a pdf (1716 kb) from the NHS Cancer Screening Programmes website using this link:
    Ethnicity:  UK Colorectal Cancer Screening Pilot Final Report

  17. DVD  - Educational 3D medical animation about colonoscopy in several languages
    Link to website where downloads can be found

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Screening for Haemoglobinopathies
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,BLOOD DISORDERS]]>
document.description: Dr. Allison Streetly, (Programme Director, NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme), considers issues associated with effective delivery of screening to minority ethnic populations.
document.body:
111-1Screening for Haemoglobinopathies

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2007

Dr. Allison Streetly

Director,
NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme

Screening for Haemoglobinopathies

Sickle cell and thalassaemia are among the world’s most commonly inherited genetic disorders. In England, sickle cell is as common as cystic fibrosis. Sickle cell disease affects an estimated 12,500 people, with a further 240,000 thought to be carriers. Similarly, there are approximately 214,000 carriers of thalassaemia with around 700 people suffering from thalassaemia major, the most severe form of the disease. Sickle cell disease presently affects more than 1 in every 2400 births in the UK. With population movement, sickle cell and thalassaemia are both increasingly common in countries of Northern and Western Europe (reference 1 below).

The NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme was set up in England in 2001. It is the world’s first linked antenatal and newborn screening programme (reference 2). The programme recommends antenatal screening, by the end of 12 weeks of pregnancy, as follows:

  • In areas of high prevalence (sickle cell disease >1.5 per 10,000 births) all women are offered screening for sickle cell disease (SCD) and thalassaemia irrespective of family origins.
  • In areas of low prevalence (SCD <1.5 per 10,000 births) all women are offered screening for thalassaemia. A family origin questionnaire is used to assess risk of SCD and other haemoglobin variants (3). If this reveals a high risk for either the woman or baby’s father, the woman is also offered screening for sickle cell.

The newborn screening programme offers screening for SCD to all infants as an integral part of the newborn bloodspot screening programme.

The highest prevalence of SCD is found among people of Black Caribbean and Black African descent, with a high risk of sudden death in the early years of life. SCD is the commonest cause of stroke in childhood in the UK; the peak incidence is between the ages of 2 and 7 years, and by the age of 10 about 6% of children have suffered clinical strokes. Children can be screened for narrowing of intracerebral blood vessels from the age of 2 years by transcranial Doppler (TCD) scanning. The STOP trial has shown that use of TCD and regular blood transfusions for identified children can reduce the risk of stroke by 90% (4). Findings have been incorporated into NHS Clinical Guidelines (NHS Sickle cell and Thalassaemia screening programme (5).

Thalassaemias are less common than SCD, with the highest prevalence found among Cypriots, Indians, Pakistanis, Bangladeshis, Chinese, and other Asian groups.Because both conditions can restrict a child’s or an adult’s ability to conduct normal daily activities, they can also have profound psychosocial effects on individuals and their families (6). Proper management and early detection can improve quality of life. For SCD, this enables parents/guardians to learn to recognise certain risk factors in their child, avoiding those that can trigger painful ‘crisis’ attacks, and administering antibiotics each day to prevent infections (7). Children with thalassaemia major (the most severe form of thalassaemia) will require blood transfusions every four to six weeks and can suffer from chronic diseases (such as diabetes), growth or puberty failure (8).

The National Institute of Clinical Guidance is currently consulting on revised guidelines for routine care of pregnant women, including revised guidance on screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia (9). Research funded by the NHS Health Technology Assessment Programme is underway to examine experience of communicating carrier status information following newborn screening in order to identify how current practice can be improved (10). 

Access to Screening

Women should ideally be offered testing as soon as possible after first contact with the NHS (11). Previous research has identified that women may not receive counselling and testing in time to allow reproductive choice (12).  Recent research suggests that GPs lack the confidence to provide basic prenatal genetic advice to women at risk of the commonest recessive disorders.  Where the couple both carry thalassaemia, there appears to be particularly low confidence combined with poor awareness of the importance of rapid referral to prenatal diagnostic services (13).  Such findings emphasise the challenge of raising awareness amongst primary care professionals if the screening programme is to achieve its objectives.

Clearly, it is important that awareness of issues such as those outlined above should be more widely disseminated among both health care professionals and the public. The NHS Library can play a key role in making the evidence and guidance available but it remains the responsibility of health care staff, both doctors and nurses and health promotion workers, to ensure that this information is widely known in communities at risk, which now can be said to include the whole population.

 

References and Resources 

  1. In PubMed:
    Modell B, et al. Epidemiology of haemoglobin disorders in Europe: an overview. in 'Scand J Clin Lab Invest'  2007;67(1):39-69

  2. Screening Programme website:
    NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme

  3. pdf at the NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme website:
    Family Origins Questionnaire (with Guidance for Health Care Professionals) pdf 998kb

  4. Access at the 'Blood' journal website:
    Lee MT, Piomelli S, Granger S, Miller ST, Harkness S, Brambilla DJ et al. Stroke Prevention Trial in Sickle Cell Anemia (STOP): extended follow-up and final results. in 'Blood' 2006;108:847-52

  5. From the website of the NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme
    Sickle cell disease in childhood. Standards and guidelines for clinical care. Oct 2006

  6. See summary in this library
    Thomas VJ, Hambleton I, Serjeant G. Psychological distress and coping in sickle cell disease: comparison of British and Jamaican attitudes. in 'Ethn Health' 2001 May;6(2):129-36

  7. See summary in this library:
    Thomas VJ, Gruen R, Shu S. Cognitive-behavioural therapy for the management of sickle cell disease pain: identification and assessment of costs. Ethn Health 2001 Feb;6(1):59-67

  8. Here are two websites with information about thalassaemia major and how thalassaemia is treated:

    www.cmht.nwest.nhs.uk/directorates/nebata/major.asp

    www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/dci/Diseases/Thalassemia/
    Thalassemia_Treatments.html

  9. Full documentation of the Nice Guidelines revision on the NICE website:
    NICE Guidelines revision: Antenatal care: routine care for the health pregnant woman

  10. Website:
    Health Technology Assessment Programme

  11. A 64 page pdf can be downloaded here:
    Standards for the linked Antenatal and Newborn Screening Programme

  12. Details of the book at Elsevier:
    Dyson, SM (2005) Ethnicity and Screening for Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia. Churchill Livingstone, 2005

  13. Details and abstract from 'Family Practice' website:
    Qureshi N, Armstrong S, Modell B. GPs' opinions of their role in prenatal genetic services: a cross-sectional survey. Family Practice 23(1):106-10, 2006

 

]]>

document.title: Screening for postnatal depression in Bengali women: preliminary observations from using a translated version of the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS)
document.publisher: Journal of Reproductive Health and Infant Psychology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body:
The majority of screening or treatment studies for postnatal depression have been conducted using white European populations, this study describes the development and use of a Bengali version of the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS).

48 Bangladeshi postnatal women were interviewed in England and Bangladesh by a Syhletti/Bengali speaker.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Securing recruitment and obtaining informed consent in minority ethnic groups in the UK
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
This study addresses percieved difficulites in carrying out health research with respondents from minority ethnic backgrounds by developing audio-recorded methods of obtaining informed consent and recording data.

The study uses a sample of respondents with type 2 diabetes who's main language is spoken and not written, respondents were recruited by two researchers from south Asian backgrounds.

The study finds that audio-recorded methods of obtaining informed consent are easy to implement and are an acceptable alternative to written consent.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Seldom heard: developing inclusive participation in social care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,OLDER PEOPLE,PEOPLE WITH MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This position paper provides a practice framework to help practitioners and managers of social care services enable the inclusive, everyday participation of people from ‘seldom-heard’ groups.

The study focuses on four groups: homeless people with addiction problems, people from black and minority ethnic communities, people with communication impairments and people with dementia. The Social Care Institute of Excellence (SCIE) has identified these people as less likely to be heard by practitioners, managers and decision makers because of the way that services and institutions operate.

Debates about participation have tended to talk about ‘hard to reach’ people, suggesting that there is something about these individuals that prevents their engagement with services. ‘Seldom heard’ is a relatively new term, which stresses the responsibility of agencies to reach out to excluded people, ensuring that they have access to social care services and that their voices can be heard.

The proposed framework is based on findings from previous research, a brief literature search and primary case study research. The visual model was developed to show how, through confidence building and organisational support, practitioners and people who use services can work together to move from participation as an add-on to participation as an integrated, everyday way of working. The practice framework and the model are offered as a starting point for others to test and develop.

 

]]>

document.title: Self report in clinical and epidemiological studies with non-English speakers: the challenge of language and culture
document.publisher: Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
One important aspect of the drive for equality in health care for ethnic minorities is good quality data.

This article looks at the inadequacies of current translation procedures when acquiring self report data from non-English speakers.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Self-harm in the UK: differences between south Asians and whites in rates, characteristics, provision of service and repetition
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Although previous studies in this area have been small, rates of self-harm appear to be high amongst south Asian young women in the UK. Data on treatment and outcomes for self-harm in south Asians is still lacking. This study compared rates of self-harm, socio-demographic and clinical characteristics, provision of services and risk of repetitive self-harming behaviour by ethnicity.

A prospective cohort study of adult self-harm attendees (7185, of which 299 were south Asians) aged 15 years and over was carried out in four emergency departments in Manchester and Salford over a four year period.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Self-reported work strain is lower in south Asian than European people: cross-sectional survey.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This study aimed to describe psychosocial work characteristics in south Asians as compared with Europeans particularly in view of increased risk of CHD in jobs with high levels of demand.

There were 652 participants in the study with 391 being European and 261 being south Asian. A cross-sectional survey was carried out in Newcastle upon Tyne, UK that utilised self reported measures for: job demand, skill utiliisation and support networks at work.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Severe vitamin D deficient rickets in black Afro-Caribbean children
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL]]>
document.body:
Thus article describes five cases of severe rickets in children of second generation Black-African or Caribbean parents who presented to paediatric outpatients in a socially deprived area of inner London. Weaning had been unsuccessful in all of  the cases. The affected children all had biochemical and radiological evidence of  severe rickets.   

 

]]>

document.title: Sexual health in exile: the sexual health concerns, issues and needs of refugees and asylum seekers in South and West Yorkshire: a community research report
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CLIENT GROUPS,SERVICE DELIVERY,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,ETHNICITY,DISADVANTAGED GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,SEXUAL HEALTH,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,JUNE 2010]]>
document.body:
A report on the outcomes of a research project into the views asylum seekers and refugees have about sexual health.  The project was carried out in South and West Yorkshire during March and April 2004, using focus groups and one-to-one interviews.  The report also provides guidelines for commissioners and service providers.

The report includes:

  • Introduction
  • Research findings: first impressions and definitions
  • Research findings: key issues
  • Research findings: awareness of services and role of health professionals
  • Research findings: sexual health promotion
  • Appendices
]]>

document.body:
An investigation into how religious affiliation affects the sexual health knowledge, attitudes and behaviours of young people.

A cross-sectional questionnaire based survey was administered in 16 secondary schools in London. 3007 students were included in the survey aged between 15 and 18. Students surveyed were either Christian, Muslim, Hindu, Other or had no religious affiliation.

250 case-control pairs were included in the study with an approximate equal number of men and women.

document.title: Sexual maltreatment of unaccompanied asylum-seeking minors from the Horn of Africa: a mixed method study focusing on vulnerability and prevention
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
The identification of the social, cultural and political factors that affect African unaccompanied asylum-seeking minors (UASM) vulnerability to sexual maltreatment in England is the aim of this study.

A mixed method approach of questionnaires and in-depth interviews was conducted with 53 (51 female, 2 male) UASM from Ethiopia, Eritrea and Somalia.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Sexually transmitted infections in black African and black Caribbean communities in the UK: 2008 report
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES]]>
document.body:
The key findings from this report into sexually transmitted infections in black African and black Caribbean communities in the UK are as follows:

  • The prevalence of diagnosed HIV in black African (3.7%) and black Caribbean (0.4%) populations is higher than that of the white population (0.09%) in England.
  • There were 2,691 new cases of HIV diagnosed among black Africans in 2007, 40% of the UK total. The number amongst black Caribbeans remained low at 3% (189 cases).
  • The majority of late diagnosed cases of HIV (42%) were amongst black Africans. Late diagnosis amongst black Caribbeans was lower (27%).
  • Black Caribbeans accounted for over a quarter (26%) of heterosexually acquired gonorrhea in England and Wales in 2007.

Further HIV data for black African and black Caribbean communities can be found here.

]]>

This document provides an analysis of returns to the proforma that was sent out in September 2005 for reviewing local Race Equality Schemes. The purpose of this exercise was to enable the Department to take stock of the progress made by NHS organisations in promoting race equality and for these organisations to share good practice. This document covers key findings, best practice identified and overall comments. The document also contains a table that shows the Equality and Human Rights Group’s analysis of responses from the SHAs.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Sickle cell disorder 2008
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,BLOOD DISORDERS,ETHNICITY LINKED DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
111-1Sickle cell disorder 2008

A foundation for future action

July is Sickle Cell Awareness Month and offers an excellent opportunity to reflect on the growing evidence base that now exists, on which to base service support.  Little more than 20 years ago, sickle cell disorder could be dismissed as an exotic condition, of little interest to the National Health Service.  It is now recognised as one of the most common genetic disorders in the UK, irrespective of of ethnic origin, with at least 12,000 people affected by the condition. 

 

Strands of literature
Three distinct bodies of literature have emerged.  First, there is interest in screening issues and identifying those at risk of sickle cell disorder [refs 1, 2].  This has assumed considerable significance in the UK, with the implementation of an antenatal and neonatal sickle cell screening programme [refs 3, 4]. 

Second, there is a long-standing collection of literature on the clinical outcomes of sickle cell disorder [refs 5, 6], supplemented by an increasing interest in the social consequences of living with the condition and a commitment to improving sufferers' quality of life [ref 7]. 

Third, there is a growing concern with how health care professionals and NHS organizations can best provide accessible and appropriate services [refs 8, 9], while also recognising the important role of social care agencies, education, benefit advice and employment support in helping those with the condition and their families [ref 10]. 

This third strand of literature is perhaps what should interest us most, and although the NHS has been slow in responding to the needs of those with sickle cell disorder, and service support remains patchy, there are many examples of innovative, sensitive and empowering provision, which could help inform service delivery more generally.  This is the next challenge facing those responsible for managing and delivering service support to those who suffer from sickle cell disorder.  Nonetheless, the achievements (and struggles) of the past, provide an excellent foundation for future action.  


References

 

  1. Dyson, S.M., Culley, L.A., Gill, C., Hubbard, S., Kennefick, A., Morris, P., Rees, D., Sutton, F. and Squire, P. (2006) ‘Ethnicity Questions and Antenatal Screening for Sickle Cell/Thalassaemia [EQUANS] in England: a randomized controlled trial of two questionnaires’, Ethnicity and Health 11 (2): 169-189. [view resource]

  2. Rowe, R.E., Garcia, J., Davidson, L.L. (2004) ‘Social and ethnic inequalities in the offer and uptake of prenatal screening and diagnosis in the UK: a systematic review’, Public Health, 118(30): 177-89.  [view resource]

  3. National Screening Committee (July 2006) Policy on sickle cell and thalassaemia screening (in pregnancy), London, Department of Health  [view resource]

  4. National Screening Committee (July 2006) Policy on sickle cell and thalassaemia screening (in newborns), London, Department of Health [view resource]

  5. Meremikwu, M.M., (2007) Sickle cell disease, BMJ Clinical Evidence [view resource]

  6. Lucas, S.B., Mason, D.G., Mason, M, and Weyman, D. (2008) A Sickle Crisis: A report of the National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death, London: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death [view resource]

  7. Anie, K.A., Steptoe, A. Ball, S., Dick, M. and Smalling, B.M. (2002)  ‘Coping and health service utilisation in a UK study of paediatric sickle cell pain.’ Archives of Disease in Childhood. 86(5):325-9. [view abstract] [link to pdf]

  8. Thomas, V.J. and Cohn, T. (2006)  ‘Communication skills and cultural awareness courses for healthcare professionals who care for patients with sickle cell disease’, Journal of Advanced Nursing 53(4): 480-488.  [view abstract]

  9. Sickle Cell Society (Forthcoming 2008) Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK, London, Sickle Cell Society.  [view resource]

  10. Anionwu, E and Atkin, K (2001) The politics of sickle cell and thalassaemia disorders, Buckingham, Open University Press  [link to pdf]

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Single equality schemes - 2006
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Aim:

One of the aims of this discussion paper is to raise awareness of the impending changes in equality legislation, policy and practice and their likely effects for NHS organisations. A number of NHS organisations either currently have or are developing a policy to meet these emerging needs and this discussion paper is intended to not only set out questions but to also broaden the debate, to stimulate further questions internally and also seek local and regional views and comments. This paper also sets out some, but by no means all, of the questions that Strategic Health Authorities, NHS Trusts and PCTs will be or are already addressing in the context of considering the development or implementation of a Single Equality Scheme or an all encompassing Equality & Diversity Strategy.

For full paper follow the link.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Snails in bottles and language cuckoos: an evaluation of patient information resources for south Asians with osteomalacia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,BONE DISORDERS,OSTEOMALACIA,PATIENT EDUCATION,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL]]>
document.body:
This study assesses the acceptability for use of information on osteomalacia for south Asian patients.

Ten focus groups were used to evaluate spoken and written patient information on osteomalacia for south Asian patients produced by the Arthritis Research Campaign (ARC). The Social Action Research Model was used for the focus groups which consisted of south Asian persons speaking, Bengali, Gujurati, Hindi, Punjabi and Urdu; with a male and female group for each Language. A questionnaire was also distributed to members of the British Society of Rheumatology and British Health Professionals in Rheumatology who had previously requested patient information for south Asians from the ARC.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Social and ethnic differences in attendance for antenatal care in England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,RACE EQUALITY,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body:
Current evidence regarding sociodemographic factors associated with late attendance for antenatal care is of poor quality for the UK. This study used survey data to quantify any identified ethnic or social differences in access to antenatal care. 

A stratified clustered random sampling strategy was used. 839 women responded to a postal questionnaire which was the result of a cross sectional survey.

]]>

document.body:

402 pregnant women living in East London were recruited for the study in the first trimester of pregnancy.

CEEHD Note: Imprecise use of ethnicity terms in this study may limit value.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE]]>
document.body:
This study examines and compares the social networks of south Asian and European-origin participants and the relationship between social network size and coronary heart disease (CHD) for these groups.

Participants consisted of 684 south Asian and 825 European men and women aged between 25 and 74 years. The south Asian participants consisted of Indians (259), Pakistanis (305) and Bangladeshis (120).

CEEHD Note: Findings are not conclusive for Coronary Heart Diseases but it is a good evidence of south Asians' cultural habits - social networks.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY]]>
document.body:

This communication document launches the debate to define potential EU-led flanking measures to support actions by member states to address this issue.

The document includes information on:

  • Inequalities in health in the EU

  • Taking action on health inequalities
  • Key issues to address
  • Next steps

document.title: South Asian and white older people and dementia: a qualitative study of knowledge and attitudes
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE,OTHER,NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
There is little published research on the understanding of dementia in ethnic minority groups, work that does exist suggests that south Asian older people may have different views about what constitutes a mental illness, who they consult abouth the condition and their acceptance of and access to health services than white older people. This study aimed to discover whether there were differences in views on the provision of care and the nature, causes and treatment of dementia.

96 south Asians and 96 white older people aged 58-85 years were interviewed using a semi structured approach.

document.title: Story-based scales: development and validation of questionnaires to measure subjective health status and cultural adherence in British Bangladeshis with diabetes
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
With questionnaires using scales to measure the quantification of subjective health traits being increasingly used in clinical trials, consideration needs to be given to developing scales valid for use with minority ethnic groups. This study aimed to to develop reliable questionnaires to measure subjective health status in British Bangladeshis with diabetes.

A multi phase study involving narrative interview, vignette construction, questionnaire development and questionnaire validation in relation to two scales was conducted. 98 participants were included in the study randomly sampled from GP diabetes registers in inner London.

]]>

document.body:
The Bangladeshi community is one of the most susceptible to diabetes in the UK, this study reviews the evidence regarding the effectiveness of diabetes health education strategies used for Bangladeshi populations.
