document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Study of Black, Asian and Ethnic Minority issues - Sep 1999
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Background:

This report marks the culmination of a study commissioned by the Department of Health (DOH) in February 1999. The study, initiated before the Macpherson Report was published, formed part of a strategic programme of activities begun in 1998 to progress implementation of the Department’s equal opportunities policy, particularly in relation to black, Asian and other ethnic minority people. At the beginning of 1999, race equality work took on a greater urgency with all Government Departments being required to report on achievements and plans in the context of the Stephen Lawrence Inquiry.

The principal foci of this report are communities in England which would describe themselves as being of African-Caribbean, Asian, black African, Chinese or Mixed Heritage descent.

The main objectives of the study were:

1. To examine the nature and extent of the issues facing black, Asian and ethnic minority communities in health and social care;

2. To look at the emerging Government-wide agenda on black, Asian and ethnic minority issues;

3. To assess the strengths and weaknesses of what the Department of Health is doing and how it is going about it; and

4. To consider the likely impact of what is being done.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Table of entitlement to NHS treatment (correct as of April 2009)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
The Department of Health appealed a High Court ruling, which found that, in certain circumstances, failed asylum seekers can pass the ordinary residence test that confers an automatic right to free NHS hospital treatment or, alternatively, be exempt from charges for hospital treatment after having spent one year in the UK.

In a judgement issued on 30 March 2009, the Court of Appeal found that failed asylum seekers can not be considered to pass the ordinary residence test, nor can they be considered exempt from charges by virtue of spending one year in the UK. This is now the law. The Court of Appeal also found that Trusts have the discretion to withhold treatment pending payment and also the discretion to provide treatment where there is no prospect of paying for it. Trusts should take account of DH guidance when applying this discretion.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Tackling health inequalities for minority ethnic groups: challenges and opportunities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,ETHNICITY,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,SOCIOECONOMIC FACTORS,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,POLICY,CULTURAL IDENTITY,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body:
Key messages from this better health briefing (Number 6) include:

  • Health inequalities exist in the UK: both between and within minority ethnic groups
  • Health inequalities vary by social class between ethnic groups and within ethnic groups
  • Health inequalities reflect inequalities in the distribution of health determinants, such as access to good housing, transport, education and employment opportunities
  • Reducing health inequalities is possible utilising the ‘ingredients’ of National Health Service system reform.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Tackling race inequality: A statement on race
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNICITY,ETHNIC GROUPS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,PUBLIC HEALTH,RACE EQUALITY,GROUPS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,POPULATIONS,FEBRUARY 2010,2010]]>
document.body:
This policy statement from Communities and Local Government highlights the progress in race equality in public services since the introduction of the Race Relations (Amendment) Act in 1999 and sets out objectives to build on this progress in the changing contexts of public services. These objectives include:

  • enforcing the strong legal framework
  • ensuring that work on race equality is an important feature of every government department and that all public services continue to play their part in tackling race inequalities 
  • targeted work to support particular groups to overcome specific challenges, where needed

This policy statement includes:

  • Foreword
  • Introduction and objectives
  • A strong legal framework, with effective enforcement
  • Embedding work on race equality into key government departments: race equality at the heart of policy
  • Conclusion
  • Appendices

A summary of responses to a discussion document that informed the statement can be found here.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Tackling the challenge: promoting race equality in the NHS in England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
This report undertaken by the Healthcare Commission highlights some of the legal obligations of the NHS in meeting its race equality duties, summarises available data on the ethnic makeup of the general population and the NHS workforce, reviews the performance of NHS trusts in promoting race equality and sets out some recommendations for the Department of Health and other commissioners and providers of health services.

The report includes:

  • Summary
  • Introduction
  • Background
  • Healthcare Commission audits of NHS equalities publications
  • The race equality review
  • Conclusions
  • Recommendations
  • References
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Talking like a manager: promotion interviews, language and ethnicity
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
This report aims to understand the discourse process in promotion interviews in ethnically and linguistically diverse areas and also identify any organisational or cultural barriers to promotion.

A mixed method approach was used including: discourse analysis, case studies, a trial for a DVD on job interviewing skills and semi-structured interviews.

This report contains:

  • Profiles of selected companies
  • A detailed methodology
  • Organisational practices that affect promotion opportunities
  • Information on interviewer-candidate interaction
  • Conclusion
  • Recommendations

CEEHD Note: Pages 1-6 of the report act as the summary.

document.body:
This study evaluates relative and cost effectiveness of a home-based cardiac rehabilitation programme with existing centre-based programmes.

The study found that a home-based cardiac rehabilitation programme does not produce inferior outcomes for low to moderate risk patients when compared with centre-based programmes.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: The black diaspora and health inequalities in the US and England: does where you go and how you get there make a difference?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
A consistent finding in health inequalities literature is the relative poor health of black American people in the US and black Caribbean people in the UK; however there is evidence that Caribbean people in the US are fairing considerably better.

This paper examines differences in the social and economic position of black American, black Caribbean and white people in the US and black Caribbean and white people in the UK.

US data was taken from the National Survey of American Life; the UK data was taken from the Health Survey for England.

]]>

document.body:
This study investigates the exclusion of women, older people and minority ethnic groups from clinical trials. The study focuses on two drug exemplars, statins and non-steroid anti-inflamatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Literature was reviewed on the exclusion of women, older people and minorities in healthcare research including: clinical trials, cohorts, hospital episode statistics and drug trials.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: The Epidemic of Coronary Disease in South Asians
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,OUTCOMES,DETERMINANTS,CIRCULATORY DISEASES,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,ETHNICITY,PUBLIC HEALTH,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,SMOKING,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,EATING HABITS,2008-OCTOBER,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,RACE,CULTURAL IDENTITY,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body:
111-1The Epidemic of Coronary Disease in South Asians

for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2008 

 

Dr Kiran C R Patel 


Consultant Cardiologist and Honorary Senior Lecturer in Cardiovascular Medicine, Sandwell, Birmingham

Chair of trustees to the South Asian Health Foundation

West Midlands SHA Clinical Lead

 

For over 50 years now, it has been known that south Asians, when compared to white Europeans, have a higher risk of coronary heart disease (CHD).  There is no single reason for this, but rather a complex interplay of factors puts these populations at risk of developing more severe heart disease earlier in life.  In this short article I will highlight some facts relating to south Asian CHD and what might be done to address some of these.  A south Asian is defined as an individual who is either from, or has roots in India, Pakistan or Bangladesh.

Some facts:

  • South Asian mortality (death rate) from CHD is 46% higher in men and 51% higher in women when compared to the UK white population.

  • South Asians have the highest overall and premature CHD mortalities of any UK ethnic group. Mortality rates are doubled in the 30-40 age group and tripled in the 20-30 age group. An audit in one part of Birmingham showed the rates of heart attack under the age of 60 years were almost 4 times greater than expected in south Asian men and almost twice the number expected in south Asian women.

  • These CHD rates occur despite a falling trend in the incidence of CHD in the general population. This suggests that more needs to be done to bring south Asians rates of heart disease down.

  • The current risk of CHD is far greater than that predicted by the models used by many doctors to determine whether an individual should receive preventative therapy.  Indeed, it is widely accepted that, at least in south Asian men, the risk of heart disease is underestimated by approximately 50%, so many individuals are still not receiving the preventative medication and advice they should.

 

Why are south Asian CHD rates so high?

There is no single reason to explain why south Asians are more susceptible to heart disease than any other population.  Genetic makeup may be a factor, since some families appear to be predisposed to heart disease.  Although there is no single specific gene identified which causes heart disease, researchers from Leicester have identified a locus on chromosome 9 which is associated with a risk of premature coronary disease. Further studies and validation are awaited.

However, families also tend to share risk factors for heart disease, and this is why the disease often occurs in several family members. Indeed, there are few south Asian families who do not have a family member afflicted by heart disease or stroke.  So what is known about the risk factors which make south Asians prone to developing heart disease?

 

Risk factors for heart disease

Risk factors can be divided into those which are modifiable and those which are non-modifiable.  Genetic make up is fixed and non modifiable.  Although there is no specific gene which causes heart disease, the south Asian genetic make up does appear to predispose this population to developing diabetes and heart disease when they move from an environment where calorie consumption is lower and levels of physical activity are higher, e.g. on farms in India, to an environment where there is an exchange of this healthy lifestyle for one with less exercise and higher calorie intake, e.g. migration to cities or urbanised lifestyles.  South Asians tend to display the thin-fat phenotype, i.e.  for the same body mass index, they have higher levels of adiposity.  In addition, a similar weight gain in south Asians and white Europeans tends to be correlated with a higher risk of diabetes mellitus in south Asians.  The transition from a relatively poor to an affluent environment over the years appears to have been responsible for much of the epidemic of heart disease and diabetes in the Asian population.

Increased age is associated with increased risk of heart disease, although this can be reduced by ensuring a healthier lifestyle early in life.  One of the most worrying societal patterns regularly seen in south Asian populations is the way in which many Asian children are fed.  After birth, rates of breast feeding are unfortunately low despite professional encouragement.   Once children begin to eat, a diet containing high calorie foods and food rich in oil, butter, ghee or sugars, which his common, may predispose these children to heart disease.  Post mortem studies have shown streaks of cholesterol in the arteries of children as young as two years of age, and we are also now seeing diabetes in south Asian teenagers as a consequence of poor lifestyles in childhood. This depressing trend must stop.  Health promotion targeted at these populations must challenge adverse childhood lifestyles.  One issue of concern, potentially fuelling adverse infant feeding patterns, is the accuracy of foetal and childhood growth charts.  Are these culturally sensitive?  Certainly, there is ample evidence now to suggest not, and perhaps wider use of customised charts should now be entertained?

In terms of modifiable risk factors, achievement of the recommended levels of exercise (30 minutes of activity, five times weekly) is lower in all south Asian populations than in their white counterparts.  Diet is a further modifiable risk factor.  Despite similar south Asian levels of fruit and vegetable intake to the Chinese population, rates of CHD are significantly higher.  One potential explanation is the way in which south Asians tend to cook food, potentially removing the nutritional benefits of consumed produce.  In addition, there is emerging evidence to suggest that vitamin D deficiency is associated with higher rates of CHD in ethnic groups, with south Asians traditionally tending to be at risk of this vitamin deficiency.  Although overall smoking rates are similar to the white population, rates are significantly higher in Bangladeshi populations and Pakistanis.  A lack of awareness among healthcare professionals of the cardiovascular risks associated with smokeless tobacco can create an inequitable access to tobacco control strategies and interventions aimed at reducing tobacco use. Services traditionally targeting smokers must widen their scope to help address inequalities.

 

Challenges

Prevention must begin in utero and therefore maternal wellbeing is a start to tackling the epidemic.  Subsequently, use of appropriate growth charts, sensible childhood lifestyle risk management and education, followed by early implementation of prevention strategies will all go some way towards tackling some of the ethnic inequalities we see today.  The launch of a Department of Health cardiovascular risk assessment strategy, with ethnic groups identified as a group to target, is long overdue and welcome. One hopes this will be the beginning of appropriate prevention strategies for high risk groups.  On a wider scale, the issue of deprivation and the social determinants of health require concerted effort across government agencies and across sectors.  In collaboration with improved access to high quality healthcare, driven by a stronger evidence base for interventions and strategies in ethnic groups, the tide can surely be forced to turn and ameliorate the epidemic of CHD experienced by south Asian populations globally today.

Resources

Agyemang, C., Bhopal, R., & M. Bruijnzeels. 2004. ‘Do variations in blood pressures of south Asian, African and Chinese descent children reflect those of the adult populations in the UK?: a review of cross-sectional data’. Journal of Human Hypertension. vol. 18, pt. 4, pp. 229-237.
[view details]

Agyemang, C., Bhopal, R., & W., K. Redekop. 2007. ‘Does the pulse pressure in people of European, African and south Asian descent differ?: a systematic review and meta-analysis of UK data’. Journal of Human Hypertension. vol. 21, pt. 8, pp. 598-609.
[view details]

Bhopal, R., et al. 2002. ‘Ethnic and socio-economic inequalities in coronary heart disease, diabetes and risk factors in Europeans and south Asians’. Journal of Public Health Medicine. vol. 24, pt. 2, pp. 95-105.
[view details]

Bhopal, R., et al. 2005. ‘Predicted and observed cardiovascular disease in south Asians: application of FINRISK, Framingham and SCORE models to Newcastle Heart Project data’. Journal of Public Health. vol. 27, pt. 1, pp. 93-100.
[view details]

Darr, A., Astin F., & K. Atkin. 2008. 'Causal attributions, lifestyle change, and coronary heart disease: illness beliefs of patients of south Asian and European origin living in the United Kingdom'. Heart & Lung: The Journal of Critical Care. vol. 37, pt. 2, pp. 91-104.
[view details]

Fischbacher, C., M., Hunt, S., & L. Alexander. 2004. 'How physically active are south Asians in the United Kingdom?: a literature review'. Journal of Public Health. vol. 26, pt. 3, pp. 250-258.
[view details]

Fischbacher, C., M., et al. 2007. 'Record linked retrospective cohort study of 4.6 million people exploring ethnic variations in disease: myocardial infarction in south Asians'. BMC Public Health. vol. 7, pt. 142.
[view details]

Forouhi, N., G., et al. 2006. 'Do known risk factors explain the higher coronary heart disease mortality in south Asian compared with European men?: prospective follow-up of the Southall and Brent studies, UK. Diabetologia. vol. 49, pt. 11, pp. 2580-8.
[view details]

Fox, C. 2004. Heart disease and south Asians: delivering the National Service Framework for Heart Disease. British Heart Foundation.
[view details]

Lyratzopoulos, G., et al. 2005. Comparative levels and time trends in blood pressure, total cholesterol, body mass index and smoking among Caucasian and south-Asian participants of a UK primary-care based cardiovascular risk factor screening programme. BMC Public Health. vol. 28, pt. 5.
[view details]

Mathews, G., et al. 2007. Impact of a cardiovascular risk control project for south Asians (Khush Dil) on motivation, behaviour, obesity, blood pressure and lipids. Journal of Public Health. vol. 29, pt. 4, pp. 388-397.
[view details]

Patel, K., C., R., & A., M. Shah. 2005. Prevention, treatment and rehabilitation of cardiovascular disease in south Asians. South Asian Health Foundation.
[view details]

Pollard, T., M., et al. 2003. Social networks and coronary heart disease risk factors in south Asians and Europeans in the UK. Ethnicity & Health. vol. 8, pt. 3, pp. 263-275.
[view details]

Tillin, T., et al. 2005. Metabolic syndrome and coronary heart disease in south Asians, African-Caribbeans and white Europeans: a UK population-based cross-sectional study. Diabetologia. vol. 48, pt. 4, pp. 649-56.
[view details]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: The health and social care experiences of black and minority ethnic older people
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
The key messages form this better health briefing (Number 9) are:

  • Older people from black and minority ethnic groups continue to recieve poorer treatment from health and social care services
  • Lack of information, language difficulties and differing expectations of services are amongst barriers for black and minority ethnic older people accessing health and social care services
  • Service professionals with stereotyped assumptions can also act as barriers to service use
  • A body of evidence is increasingly growing regarding what black and minority ethnic groups want from services
  • Although good services exist there has been a difficulty in bringing them into the mainstream
]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,GYPSIES AND TRAVELLERS]]>
document.body:
This better health briefing (Number 12) includes the following key messages:

  • The health of Gypsies and Travellers is much poorer than that of the general population
  • A major factor in Gypsy and Traveller health is the poor access to and uptake of health services
  • There is scant attention for Gypsy and Traveller health in policy documents on health inequalities
  • Examples of good practice need to be funded and replicated across more localities
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: The involvement of black and minority ethnic consumers in health research : a research review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,NHS ACTIVITIES,POLICY,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INEQUALITIES,RESEARCH,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This report is a review of black and minority ethnic (BME) group involvement in health research. It recommends that:

  • Most BME consumer-oriented research tends to be qualitative and based around needs assessment. Qualitative methods seem the most effective way of dealing with diversity in the population.
  • There are major issues of marginalisation and exclusion in other spheres (beyond health), particularly in education, employment and local politics - these have an impact upon health-related issues.
  • There is what the social sciences refer to ‘structured exclusion’ - whereby ‘colour-blind’ and culturally insensitive approaches are built into mechanisms: the NHS and health related R&D are part of this.
  • Working with BME consumers takes longer, in particular to overcome suspicions based on the above, and to win trust and obtain access. Other factors such as identification of populations and their structures, and translation/interpretation, contribute to this.
  • Explicit (focused or specific) attention and initiatives are required to overcome the historic problems arising from social exclusion.
  • Many concerns of BME populations have been left out of main programmes because they are seen as ‘minority’ concerns: equally, much of the research has seen minority culture and lifestyles as ‘pathogenic’ and been critical of cherished institutions. Similarly, it has sometimes appeared that research has been directed to ‘control’, rather than ‘care’ for the community.
  • Equal Opportunity and affirmative action policies should be part of all research and could be made conditions of funding, and monitored.
  • Power relationships within the research and development process are important: those involved must be enabled to influence, conduct and use research.
  • There is good practice available but it needs to be sought out and preserved: this includes the management of research reports and the identification of ‘grey literature’; this in turn is part of a wider issue about dissemination and the achievement of ‘best value’ in funding research.
  • The ethnic and cultural origin of researchers and agencies is not irrelevant.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: The involvement of Chinese older people in policy and practice: aspirations and expectations
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,OLDER PEOPLE,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,OLDER PEOPLE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This report explores the active involvement of Chinese older people in research and the promotion of their quality of life.

Three local working groups in South Yorkshire, Manchester and London each adopted different approaches to support Chinese older people to develop a collective voice, influence policy and practice and reflect upon their experiences.  This report includes participant's original ideas, first-hand experiences and personal reflection to evaluate the effectiveness of each approach.

The report includes:

  • Executive summary  
  • Introduction
  • The joint statement
  • The local projects
  • Experiences of involvement
  • Aspirations, gains and loss
  • Conclusions and recommendations
  • References
  • Appendices
]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL]]>
document.body:
Renal involvement is a major complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) as well as being a strong determinant of morbidity and mortality. This study the first on the epidemiology of lupus nephritis aims to establish the prevalence and incidence of biopsy-proven lupus nephritis in the northwest of England (2001) and to examine the influence of age, sex and ethnicity.

208 cases of biopsy-proven lupus nephritis were identified from five sources: renal biopsy databases, dialysis/transplant databases, nephrologists' patients, clinic lists, and lupus patient groups. 

CEEHD Note: This paper uses imprecise ethnicity terms.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: The principles of midwifery care in a transcultural context
document.topics: <![CDATA[ WOMEN'S HEALTH,NORMAL PREGNANCY,PROVISION OF CARE,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES,GOOD PRACTICE,STANDARDS OF PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
Aims and learning objectives

The Aim of this chapter is to introduce student midwives and midwives to the issues related to the provision of care for women and their families across different culturally diverse communities. The text aims to promote culturally safe practice which in turn will signpost good standards of health care practice.

By the end of this chapter students will have

  • Explored the challenges offered in the provision of maternity care in a multi-cultural/multi-ethnic society.
  • Discussed the strategies adopted to ensure the provision of equitable care in a midwifery setting.
  • Demonstrated awareness of the role of the midwife in the provision of an equitable service.

Whilst in the main the feminine pronoun has been used when designating the midwife, it is recognised that midwives may be male. When dealing with some cultures a male midwife may be unacceptable to both the woman and her family. This is a problem that has not been explored in this work although it is acknowledged that it is an important issue to consider.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: The recruitment and retention of black and minority ethnic staff in the National Health Service
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
The key messages from this Better Health Briefing are:

 

  • The UK labour market is characterised by discrimination against BME people
  • The representation of BME staff within the NHS is disproportionate
  • BME staff experience discrimination at work and in their careers
  • Overseas-qualified BME doctors and nurses are more likely to be discriminated against
  • There is concerted effort to combat racial discrimination at the national level
  • The evidence on the impact of policies aimed at facilitating the recruitment and retention of BME staff is mixed

 

]]>

document.body:
In the US, African American men have a greater risk of developing prostate cancer than white men.  This study investigates whether the same is true for first generation black Caribbean and black African men in the UK.

All cases of prostate cancer diagnosed over a five year period in specific areas of London and Bristol were included in a clinical cohort study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: The social care needs of refugees and asylum seekers
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
This discussion paper attempts to describe the specific experiences of refugees and asylum seekers with social care needs.  It also makes a series of recommendations for services to meet their needs more effectively.  It concludes with a number of recommendations, including:

  • As part of planning and designing services, social care agencies should carry out local mapping and consultation exercises to collect data and information about refugees and asylum seekers.  As those with social care needs are likely to be the hardest to reach, innovative methods should be used.
  • The social care needs of refugees and asylum seekers cannot and should not be met by local authority ‘asylum teams’.  Instead, specialist teams and services should plan and deliver services that meet the needs of service users who are refugees or asylum seekers. Consultation and feedback with refugees and asylum seekers would be a good basis for doing this.
  • The refugee community and voluntary sectors should play a far bigger role in the planning, design and delivery of social care services
     

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,ETHNICITY LINKED DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Key messages from this better health briefing (number 17) include:

  • An important starting point in developing more appropriate and accessible care is a greater understanding of sickle cell and thalassaemia
  • Sickle cell and thalassaemia disorders are one of the most common genetic inherited conditions in the UK this provides opportunities for greater screening interventions for healthy carriers
  • Although there has been improvements in clinical management, poor service support remains a long standing difficulty
  • Although examples of good practice exist in health and social care, the potential of such interventions are rarely identified and lessons are rarely disseminated to those that need them
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Towards an understanding of variations in infant mortality rates between different ethnic groups in England and Wales
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LIFE EVENTS,BIRTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE,REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH]]>
document.body:
The key messages from this; Inequalities in Infant Mortality Project Briefing (Number 3) are:

  • Large inequalities in infant mortality rates exist between ethnic minorities and the general population in England and Wales.
  • In part due to a higher prevalence of preterm birth and congenital anomalies Caribbean and Pakistani babies are more than twice as likely to die before the age of one than white British or Bangladeshi babies.
  • Heterogeneity is considerable between different ethnic groups in both risk factors and causes of infant mortality.
  • Explanations for variations in infant mortality between ethnic groups are complex.
  • To identify the pathways that lead to higher risks of infant death among black and minority ethnic groups more research is needed.
]]>

document.title: Towards race equality in advocacy services: people with learning disabilities from black and minority ethnic communities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.body:
Key messages from this better health briefing (Number 15) include:

  • "Double discrimination" is faced by black and minority ethnic (BME) people with learning disabilities when accessing services
  • The concept of advocacy may not be easily translatable for many BME communities
  • Through training and personal development advocacy practitioners must be able to respond appropriately to BME clients experiences of racism
  • It is essential to meet the language needs of BME individuals who need advocacy services.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Transcultural clinical supervision in health care practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES]]>
document.body:
Aims of the Module

There are many different models and approaches to clinical supervision;

  • One-to-one supervisor (supervisor-supervisee)
  • Group Supervision (Supervisor-Supervisees)
  • Peer Group Supervision (Dual Roles: Supervisors/Supervisees)

Clinical Supervision should not be confused with other 'supervisory' activities, such as the appraisal system, or mentoring.

This module intends to familiarise you with:

  • one particular model of clinical supervision known as The Supervision Triangle
  • the supervisory relationship within a multicultural environment
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Transcultural communication and health care practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,COMMUNICATIONS,CULTURAL AWARENESS,PATIENT COMMUNICATIONS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES]]>
document.body:
This module is concerned with the content and the process of communication. It concerns all of those things that we say, do, and feel about each other when we are in the presence of other people.

It is our intention that in the course of this module you will experience an increasing awareness of the complex social structures within which we exchange meaningful messages with each other. It is also hoped that you might feel yourself comfortable and competent with some terminology that is new to you, and thus be able to think more clearly about the process of communication.

For the most part, most of us feel fairly confident, or at least competent, in making ourselves understood, making people feel comfortable, getting our feelings across to others and so on; and we are. However, there are occasions on which we do not feel so comfortable. Indeed, in some situations, such as interviews, arriving late, or being reprimanded for a mistake, we might feel very ill at ease; perhaps even a little defensive.

This module will introduce you to some of the elements constituting the communicative process, and to some of the levels on which we might analyse and possibly improve that process. It will consider the notions of communicative competence and social skills acquisition in order that you might become familiar with a concept that we call Transcultural Communicative Competence. All of these terms will probably be new to you but you will soon come to understand them.

You will find that there is a good deal of content on the basic processes of communication and on the nature of social interaction. It may well seem that there is rather more social psychology in this module than you expected. This is because this module aims to prepare you to be able to develop your transcultural communication skills. Good transcultural communication is essentially just good communication, and hence this module will provide a broad foundation for the understanding of interpersonal communication, on the basis of which you will be able to develop your transcultural skills.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Transcultural health care practice with children and their families
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,POPULATIONS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,ADULTS,CHILDREN,SERVICES,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,SECONDARY & TERTIARY SERVICES]]>
document.body:
Introduction

In this chapter we shall consider the care that sick children, from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and their families, require from nurses and health care professionals. We shall refer to other modules in this series, books, key articles and texts, and we will provide activities and scenarios to help relate theory to the practice area.

There is a belief in nursing that the care provided should be equitable and 'fair' or democratic, the 'same for all' without prejudice or favouritism. This belief often assumes that the needs of all are identical and this clearly is not so. The child admitted for minor surgery, accompanied by their parents, pain-free and familiar with the ward routine and staff, will react differently to the child admitted as an emergency from A & E as the result of a car accident. The needs of each, and the care they require, will differ and, if they represent different cultural backgrounds, their perception of what is happening and their reactions to events may also vary.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Transcultural health care practice: an educational resource for nurses and health care practitioners
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES]]>
document.body:
Introduction to the materials

These modules have been written by a large number of individuals who have each drawn upon their professional expertise and experience in preparing their own contributions to the whole programme. Many contributions have emerged from collaborations between colleagues who are actively engaged in delivering professional education and training within the same higher educational establishment. Consequently, across these materials can be found the distinctive styles and priorities of professionals addressing the challenge of contributing to the development of transcultural health care practice. Additionally, all of these modules have been subject to a process of piloting and revision which has seen a further 25 institutions across the United Kingdom being involved in the development of the materials. This piloting process enabled the materials to be appraised by practitioners and educators with very different minority ethnic client populations: and within institutions located within widely differing multi-ethnic demographics. Finally, the revised materials have benefited from a Department of Health peer review process.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Transcultural health care practice: mental health and minority ethnic groups
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES,PUBLIC HEALTH,OUTCOMES,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,ANALYSIS & RESEARCH,POPULATIONS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,GROUPS,MENTAL & BEHAVIOURAL DISORDERS,ETHNICITY,LANGUAGE,ETHNIC GROUPS,METHODS,TEACHING METHODS,HEALTHCARE & HEALTH SERVICES,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,NURSING,FRAMES OF REFERENCE,GOOD PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
Aim and learning objectives

The aim of this chapter is to introduce learners to the main themes in the care of mentally ill patients from minority ethnic groups in contemporary Britain.

The learning objectives include:

  • Critically examine the role culture plays in shaping the health beliefs and health seeking behaviours of people from different cultural backgrounds.
  • Recognise the importance of cultural influences in the communication patterns of patients.
  • Develop robust assessment tools in practice to highlight the cultural profile of patients.
  • Appreciate the pathways to care followed by patients and ascertain the effectiveness of the three sectors of mental health care for minority ethnic patients.
  • Critically evaluate your own strengths and weaknesses in working with people from different ethnic backgrounds.
  • Actively seek to influence change in knowledge, skills and attitudes, making it more receptive to the needs of patients from different backgrounds.
]]>

document.title: Tuberculosis in the UK: annual report on tuberculosis surveillance in the UK 2009
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
8,655 cases of tuberculosis (TB) were reported in the UK in 2008.  The majority of cases occur in urban areas, particularly London (39%) and amongst young adults (15-44 years) and those born outside the UK (72%).  People of black African and south Asian ethnicity remain at increased risk of contracting the disease.

This report includes:

  • Foreword
  • Executive summary
  • Introduction
  • TB case reports, UK, 2000-2008
  • TB drug resistance, UK, 2000-2008
  • TB treatment outcomes, UK, 2001-2007
  • Progress, conclusions and recommendations
  • References
  • Appendices
  • Other sources of information

Previous annual reports are available here

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Turning Evidence into Action - Ethnicity Data
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING,COMMISSIONING,POPULATIONS SERVED,ETHNIC MINORITY GROUPS,KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS,KNOWLEDGE AND DATA MANAGEMENT,COMMISSIONING COMPETENCIES,MANAGE KNOWLEDGE]]>
document.body:
111-1Turning Evidence into Action - ethnicity data

 for SLEH National Knowledge Week 2008

 

 Ray Warburton

 

Head of Programme,
NHS Change Programmes

Equality Rights Group
Department of Health


Community perceptions of evidence

The one thing that most annoys black and minority communities, and organisations that support their quest for better health care, is the seemingly constant quest for new evidence about their health needs and circumstances. While we could all agree that new evidence is always welcome, doing more research is seen or used as an excuse for inaction. Whether this is right or wrong, in many places actions to address their health concerns can be thin on the ground.

There is considerable evidence about the health issues and inequalities experienced by individuals from black and minority ethnic (BME) communities. Sometimes the evidence is available nationally; at other times it is available locally; or maybe both. Sometimes the evidence becomes available, or is updated, only every five or even 10 years. Some evidence is based on censuses; other evidence is based on sample surveys. The evidence – from whatever source – has now reached a critical mass, and may be used, sometimes with caution but often authoritatively, at both national and local level to drive forward real change.

The key message to all health service planners, commissioners, evaluators and regulators is: “use existing sources of evidence as much as possible; and collect new data when essential”.

 

Current sources

There are a number of good data sources about BME communities and their health – ranging from the Office of National Statistics’ (ONS) 10 yearly census to the information held by Public Health Observatories  and academic institutions.

The ONS census in 2001 asked for information on ethnicity and religion. The 2011 census is likely to ask a question about language competency as well. The census data, covering the entire population, are powerful means of getting to grips with the make-up of local populations. The 2001 census informed us that over 9% of the population in England is from BME backgrounds, with some very marked differences in certain towns and cities. While over 71% of the population in England said they were Christian, the 2001 census revealed big differences up and down the country, with Muslims, Hindus and Sikhs having a prominent profile in some inner-city areas. Between censuses, the census data become increasingly difficult to use. By 2010 the BME population is likely to have changed significantly from 2001. However, through use of good local intelligence and ONS Mid-Year estimates, national and local NHS bodies can keep a fairly good check on numbers.

The Health Survey for England (HSE) [ref 1] is an annual survey commissioned by the Department of Health (DH) to monitor the health of the nation across health conditions and groups. Once in every five years, the sample is doubled to provide greater sensitivity to BME communities’ needs. The last ‘boost’ was in 2004; the next time will be in 2009. The 2004 HSE showed, for example, that compared with the general population:

  • Bangladeshi and Pakistani people and Black Caribbean women are more likely to report bad or very bad health;

  • Pakistani women and Bangladeshi men are more likely to report limiting longstanding illness;

  • Pakistani men are at more risk of ischaemic heart disease;
     
  • Bangladeshi, Pakistani and Indian people and African Caribbean women are more at risk of Type 2 diabetes;
     
  • Bangladeshi and Irish men are more likely to smoke.

The Health Statistics Quarterly (HSQ) [ref 2] also routinely reports on infant mortality. This is a key indicator in its own right but also a critical measure of community health and cohesion. The HSQ draws on birth information from the Registrar General at ONS.  For a number of years, the data have shown that babies of mothers born in Pakistan, the Caribbean and parts of Africa have particularly high infant mortality rates compared with the general population. Until recently, the HSQ data only showed the link between infant deaths and the country of birth of mothers, because birth certificates do not record the ethnicity of mother or baby. By linking birth certificates to birth notifications of hospitals, ONS have lately been able to analyse infant deaths by ethnicity. This is a great step forward.

NHS data

The NHS itself collects data on its patients. Some of these data can be used to draft the statutory equality schemes and action plans required.  Some data can be used for public health purposes – for example, to compare patients accessing and being treated by the NHS with the populations NHS Trusts serve. Some of the data can be used for clinical purposes. Acute hospitals are directed by DH to collect the ethnicity of in-patients.  Currently GPs are incentivised to collect the ethnicity of patients newly registering with them under the Quality and Outcomes Framework.  Following the primary care access review by the National Improvement Team and a subsidiary report on   BME access, [ref 3], GPs will be encouraged to collect the ethnicity and first language of all their patients under a Directed Enhanced Service [ref 4]. 

All told, however, the collection of ethnicity data in the NHS can be patchy, but the NHS Information Centre for Health and Social Care is supporting the NHS to collect the data required of it. In 2005, in collaboration with NHS Employers and the NHS Information Centre, DH published guidance to the NHS on the categories and codes to use when monitoring the ethnicity, religion, diet and language proficiency of patients [ref 5].  DH intends to update and extend this guidance to cover all equality strands in the future.


There are a number of other NHS-focused surveys and data collections that can be used by NHS organisations.  For example, there is the annual GP Patient Survey, commissioned by DH and run by the NHS Information Centre. These large sample surveys are a rich source of data and include analyses by ethnicity. Results from the 2008 survey have just been published [ref 3].  

The Health Protection Agency (HPA), the National Treatment Agency (NTA) and others also collect important NHS data on topics such as healthcare associated infections, drug and substance misuse.  The General Household Surveys and the Integrated Household Surveys, annually run by ONS, deliver useful data on health issues, such as smoking prevalence, broken down by ethnicity.


The Healthcare Commission reports are a strong source of evidence of how BME people access and experience the NHS.  Each year, the Commission undertake a series of patient-focused surveys, looking at different aspects of health.  Data are collected on the age, gender and ethnicity of patients, making it possible to obtain authoritative analyses by these equality strands.  A recurrent theme is that South Asian people, but particularly Bangladeshi people, experience the NHS less positively than other groups.


The Healthcare Commission also team up with other organisations, including the Mental Health Act Commission to carry out a census of patients with mental health problems or learning disabilities living in institutional settings. This census is into its third year.  Data on the age, gender, ethnicity, religion and sexual orientation of patients are collected, and are used to analyses how patients are cared for in what setting. Results from 2005, 2006 and 2007 are consistent: namely more black people are mental health patients, and are detained under statutory powers, often in seclusion, compared with other groups [ref 6].

 

Other Sources

Public Health Observatories (PHOs), which operate in each Government Office region collect and analyse a range of health–related data, including ethnicity and other equality data.  Local NHS organisations should always consult either their own public health departments or these PHOs when using existing data or needing fresh data.  Each PHO specialises in particular themes, with London PHO leading on BME health and data. The London PHO, in partnership with the NHS Information Centre and the Association of PHOs (APHO) has developed a Local Basket of Indicators, a national collection of a wide range of measures that can be used at a local level to track progress against local priorities for action on health inequalities, some related to ethnicity. In 2006, the Association of PHOs published a report on health and ethnicity [ref 7]. The report looked at regional data on key health conditions by ethnicity, and commented on regional differences. In the report, APHO commented on the scope and quality of ethnicity data collections in the NHS, and urged both DH and the NHS to do better.

 

Academic institutions can be a good source of health and ethnicity evidence. One such is the University of Nottingham, where the School of Community Health Services runs a Q Research database derived from the anonymised health records of over nine million patients in the 550 or so GP practices using the EMIS clinical computer system.  NHS organisations can access the Q Research database to inform their thinking, planning and commissioning of services, including those for BME communities (subject, of course, to the availability of ethnicity data from GP practices).  In a related development, the University has also developed a Q risk score, indicating the risk of CVD among communities including BME communities [ref 8]


New evidence: gypsy and traveller case study

Where existing data sources are inadequate or not up-to-date, health organisations should consider collecting or commissioning new evidence. The NHS often deals with very marginalised BME groups for which ONS census or other survey data do not exist (yet) and who are not included in the usual NHS collections of ethnicity.  None is more marginalised or seldom heard than gypsies and travellers. Until recently evidence on the health status of gypsies and travellers, and their access to the NHS, had been hard to come by. However, in recent years two reports have addressed this problem. In 2002, the South West Public Health Observatory reviewed the various small scale research studies that had been published to date. In 2004 the University of Sheffield, under a commission from the Department of Health, published the results of their research which compared, in a robust way, the health status of gypsies and travellers with the health status of a number of comparator communities [ref 9].

 

The broad finding was that the overall health status of gypsies and travellers is relatively poor in comparison with other disadvantaged groups and very poor compared with the general population.  Certain health conditions and illnesses are significant for gypsy and traveller adults; these include anxiety, asthma, bronchitis, depression, and long-term illness.  There are significant health issues for children, many relating to lack of immunisation.  In addition, there are considerable risks to mothers and their babies leading up to, at, or just after birth.  Despite these health problems, access to healthcare is often difficult for gypsies and travellers.  For example, many feel that health workers, including GPs and their staff, have a poor understanding of their needs, circumstances and culture.  Furthermore, they report considerable problems in registering with GPs and/or receiving appropriate care from GP practices.  As a result, many gypsies and travellers tend to make greater use of A&E for basic health needs than the general population.

 

A new response

In response to the research findings, the Department of Health has engaged with gypsy and traveller community members and organisations to discuss appropriate action. As a result, the Department has begun to trial innovative approaches to some of the more deep-seated health access problems experienced by gypsies and travellers as part of its Pacesetters programme [ref 10].  This work centres on:

  • raising awareness of gypsies’ and travellers’ health needs and circumstances among NHS professionals;
  • raising awareness among community members of the potential of the NHS to help them;
  • improving GP registration and access to the NHS in general;
  • improving the recording and sharing of health information of individual community members. 

Learning and good practice will be disseminated widely to the NHS.  Already, some exciting and innovative projects have commenced, including the employment of gypsy and traveller community members, on a sessional basis, to act as “Health Ambassadors” between the NHS and local communities in the East Midlands.

 

DH has also commissioned a ‘Commissioning Framework for Gypsies and Travellers’ as part of DH’s work to develop such frameworks for transient populations. It is anticipated that the framework will be published early in 2009.

 

It seems likely that the 2011 ONS census will begin to record the ethnicity of gypsies and travellers.  Until results from the 2011 census are available, NHS organisations can refer to the ‘Caravan Count’ carried out by communities and Local Government each January and July [ref 11].

 

Everyone, including CLG, recognises that the caravan count provides a partial estimate of the numbers of gypsies and travellers in England. For one thing, it counts caravans not people. For another, it has been estimated that at least a half of gypsies and travellers live in permanent “bricks and mortar” accommodation.  However, as an estimate, local NHS organisations can multiply the number of caravans in their patch by an estimate of the numbers of people each caravan holds and then double the answer to give an estimate of gypsies and travellers in their area.

 

In Leeds, organisations concerned about the health and well-being of gypsies and travellers took a significant step in getting much more reliable data.  The Leeds Race Equality Council, supported by Leeds Gypsy and Traveller Exchange and Leeds City Council, talked to local gypsy and traveller communities and, using enumerators from these communities, conducted their own census. This gave rise to far more reliable estimates than the caravan count could give, and also helped Leeds REC to document and calculate facts and figures about the local gypsy and traveller populations. The most chilling fact to emerge was that life expectancy among these local communities was no more than 50 [ref 12]. 

 

Future actions

DH is keen for there to be better collection of ethnicity and other equality-focused data within the NHS and beyond.  DH has formed an Equality Monitoring Group to make better use of data that are already collected and to commission new collections where necessary.  To date, the group has commissioned a disaggregation of the ‘Vital Signs’ – the indicators that are used to track the NHS’s progress against key deliverables, such as the 18 weeks wait target (from referral to hospital appointment).  Disaggregated data, showing outlying trusts will be presented to senior officials at DH and in the NHS for comment and action.  Another notable achievement has been, with the support of the GP Committee of the British Medical Association a Directed Enhanced Service (DES) for ethnicity monitoring. This DES will require GP practices to record the ethnicity of all patients registered with them. Practices will be paid according to the percentage of patients for whom an ethnicity and first language is recorded [ref 4].    

 

In the meantime NHS organisations are asked to make full use of what is already available and to commission new evidence where necessary.  In particular, they should make sure that the ethnicity data about their own  patients are as good as possible.

References  

  1. Sproston Kerry; Mindell Jennifer (eds), 2006. Health survey for England 2004: the health of ethnic minorities. London, National Centre for Social Research
    [view details]

  2. Health Statistics Quarterly
    Further information from their website.

  3. Department of Health, Healthcare Commission, 2008. Report on self reported experience of patients from black and minority ethnic groups.  London:  Department of Health
    [view details]
     
  4. NHS Employers, 2008. Clinical directed enhanced services (DES) guidance for GMS contract 2008/09: delivering investment in general practice. [Appendix 5: Specification for a directed enhanced service in England: ethnicity].  London:  NHS Employers
    [download pdf]
     
  5. Department of Health et al, 2005. A practical guide to ethnic monitoring in the NHS and social care.  London:  Department of Health
    [view details]

  6. Healthcare Commission et al, 2007. "Count me in" 2007: results of the 2007 National Census of Inpatients in Mental Health and Learning Disability Services in England and Wales.  London:  Commission for Healthcare Audit and Inspection
    [view details]

  7. Association of Public Health Observatories, 2005. Indications of public health in the English regions: ethnicity and health.  London:  London Health Observatory.  Indications 4.
    [view details]

  8. Hippisley-Cox, J. et al, 2008. 'Predicting cardiovascular risk in England and Wales: prospective derivation and validation of QRISK2'. British Medical Journal.  336(7659), pp. 1475-82   
    [view details]
     
  9. Parry, G., et al. 2007. 'Health status of gypsies and travellers in England'. Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health.  61(3), pp. 198-204.

  10. NHS Networks. Pacesetters Programme
    [programme website]

  11. Communities and Local Government.  [webpage on the internet] Gypsy and traveller site data and statistics.  London:  Communities and Local Government [downloadable statistical tables (2008) and related publications].

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular risk in the UK south Asian community
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES]]>
document.body:
This study describes and compares the prevalence of type 2 diabetes cardiovascular diseases (CVD) and their associated risk factors in south Asian and white populations to ascertain possible reasons for the increased rates of these diseases in south Asians.

Erratum in:
Diabetologia. 2007 Jan;50(1):244.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Type 2 diabetes and obesity in the south Asian population
document.publisher: SLEH (NLH Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DIABETES,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,PEOPLE FROM ETHNIC MINORITIES,DETERMINANTS,OUTCOMES,BIOLOGICAL COMPOSITION,OBESITY,ETHNICITY,DIABETES,ENDOCRINE DISORDERS,OBESITY,TYPE 2,DIABETES,PUBLIC HEALTH,EATING HABITS,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,2008-OCTOBER,POPULATIONS,CULTURAL IDENTITY,RACE]]>
document.body:
111-1Type 2 diabetes and obesity in the south Asian population

Written for the Specialist Library for Ethnicity & Health (SLEH) National Knowledge Week 2008

 

Wasim Hanif
MD FRCP (UK)

 

Consultant Physician & Honorary Senior Lecturer University Hospital Birmingham

Consultant Physician and Honorary Senior Lecturer in diabetes and endocrinology at University Hospital Birmingham

 

Obesity is a major risk factor for diabetes, and this has been confirmed in the South Asians (ref 1). High rates of obesity were found in all ethnic minority groups studied in one US survey and were associated with high waist-hip ratio, low socio-economic status, and low educational attainment (ref 2). In a British survey, however, obesity as indicated was found to be no more common in British Asian men than in white men, though the prevalence was higher in Asian than white women (ref 3). It is important to note, however, that the definition of obesity was based on the old WHO definition of obesity i.e. BMI greater than 30 kg/m2. The new WHO definition (ref 4) of obesity in South Asians, which is a BMI greater than 25 kg/m2, indicates that obesity is very common in this group (ref 5). In an epidemiological survey in South India, the higher prevalence of adult diabetes (8.2%) in urban areas when compared to rural ones (2.4%) was related to both increased waist-hip ratio and BMI in urban subjects (ref 1).

 

The importance of central adiposity

In the early forties Dr Jean Vague, a French Physician, reported that the complications commonly found in obese patients were more closely related to the distribution of excess fat rather than to excess weight per se (ref 6).  Central adiposity is associated with deposition of a high proportion of fat intra-abdominally (ref 7) and may reflect the evolution in the past of a thrifty genotype, which can use non-esterified fatty acids in place of glucose as a muscle fuel and better tolerate prolonged periods of food scarcity (ref 8). Alternatively (or in addition), according to the thrifty phenotype hypothesis of Barker and Hales, the combination of insulin resistance, hypertension, dyslipidemia with hypertriglyceridaemia, and central adiposity may reflect an acquired metabolic adaptation of the individual to impaired growth in foetal life and early infancy (ref 9).

A large community survey conducted by McKeigue and colleagues of 2,936 men and 537 women in London demonstrated the importance of central obesity as an anthropometric marker of glucose intolerance in white Europeans and much more strongly in British South Asians (ref 10). Dhawan and colleagues demonstrated, in a case-control study of 200 male coronary heart disease patients and age-matched controls, that ethnic Indian men in both UK and India had higher total plasma insulin concentrations than white British men, in the fasting state and after a glucose load (ref 11). In these patients, hyperinsulinaemia was strongly associated with central obesity and these variables were associated both with one another and with the presence of coronary heart disease. In addition, both British and South Asians had lower HDL, higher LDL, and higher triglycerides levels than white British men, although total cholesterol levels were similar. Central obesity was inversely related to HDL level and directly related to hypertriglyceridaemia. These authors concluded that a “predisposition to insulin resistance and its metabolic abnormalities in this group of South Asians seems to be genetically determined; environmental changes after migration having only a small additional effect”. There have been “emerging factors” like adiponectin that may explain central adiposity and insulin resistance in South Asians. In a study Valsamakis et al demonstrated that in BMI matched subjects adiponectin levels were lower in South Asian when compared to Caucasians (ref 12). Hanif et al demonstrated that the levels were lower, even at the stage of impaired glucose tolerance, and high molecular weight adiponectin was more closely related to glucose dysregulation (refs 13, 14).

 

The evidence on diet

The question of exactly which aspects of the British South Asian lifestyle predisposes to glucose intolerance and dyslipidaemia remains largely unanswered. One uncontrolled experimental trial showed somewhat surprisingly, that a “typical ”Indian vegetarian diet induced higher and more prolonged rises in plasma glucose and free insulin levels than a “typical” European diet in a group of volunteers of mixed ethnic origin (ref 15). Ethnic Asian diets are said to contain more carbohydrate, less fat, less protein and more fibre than indigenous British diets. An epidemiological survey in which dietary intakes of 173 British South Asians and white Europeans were weighed and analysed did not demonstrate any greater coronary risk ( in terms of total calories, total fat, proportion of saturated fat, or fibre content) in the Asian diet, but showed that 2-hour plasma free insulin levels in the Asian subjects were directly related to the carbohydrate content of the diet (ref 16).

It must, be remembered, however, that the dietary preferences of South Asian ethnic groups are very diverse (ref 17), and generalisations should not be made. Ghee (clarified butter), for example is in common use in groups originating from north India and Bangladesh and has been shown to contain atherogenic constituents (ref 18), but ghee is rarely used by people of south Indian origin, whose risk of atherosclerotic disease is equally high (ref 19). A nutritional analysis of common Punjabi and Gujarati composite dishes from different households, as calculated from the records of weighed ingredients and portion sizes, showed considerable variation in the fat and energy content of different recipes (ref 20), suggesting the use of “typical” recipes for nutritional analysis will be inaccurate.

 

Physical inactivity

Physical inactivity is an independent risk factor for diabetes in Asians (ref 21). At diagnosis British South Asians are less likely to be physically active than other ethnic groups (ref 22).  A large survey of Asian immigrants to Australia showed that as individuals become culturally integrated, both physical activity levels and BMI increase but these changes are insufficient to explain the change in risk of cardiovascular disease (ref 23). Levels of physical activity in British South Asians have rarely been studied. Williams and colleagues’ survey, which used interview reports of exercise levels, showed a lower rate of vigorous exercise in British Asian men when compared to indigenous white males but no difference in women (ref 24). Dhawan and colleagues in a case control study of British Asians and Indian Asians showed that twice as many of the former took no physical exercise (ref 25).

The physical activity levels of a random sample of 4,658 subjects of Asian Indian, Chinese and Creole descent were recorded in Mauritius. The results of this large study not only confirm that physical inactivity is an important risk factor for IGT and diabetes in ethnic Asians, but also suggest a “dose-response” relationship, mediated by an effect on insulin-glucose metabolism (ref 26).

References

    [view abstract]

  2. Kumanyika SK. Special issues regarding obesity in minority populations. Ann Int Med 1993;119:650-654.
    [view abstract]

  3. Williams R, Bhopal R, Hunt K. Coronary risk in a British Punjabi population: comparative profile of non-biochemical factors. International Journal of Epidemiology 1994;23(1):28-37.
    [view abstract]

  4. World Health Organisation. The Asia-Pacific perspective: redefining obesity and its treatment; 2000.
    [download pdf]

  5. Hanif MW, Kumar S, O'Hare P, Jones AF, Mughal S, Dodd L, et al. Obesity is highly prevalent in Indo-Asian type 2 diabetics and increased risk of metabolic syndrome. Diabetic Med 2002;19 (supp 2):33.
    Further Details (P24, Page 6 of Full Text PDF link)
    [link to infomation on access]  Athens login or subscription required

  6. Despres JP, Lemieux I, Prud'homme D. Treatment of obesity: need to focus on high risk abdominally obese patients. BMJ  2001;322(7288):716-20.
    [link to full text]

  7. Mckeigue PM, Shah B, Marmott MG. Relation of central obesity and insulin resistance with diabetes prevalence and cardiovascular risk. Lancet 1991;337:382-386.
    [view abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Understanding and beliefs of diabetes in the UK Bangladeshi population
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES]]>
document.body:
This study examined the understanding and beliefs of people with diabetes from the Bangladeshi community living in the UK.

Structured one-to-one interviews were conducted in English or Sylheti with 14 people invited to a peer educational programme.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Understanding influences on smoking in Bangladeshi and Pakistani adults: community based, qualitative study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This study aims to gain a detailed understanding of influences on smoking behaviour in Bangladeshi and Pakistani communities in the UK as a means to informing the development of culturally acceptable and effective smoking cessation interventions.

A qualitative study including one to one interviews was conducted in Newcastle upon Tyne with 141 participants (87 male, 54 female) aged 18-80 years from the Pakistani and Bangladeshi communities.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Understanding of mental health and mental illness by Gujarati young people and their parents
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This is a report on a project exploring Gujerati Hindu young people's and their parents understanding of the terms "mental health" and "mental illness". Semi-structured interviews were carried out with 15 parents and 15 young people from an inner city community in which Gujeratis formed the largest social group.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Understanding why some ethnic minority patients evaluate medical care more negatively than white patients: a cross sectional analysis of a routine patient survey in English general practices.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE]]>
document.body:
This study examines why patients from ethnic minorities give poorer evaluations of primary health care than white patients.

1,098 English general practices surveyed patients using the 'General Practice Assessment Questionnaire' between April 2005 and March 2006.  188, 572 patients responded to the questionnaire.  A cross sectional analysis of between 133, 441 and 147, 686 of survey respondents was carried out for this study.

NHS Evidence - ethnicity and health: There is an editorial related to this study and a letter was written to the BMJ as a result of this study.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Understandings of depression: an interview study of Yoruba, Bangladeshi and White British people
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,MENTAL HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
This study aims to explore the views and understanding in three ethnic groups (Yoruba, Bangladeshi, white British) of depression.

 

Qualitative, semi-structured interviews were carried out on 20 Yoruba, 20 Bangladeshi and 20 white British people recruited from primary care practices in South London.

]]>

document.description: Vitamin D deficiency remains common in people of South Asian origin and may mimic other musculoskeletal disorders or mental health problems
document.body:
Case studies and literature review suggest that unrecognised Vitamin D Hypovitaminosis in people of South Asian origin in Britain may be on the increase or presenting new challenges. 

 

Extract of related BMJ editorial

document.title: Use of herbal remedies to promote general wellbeing by individuals of African-Caribbean origin in England
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,TRADITIONAL MEDICINE AND TREATMENTS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This paper presents an account of an ethnographic study which aimed to describe Caribbean hypertension patients' use of herbal remedies.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: User participation in health care services
document.publisher: Race for Health, Department of Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,NHS ACTIVITIES,SERVICE SECTORS,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HEALTH AND SOCIAL CARE,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,RACE EQUALITY,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Better Health Briefing 7

This eight page briefing includes further references and resources.

Key messages:

  • Black and minority ethnic (BME) groups generally have poorer health than the overall population, although the extent of ethnic health inequalities is masked by poor data collection

  • Low take-up of services among black and minority ethnic communities is still frequently explained as being due to cultural and social preferences within these communities, despite contrary evidence

  • Black and minority ethnic users and carers lack support to use the available information and have little faith in those services that exist

  • Users from black and minority ethnic communities want greater diverse provision to be as explicit a goal of health care as it increasingly is of  social care

  • The NHS workforce should better represent the local communities it serves, especially at senior levels. However, what most black and minority ethnic users really want is better training for all staff

  • Despite the importance given by the Department of Health to choice and involvement, user participation still remains an ambition rather than a reality for black and minority ethnic users.  However, BME user participation is key to improving the organisation and delivery of health care services.
]]>

document.body: <![CDATA[ This article discusses specific methodological issues in the use of focus groups with minority ethnic communities in a study on the provision of infertility services to south Asian communities in three English cities.]]>
