document.body: <![CDATA[ This study investigated levels of knowledge of diabetes self-care and perceived self-efficacy in carrying out self-care behaviours in individuals with diabetes from south Asian backgrounds. ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Validating self-rated health in different ethnic groups
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body:
Social surveys and medical research increasingly use subjective accounts of health status to assess well-being; however some concerns have been raised that different ethnic groups may interpret health status in different ways. This study investigates the validity of using self-rated health status to measure health in different ethnic groups.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Valuing and recognising the talents of a diverse healthcare workforce
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES,HUMAN RESOURCES]]>
document.body:
When the report was commissioned the recruitment of nurses was a priority for the Department of Health. This priority has shifted somewhat during the time of the research to retention of nursing staff, including overseas-trained nurses. This concern with retention means that employers must make the best use of overseas-trained nurses already in post, by identifying in particular how best to accredit their skills, how to help them learn new skills for UK practice and how to promote them to posts within the UK workforce where they can make best use of their often extensive clinical and managerial experiences.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Variations in health behaviours among inner city 12-year-olds from four ethnic groups.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
A description of factors that contribute to variations in health related attitudes and behaviours among inner city 12 year olds, particularly amongst ethnic groups.

A stratified sample of twelve year old students and their parents from 4 ethnic groups took part in semi-structured interviews.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Views of general practitioners towards refugees and asylum seekers: an interview study
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,DOCTORS,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
Semi-structured interviews were conducted with 17 general practioners working in an urban environment, approximately half of which working in practices which recieved high numbers of refugees and asylum seekers.

Interviews were conducted to measure views on: resource and resources management, the logisitics of the asylum process, the impact on primary care of asylum seekers and refugees and new training needs as a result of this.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Vitamin D deficiency in UK Asian families: activating a new concern
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,DIET,MUSCULOSKELETAL]]>
document.body:
In this review, the incidence, aetiology, prevention, and treatment of symptomatic vitamin D deficiency in childhood are considered. A renewed public health campaign is required in the UK to address the continuing problem of vitamin D deficiency in Asian families.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Vulnerability and access to care for south Asian Sikh and Muslim patients with life limiting illness in Scotland: prospective longitudinal qualitative study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH LONG TERM & CHRONIC CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
An examination of the care experiences of Sikh and Muslim patients of south Asian descent with life limiting illness as well as the experiences of their families. The study also looks at any difficulties with access to services for these patients and how they may be overcome.

In depth interviews were carried out with 25 patients (Muslim or Sikh), 18 family carers and 20 key health professionals.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: We can: reducing inequalities in commissioning cancer services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,RACE EQUALITY,COMMISSIONING,POPULATIONS SERVED,DISEASE/CONDITION GROUPS,CANCERS AND TUMOURS,DISADVANTAGED GROUPS]]>
document.description: Principles and practical guidance for good equality working
document.body:
This guidance is intended for those in PCTs, SHAs, cancer networks and voluntary sector organisations who are running or commissioning services aimed at reducing cancer inequalities.

It is intended to be used both as a tool such as a checklist for equalities proposals and tenders and as guidance.

The document includes:

  • Foreword
  • Introduction
  • Key principles and practical guidance for equality working
  • Underpinning activity
  • Further information
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: 'We should change ourselves, but we can't': accounts of food and eating practices amongst British Pakistanis and Indians with type 2 diabetes
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,DIABETES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Interviews with 23 Pakistanis and nine Indians with type 2 diabetes were conducted in this study.  The objective was to examine food and eating practices, their perceptions of the barriers and facilitators to dietary change, and the social and cultural factors informing their accounts.]]>

A cross-sectional design was used, qualitative in depth semi-structured interviews were conducted.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: What do language barriers cost? an exploratory study among asylum seekers in Switzerland
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,CULTURAL COMPETENCE,LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,REFUGEES AND ASYLUM SEEKERS]]>
document.body:
Language barriers can have a major impact on the quality and costs of health care, and while there is a growing evidence base for the detrimental effects they have on the quality of health care provision, there is little about the impact on costs.  This study investigates the associations between language barriers and the costs of health care.

A cross-sectional survey was conducted using data sourced from the Swiss Health Maintenance Organisation.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Wheeze and asthma prevalence and related health-service use in white and south Asian pre-schoolchildren in the United Kingdom
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISORDERS,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
There is contradictory data for south Asian children with asthma in the UK even though they show a lower prevalence of wheeze they have a higher level of medical consultations and hospital admissions. This study compares the prevalence of wheeze and health related service use in south Asian and white pre-school children in the UK.

Parents of white (4366) and south Asian (1714) children aged 1-4 years completed a postal questionnaire.

There is a comment on this study available here.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Which aspects of non-clinical quality of care are most important? Results from WHO's general population surveys of " health systems responsiveness" in 41 countries.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Using 105,866 survey interview records from the World Health Organisation's general population surveys of 41 countries this paper describes the relative importance of eight domains of non-clinical quality of care in health systems responsiveness.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Why poor quality of ethnicity data should not preclude its use for identifying disparities in health and healthcare
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,ETHNIC RECORD KEEPING]]>
document.body:
Concerns over the completeness, accuracy and timeliness of ethnicity data are long standing; this review aims to identify incompleteness of ethnicity data across routine health and healthcare datasets.

An analysis was conducted to identify incompleteness of ethnicity data by government office regions. Literature was then reviewed to identify appropriate analytical strategies to address this issue.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Widening access to cardiovascular healthcare community screening among ethnic minorities in inner-city Britain: the Healthy Hearts Project
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
The majority of cases of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in Britain occur in inner city areas including those with diverse multi-ethnic populations. This study describes a health screening project that took place in Sandwell, Birmingham.

Ten health screening events were held with 842 people participating in total. Community groups in the study included: Gujarati Indian, Punjabi Indian, white European, Yemeni, Pakistani and Bangladeshi.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Will community-based support services make direct payments a viable option for black and minority ethnic service users and carers?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLIENT GROUPS,PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MINORITY ETHNIC GROUPS]]>
document.body:
More and more people are choosing the "direct payments" scheme for personal assistance over those supplied by local authorities.

This scheme has given disabled people more choice and control over their lives than ever before; however black and minority ethnic (BME) communities are failing to benefit from the scheme and there is a growing evidence base concluding that BME service users and carers will be under represented in the scheme.

The purpose of this discussion paper is:

  • to explain the latest legislation on the "direct payments" scheme and how it is meant to work
  • to summarise the growing research and secondary evidence pointing to the inability of BME service users and carers to fully embrace direct payments
  • to find ways in which the "direct payments" scheme can be effective for service users and carers  
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Women at the Crossroads
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER]]>
document.body:
111-1Women at the Crossroads

Written for the 'ethnicity and health' Annual Evidence Update 2010

 


 

Professor Anil Jain
MB BS, MD, FRCR, PG Dip (Medical Law)

Consultant Radiologist
Dept of Radiology and The Nightingale Centre & Genesis Prevention Centre
University Hospital of South Manchester NHS Foundation Trust


 

 

South Asian Women at the Crossroads
- rising breast cancer incidence, poor breast cancer awareness and poor screening uptake

Introduction
Ethnic minority communities comprise 9% of the population in England and Wales, with almost half from the Indian subcontinent (2001 Census). This is predicted to increase to 20% in the next 40 years [ref 1].

Many South Asian origin women are multilingual but a lot can only read their own language and some cannot read at all. Breast cancer awareness and breast screening uptake rates remain consistently low in South Asian women.

It is now recognised that South Asian women who live in the west have a higher incidence of breast cancer then that in their country of origin. This is due to changes in life style and increases in other environmental risk factors for breast cancer [ref 2]. There has been an increase in breast cancer incidence amongst South Asian women within the Indian subcontinent also. In 2008 there 115,251 new cases of breast cancer in India but this is predicted to rise to 250,000 cases by 2015 [ref 4].


UK incidence of breast cancer in South Asian women
In 2002, the national age standardised breast cancer incidence rates (per 100,000 women) in the UK, the Caribbean, West Africa and India were 87.2, 32.9, 27.8 and 19.1 respectively [ref 5]. The age-adjusted rates reported from various urban registries in India are much higher and range from 24.8 to 33.4 per 100,000 [ref 3]. However, it has been identified that South Asian women who live in the UK have a significantly higher incidence of breast cancer (64.6/100,000 women) [ref 3]. This difference may partly be due to early diagnosis but will also be due to changes in life style, e.g. later marriages and first child, a fewer number of children, shorter breast feeding period and other increased environmental risk factors.


In India, breast cancer incidence peaks among women 45–50 years of age. The average age of patients in six hospital-based cancer registries has been reported to range from 44.2 in Dibrugarh, 46.8 in Delhi, 47 in Jaipur to 49.6 in Bangalore and Chennai. Among patients in a Lucknow hospital, 26% were younger than 35 years of age, whereas in a hospital in Mumbai, this percentage was 11% [refs 3 & 7]. In a study by Kakarala et al (2010), among US Asian Indian/Pakistani breast cancer patients, 16.2% were women younger than 40 years of age or premenopausal women compared to 6.23% in Caucasian women (p < 0.0001). The higher percentage of women aged under 40 with breast cancer diagnosed in the Asian Indian/Pakistani population was mirrored in peri-menopausal 40-50 yr olds, occurring in 29.9% of Asian Indians/Pakistanis compared to 18.9% of Caucasian women (p < 0.0001) [ref 8].


In the UK, NHS Breast screening is offered from age 50 to 70 and this will be extended to 47 to 73 yr old by 2012. Hence it is likely that many South Asian women will develop breast cancer even before their screening invitation and present as symptomatic cases.


Poor breast cancer awareness and poor screening uptake
It is well documented that South Asian women have poor breast cancer awareness. To a large extent this is due to poor general health literacy and lack of availability of language specific and culturally sensitive information [ref 9]. This is a ‘double whammy’ since they need to be even more breast-aware due to the higher incidence of symptomatic presentation in the younger age group prior to eligibility for the NHS Breast Screening Programme (NHSBSP).


Unfortunately, even once invited, breast screening uptake rates also remain consistently low, particularly in Bangladeshi and Pakistani women [refs 10 & 11]. This again appears to be due to lack of knowledge and information (see section above). Uptake rates are even lower where ethnicity and deprivation are combined e.g. in our inner city areas and some of our northern English towns [refs 12, 11 and 10].


Overall, the NHSBSP breast units appear to have poor communication with their South Asian population with low utilisation of even freely available translated materials. This is partly attributed to lack of prior knowledge of a patient’s language before a screening appointment. But, even for patients who present to screening vans or static units, hardly any attempt is made to provide them with translated material or raise their level of breast cancer awareness [ref 9].


Histological and prognostic parameters
South Asian women with cancer diagnosed at screening have similar Nottingham Prognostic Index score based on histological parameters, and this should encourage their greater participation in breast screening [ref 6].


Kakarala et al [ref 8], in their study of Asian Indian and Pakistani women in the US had more oestrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative tumours than their Caucasian counterparts. Invasive ductal carcinoma was the most common histology. Inflammatory cancer was also more common in Asian Indians/Pakistanis than Caucasians. In India, about 60% of SGPGIMS, Lucknow breast cancer patients have grade 3 tumors, 66% have axiliary lymph node metastases, and 58% are both ER and PR receptor-negative [ref 7]. Data from Mumbai shows a slightly lower ER- and PR-negative rate of 47% [ref 13]. Although data on HER-2neu immuno-reactivity are scarce, the available information hints at low rates of positive HER-2neu status: 17% of 100 breast cancer patients recently treated at SGPGIMS were found to overexpress HER-2neu. On the whole, women younger than 35 years of age presented with larger tumours and at a later stage. They were also more likely to be ER-negative and to have a higher grade of cancer compared to the overall average [ref 7].


All the above clearly lower the prognostic outcome for South Asian women due to limited treatment options.  Hence, despite a lower incidence of breast cancer in India, the mortality rates are disproportionately higher [refs 14, 15]. The 5-year survival rate of breast cancer patients reported at Bangalore’s population-based cancer registry was 42.3% [ref 16]. The Madras Metropolitan Tumor Registry reported survival rates of 80, 58, and 48% at 1 year, 3 years, and 5 years, respectively [ref 17]. These survival rates are much lower than those in the Western world.  For example, Canadian 5-year relative survival rate for breast cancers diagnosed from 1995–1997 is 86% overall [ref 18] whilst in Sweden the current overall survival rates at a national level are 86% at 5 years and 75% at 10 years [ref 19]).


Conclusions
With a predicted increase in the South Asian population in the UK it is likely that, similar to their counterpart in India, the burden of breast cancer will increase with rather aggressive tumours presenting at relatively younger age and with poorer prognosis. Hence, there is an overwhelming need to raise breast cancer awareness amongst this population from a younger age along with early risk assessment, annual Clinical Breast Examination (CBE) and screening, if at high risk. It is also important to encourage women to take preventative measures with regard to diet and exercise to decrease cancer risk factors.


It should remain a DOH priority to improve the screening uptake rates for South Asian women with all necessary measures. These should include recording of women’s ethnicity and language by the PCTs (or their successors), provision of language specific translated, pictorial, audio and video materials and provision of link workers or community health educators. There is also a need to take more active steps to promote breast screening in the South Asian media, along with raising awareness amongst the very large cohort of South Asian health professionals now working in the NHS, who can then take this message to their family, friends and communities.

References

  1. Wohland P, Rees P, Norman P, Boden P and Jasinska M (2010) Ethnic Population Projections for the UK and Local Areas, 2001-2051, Working Paper 10/2, School of Geography, University of Leeds
    [download pdf] (4.08 mb - 185 pages)

  2. Rastogi, T., Devesa, S., Mangtani, P., & A. Mathew et al. (2008). Cancer incidence rates among South Asians in four geographic regions: India, Singapore, UK and US. International Journal of Epidemiology. Vol. 37, pt. 1, pp. 147-60.
    [download pdf]

  3. Nandakumar A, Gupta PC, Gangadharan P, Visweswara RN (eds) (2004) Summary of specific sites: breast (ICD-10:C50)-females. In: Development of an atlas of cancer in India: first all India report: 2001–2002, Bangalore, India.
    [view website] NB: The website giving details may produce a certificate warning.

  4. Globocan Project 2008, Cancer Incidence and Mortality Worldwide in 2008. International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), World Health Organization. June 2010
    [view details]

  5. International Agency for research on Cancer. Cancer incidence in five continents. Volume VIII. IARC.Sci Publ 2002; (155): 1-781
    [view details]


  6. Henderson L, Jain A, Astley S (2006). Do Asian women with screen detected breast cancer have a poorer prognosis based on histological parameters? Proceedings of RCR Breast Group Conference, Edinburgh Nov 2006
    [view details] [access poster]

  7. Stanley P. L., Leong, Zhen-Zhou Shen, Tse-Jia Liu, Gaurav Agarwal, Tomoo Tajima, Nam-Sun Paik, Kerstin Sandelin, Anna Derossis, Hiram Cody, and William D. Foulkes. Is Breast Cancer the Same Disease in Asian and Western Countries? World J Surg. 2010 October; 34(10): 2308–2324.
    [view abstract]

  8. Kakarala, M, Rozek L, Cote M, Liyanage S, Brenner, D(2010).  Breast cancer histology and receptor status characterization in Asian Indian and Pakistani women in the U.S. - a SEER analysis. BMC Cancer 2010, 10:191.  doi:10.1186/1471-2407-10-191.
    [view abstract] [download pdf]

  9. Jain AK, Acik-Toprak N, Serevitch J, Nazroo J. The NHS Breast Screening Programme – Are we communicating well with South Asian Origin Women. EJC Supplements Sept 2010. doi:1016/j.ejcsup.2010.06.091

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Ethnicity and Health]]>
document.title: Zimbabwean cultural traditions in England: Ubuntu-Hunhu as a human rights tool
document.publisher: Diversity in Health and Social Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,CLIENT GROUPS,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,PEOPLE WITH LONG TERM & CHRONIC CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This study explored the meaning of Ubuntu-Hunhu, a Zimbabwean notion grounded in respect, humanity and the interconnectedness of beings, and the applicability of this concept in helping those with HIV.

These cultural resources can be harnessed in conducting research on sensitive topics such as HIV or used to deliver health promotion interventions.

]]>
